Block chain based Decentralized Applications Technology Review and Development Guidelines Claudia Pop Tudor Cio ara Ion ut Ang hel Marcel An tal and Ioan Salom ie Computer Science Department Technical University of Cluj Napoca Memorandum ului Cluj Napoca Romania claudia pop cs utc luj ro tudor cio ara cs utc luj ro ion ut ang hel cs utc luj ro marcel an tal cs utc luj ro ioan salom ie cs utc luj ro Abstract Block chain or Distributed Ledger Technology is disruptive technology that provides the infrastructure for developing decentralized applications enabling the implementation of novel business models even in traditionally centralized domains In the last years it has drawn high interest from the academic community technology developers and startup thus lots of solutions have been developed to address block chain technology limitations and the requirements of applications software engineering In this paper we provide comprehensive overview of LT solutions analyzing the addressed challenges provided solutions and their usage for developing decentralized applications Our study reviews over block chain papers and startup initiatives from which we construct tier based architecture for decentralized applications and we use it to systematically classify the technology solutions Protocol and Network Tier solutions address the digital assets registration transactions data structure and privacy and business rules implementation and the creation of peer to peer networks ledger replication and consensus based state validation Scaling Tier solutions address the cal ability problems in terms of storage size transaction throughput and computational capability Finally Federated Tier aggregates integrative solutions across multiple block chain applications deployments The paper closes with discussion on challenges and opportunities for developing decentralized applications by providing multi step guideline for decentralizing the design of traditional systems and implementing decentralized applications Keywords Block chain decentralized applications development distributed ledger technology guideline for block chain application implementation block chain application architecture

Abstract of Adapting Persistent Data Structures for Concurrency and Speculation by Thomas Dickers on Ph Brown University May This work unies insights from the systems and functional programming communities in order to enable compositional reasoning about software which is nonetheless cie ntl realizable in hard ware It exploits correspondence between design goals for ec ent concurrent data structures and ec ent immutable persistent data structures to produce novel implementations of mutable concur rent trees with low contention and an ec ent snapshot operation to support speculative execution models It also exploits com mut at iv it to characterize design space for integrating traditional high performance concurrent data structures into Software Transactional Memory STM run times and extends this technique to yield novel algorithm for concurrent execution of so called smart contracts specialized programs which manipulate the state of block chain ledgers

ar Xiv Article Block chain Based Distributed Patient Centric Image Management System Mohamed Ya seen Jab arul la and Heung No Lee School of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Gwangju Institute of Science and Technology Gwangju Korea ya seen gm gist ac kr Correspondence heung no gist ac kr Received date Accepted date Published date Abstract In recent years many researchers have focused on developing feasible solution for storing and exchanging medical images in the field of health care Current practices are deployed on cloud based centralized data centers which increase maintenance costs require massive storage space and raise privacy concerns about sharing information over network Therefore it is important to design framework to enable sharing and storing of big medical data efficiently within trust less environment In the present paper we propose novel proof of concept design for distributed patient centric image management PCI system that is aimed to ensure safety and control of patient private data without using centralized infrastructure In this system we employed an emerging there um block chain and distributed file system technology called Inter Planetary File System PFS Then we implemented an there um smart contract called the patient centric access control protocol to enable distributed and trustworthy access control policy PFS provides the means for decentralized storage of medical images with global accessibility We describe how the PCI system architecture facilitates the distributed and secured patient centric data access across multiple entities such as hospitals patients and image request or Finally we deployed smart contract prototype on an there um test net block chain and evaluated the proposed framework within the Windows environment The evaluation results demonstrated that the proposed scheme is efficient and feasible Keywords Block chain distributed storage medical image sharing healthcare system smart contract PFS

Block chain Governance An Overview and Prediction of Optimal Strategies using Nash Equilibrium Nida Khan Tab rez Ahmad An as Patel and Radu State SEDAN Research Group University of Luxembourg Luxembourg ArcelorMittal Europe Luxembourg as France nida khan uni lu Abstract Block chain governance is subject of ongoing research and an inter disciplinary view of block chain governance is vital to aid in further research for establishing formal governance framework for this nascent technology In this paper the position of block chain governance within the hierarchy of Institutional governance is discussed Block chain governance is analyzed from the per spec ti ve of IT governance using Nash equilibrium to predict the outcome of different governance decisions payoff matrix for block chain governance is created and simulation of different strategy profiles is accomplished for computation of all Nash qui libri The paper elaborates upon payoff matrices for different kinds of block chain governance which are used in the proposition of novel mathematical formulae usable to predict the best governance strategy that minimizes the occur rence of hard fork as well as predicts the behavior of the majority during pro to col updates The paper also includes validation of the proposed formulae using real there um data Keywords Block chain governance Nash equilibrium Game theory IT gov er nance Mathematical optimization

TRANSACTIONAL PERSPECTIVE ON EXECUTE ORDER VALIDATE BLOCK CHAINS PRE PRINT Ping cheng Ru an Du mitre lL oghi Quang Trung Ta National University of Singapore National University of Singapore National University of Singapore rua npc comp nus edu sg dum it rel comp nus edu sg ta qt comp nus edu sg Mei hui Zhang Gang Chen Be ng ChinO oi Beijing Institute of Technology Zhejiang University National University of Singapore mei hui zhang bit edu cn cg zju edu cn oo ibc comp nus edu sg March ABSTRACT Smart contracts have enabled block chain systems to evolve from simple crypto currency platforms such as Bitcoin to general transactional systems such as there um Catering for emerging business requirements new architecture called execute order validate has been proposed in Hyper ledger Fabric to support parallel transactions and improve the block chains throughput However this new architecture might render many invalid transactions when serializing them This problem is further exaggerated as the block formation rate is inherently limited due to other factors beside data processing such as cryptography and consensus In this work we propose novel method to enhance the execute order validate architecture by re duc ing invalid transactions to improve the throughput of block chains Our method is inspired by state of the art optimistic concurrency control techniques in modern database systems In contrast to existing block chains that adopt databases preventive approaches which might abort serial iz able transactions our method is theoretically more ne grained Spec ic ally unser aliz able transactions are aborted before ordering and the remaining transactions are guaranteed to be serial iz able For evaluation we implement our method in two block chains respectively Fabric Sharp on top of Hy per ledger Fabric and Fast Fabric Sharp on top of Fast Fabric We compare the performance of Fab ric Sharp with vanilla Fabric and three related systems two of which are respectively implemented with one standard and one state of the art concurrency control techniques from databases There sul ts demonstrate that Fabric Sharp achieves higher throughput compared to the other systems in nearly all experimental scenarios Moreover the Fast Fabric Sharps improvement over Fast Fabric is up to Keywords Optimistic Concurrency Control Block chain Execute Order Validate Transaction Database

Block Mark chain Secure Decentralized Data Market with Constant Load on the Block chain Hamid reza Eh te ram Mohammad Tah To hani and Mohammad Ali Madda Ali Department of Electrical Engineering Sharif University of Technology Tehran Iran Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering Rice University Houston TX USA Nokia Bell Labs Holm del NJ USA Abstract In this paper we develop Block Mark chain as secure data market place where individual data sellers can exchange cer tied data with buyers in secure environment without any mutual trust among the parties and without trusting on third party as mediator To develop this platform were lyon smart contract deployed on secure public block chain The main challenges here are to verify the validity of data and to prevent malicious behavior of the parties while preserving the privacy of the data and taking into account the limited computing and storage resources available on the block chain In Block Mark chain the buyer has the option to dispute the honesty of the seller and prove the invalidity of the data to the smart contract The smart contract evaluates the buyers claim and punishes the dishonest party by forfeiting his her deposit in favor of the honest party Block Mark chain enjoys several salient features including the cer tied data has never been revealed on the public block chain ii the size of data posted on the block chain the load of computation on the block chain and the cost of communication with the block chain is constant and negligible and iii the computation cost of ver cations on the parties is not expensive

Block EOS Extracting and Exploring Block chain Data From EOS IO Weil in Zheng Zi bin Zheng Hong Ning Dai Xu Chen Peil in Zheng School of Data and Computer Science Sun Yat sen University Guangzhou China National Engineering Research Center of Digital Life Sun Yat sen University Guangzhou China Faculty of Information Technology Macau University of Science and Technology Macau Abstract Block chain based crypto currencies and applications have our is he in block chain research community Massive data generated from diverse block chain systems bring not only huge business values but also technological challenges in data analytics of heterogeneous block chain data Die rent from Bitcoin and there um EOS IO has richer diversity and higher volume of block chain data due to its unique arch tec ural design in resource management consensus scheme and high throughput Despite its popularity blocks generated till November since its launch on June few studies have been made on data analysis of EOS IO To ll this gap we collect and process the up to date on chain data from EOS IO We name these well processed EOS IO datasets as Block EOS which consists of well processed datasets Block Transaction and Action Internal and External EOS Transfer Action Contract Information Contract Invocation Token Action Account Creation Resource Management It is challenging to process and analyze high volume of raw EOS IO data and establish the mapping from original raw data to the well grained datasets since it requires substantial or ts in extracting various types of data as well as sophisticated knowledge on software engineering and data analytics Meanwhile we present statistics and exploration on these datasets Moreover we also outline the possible research opportunities based on Block EOS Keywords Block chain EOS IO Big Data Data Acquisition Data Analysis Security

Can Advanced Type Systems Be Usable An Empirical Study of Ownership Assets and Type state in Obsidian MICHAEL COBLENZ Carnegie Mellon University USA JONATHAN ALDRICH Carnegie Mellon University USA BRAD MYERS Carnegie Mellon University USA JOSHUA SUNSHINE Carnegie Mellon University USA Some block chain programs smart contracts have included serious security vulnerabilities Obsidian is newtype state oriented programming language that uses strong type system to rule out some of these vulnerabilities Although Obsidian was designed to promote usability to make it as easy as possible to write programs strong type systems can cause language to be difficult to use In particular ownership type state and assets which Obsidian uses to provide safety guarantees have not seen broad adoption together in popular languages and result insignificant usability challenges We performed an empirical study with participants comparing Obsidian to Solidity which is the language most commonly used for writing smart contracts today We observed that Obsidian participants were able to successfully complete more of the programming tasks than the Solidity participants We also found that the Solidity participants commonly inserted asset related bugs which Obsidian detects at compile time CCS Concepts Software and its engineering Language features Domain specific languages Security and privacy Software and application security Human centered computing Empirical studies in HC Additional KeyWords and Phrases type state linear types ownership assets permissions block chain smart contracts empirical studies of programming languages ACM Reference Format Michael Coblenz Jonathan Aldrich Brad Myers and Joshua Sunshine Can Advanced Type Systems Be Usable An Empirical Study of Ownership Assets and Type state in Obsidian Proc ACM Program Lang OOPS LA Article November pages https doi org

Topological Properties of Multi Party Block chain Transactions Dong fang Zhao Department of Computer Science and Engineering The University of Nevada Reno NV United States zhao unr edu Abstract The cross block chain transaction remains one of the most challenging problems in block chains The root cause of the challenge lies in the non deterministic nature of block chains An party transaction across multiple block chains might be partially rolled back due to the potential forks in any of the participating block chains eventually only one fork will survive in the competition among miners While some effort has recently been made to developing hierarchically distributed commit protocols to make multi party transactions progress there is no systematic method to reason about the transaction outcome This paper tackles this problem from perspective of point set topology We construct multiple topological spaces for the transactions and block chain forks and show that these spaces are internally related through either home morphism or continuous functions Combined together these tools allow us to reason about the cross block chain transactions through the growing fork topology an intuitive representation of block chains Index Terms Block chains multi party transactions point set topology home morphism

Attacking with Bitcoin Using Bitcoin to Build Resilient Botnet Armies Dimitri Kamen ski rash Shag hag hi Matthew Warren and lil Kan here Centre for Cyber Security Research and Innovation Deakin University Australia The University of New South Wales Sydney Australia kamen ski shag hag hi matthew warren deakin edu au lil kan here nsw edu au Abstract We focus on the problem of botnet orchestration and is cus show attackers can leverage de centralised technologies to dynamically control botnets with the goal of having botnets that are resilient against hostile takeovers We cover critical elements of the Bitcoin block chain and its usage for oat ing command and control servers We further is cuss how block chain based botnets can be built and include detailed discussion of our implementation We also showcase how spec ic Bitcoin APIs can be used in order to write extraneous data to the block chain Finally while in this paper we use Bitcoin to build our resilient botnet proof of concept the threat is not limited to Bitcoin block chain and can be generalized Keywords Bitcoin Botnet Dynamic Block chain

The cost of Bitcoin mining has never really increased Yo Der Song and Toma so As te Department of Computer Science Centre for Block chain Technologies University College London Gower Street WC EA London United Kingdom The Bitcoin network is burning large amount of energy for mining In this paper we estimate the lower bound for the global energy cost for period of ten years from taking into account changing oil costs improvements in hashing technologies and hashing activity Despite ten billion fold increase in hashing activity and ten million fold increase in total energy consumption we nd the cost relative to the volume of transactions has not increased nor decreased since This is cons is tent with the perspective that in order to keep the Block chain system secure from double spending attacks the proof or work must cost sizable fraction of the value that can be transferred through the network We estimate that in the Bitcoin network this fraction is of the order of Keywords Bitcoin mining cost proof of work crypto currency block chain

Pre print of accepted manuscript in Advanced Engineering Informatics CC BY NC ND license Do you need block chain in construction Use case categories and decision framework for LT design options Jens Hun he vic Daniel Hall Institute of Construction and Infrastructure Management Department of Civil Environmental and Geo mati Engineering ETH Zurich Zurich Switzerland Corresponding author Abstract Block chain and other forms of distributed ledger technology LT provide an opportunity to integrate digital information management and contracts to increase trust and collaboration within the construction industry LT enables direct peer to peer transactions of value across distributed network by providing an immutable and transparent record of these transactions Furthermore there is potential for business process optimization and automation on the transaction level through the use of smart contracts which are code protocols deployed on supported LT systems However LT research in the construction industry remains at theoretical level there have been few implementation case studies to date One potential reason for this is knowledge gap between use case ideas and the LT technical system implementation This paper aims to reduce this gap by reviewing and categorizing proposed LT use cases in construction literature providing an overview of LT and its design options proposing an integrated framework to match LT design options with desired characteristics of use case and analysing the use cases using the new framework Together the use case categories and proposed decision framework can guide future implementers toward more connected and structured thinking between the technological properties of LT and use cases in construction Keywords Construction Industry Construction Automation Block chain Distributed Ledger Technology LT Smart Contracts

Adversary Power Resistant Block chain harding Approach Yi bin Xu Jian hua Shao Yang yuHuan Ti sSl at and Boris udder Abstract Block chain harding is block chain performance enhancement approach By splitting block chain into several parallel run committees shards it helps increase transaction throughput reduce computational resources required and increase reward expectation for participants Recently several ex ib les harding methods that can tolerate upton Byzantine nodes security level have been proposed However these methods sue from three main drawbacks First in non harding block chain nodes can have die rent weight power or stake to create consensus and as such an adversary needs to control half of the overall weight in order to manipulate the system security level In block chains harding all nodes carry the same weight Thus it is only under the assumption that honest participants create as many nodes as they should that security level block chain harding reaches the security level Second when some nodes leave the system other nodes need to be reassigned frequently from shard to shard in order to maintain the security level This has an adverse eec on system performance Third while some approaches can maintain data integrity with upton Byzantine nodes their systems can halt with smaller number of Byzantine nodes In this paper we present security level block chains harding approach that does not require honest participants to create multiple nodes requires less node reassignment when some nodes leave the system and can prevent the system from halting Our experiments show that our new approach outperforms existing block chain harding approaches in terms of security transaction throughput and ex bil it Keywords Block chain Distributed Ledger Block chain Security Block chainS harding Block chain Performance

Change Block chain based Mechanism for Generic Asset Trading In Resource constrained Environments Technical Report Marti jn de Vos Can mut Il eri devo tu delft nl il eri tu delft nl Johan Po uw else po uw else tu delft nl April Abstract An increasing number of industries rely on Internet of Things devices to track physical resources Block chain technology provides primitives to represent these resources as digital assets on secure distributed ledger Due to the proliferation of block chain based assets there is an increasing need for generic mechanism to trade assets between isolated platforms To date there is no such mechanism without reliance on trusted third party In this work we address this shortcoming and present Change Change mediates trade of any digital asset between isolated block chain platforms while limiting the fraud conducted by adversarial parties We rst describe generic ve phase trading protocol that establishes and executes trade between individuals This protocol accounts full trade spec cations on separate block chain We then devise lightweight system architecture composed of all required components for generic asset marketplace We implement Change and conduct real world experimentation We leverage an existing lightweight block chain Trust Chain to account all orders and full trade spec cations By deploying Change on multiple low resource devices we show that full trade completes within half second To quantify the cal ability of our mechanism we conduct further experiments on our compute clu ter We conclude that the throughput of Change in terms of trades per second scales linearly with the system load Furthermore we nd that Change exhibits superior throughput and order full latency compared to related decentralized exchanges Bit Shares and Waves

Intelligence Cairo University Egypt Scientific Research Group in Egypt SR GE Egypt Abstract The world is currently witnessing dangerous shifts in the epidemic of emerging SARS CoV the causative agent of OVID coronavirus The infection and death numbers reported by World Health Organization WHO about this epidemic forecasts an increasing threats to the lives of people and the economics of countries The greatest challenge that most governments are currently suffering from is the lack of precise mechanism to detect unknown infected cases and predict the infection risk of OVID virus In response to mitigate this challenge this study proposes novel innovative approach for mitigating big challenges of OVID coronavirus propagation and contagion This study propose block chain based framework which investigate the possibility of utilizing peer to peer time stamping and decentralized storage advantages of block chain to build new system for verifying and detecting the unknown infected cases of Continuous Credit Networks and Layer Block chains Monotonic it and Sampling SHISH GO EL Stanford University GEOFFREY RAMSEY ER Stanford University To improve transaction rates many crypto currencies have implemented so called Layer transaction protocols where payments rerouted across networks of private payment channels However for given transaction not every network state provides feasible route to perform the payment in this case the transaction must be put on the public ledger The payment channel network thus multiplies the transaction rate of the overall system the less frequently it fails the higher the multiplier We build on earlier work on credit networks and show that this network liquidity problem is connected to the combinatorics of graphical mat roid Earlier work could only analyze the unnatural scenario where transactions had discrete sizes In this work we give an analytical framework that removes this assumption This enables meaningful liquidity analysis for real world parameter regimes Superficially it might seem like the continuous case would be harder to examine However removing this assumption lets us make progress in two important directions First we give partial answer to the monotonic it conjecture that previous work left open This conjecture asks that the networks performance not degrade as capacity on any edge increases And second we construct here network state sampling procedure with much faster asymptotic performance than off the shelf Markov chains where is the complexity of solving linear program on constraints We obtain our results by mapping the underlying graphs to convex bodies and then showing that the liquidity and sampling problems reduce to bounding and computing the volumes of these bodies The trans formation relies crucially on the combinatorial properties of the underlying graphic mat roid as do the proofs of monotonic it and fast sampling CCS Concepts Applied computing Electronic funds transfer Digital cash integrity image authentication has the potential to be enhanced by block chain There are many techniques that can be used to authenticate images the technique investigated by this work is image hashing Image hashing is technique used to calculate how similar two different images are This is done by converting the images into hashes and then comparing them using distance formula To investigate the topic an experiment involving simulated block chain was created The block chain acted as database for images This block chain was made up of devices which contained their Keywords own unique image hashing algorithms The block chain was tested by creating modified copies of Block chain the images contained in the database and then submitting them to the block chain to see if it will hashing However the design Image hashing proposed by this work requires refinement as it appears to struggle in some situations This work shows that block chain can be suitable approach for authenticating images particularly via image hashing Other observations include that using multiple image hash algorithms at the same time can increase performance in some cases as well as that each type of test done to the block chain has its own unique pattern to its data

Mean Field Game Approach to Bitcoin Mining Charles Ber tucci Louis Ber tucci Jean Michel Las ry Pierre Louis Lions April Abstract We present an analysis of the Proof of Work consensus algorithm used on the Bitcoin block chain using Mean Field Game framework Using master equation we provide an equilibrium characterization of the total com put ional power devoted to mining the block chain hash rate From simple set ting we show how the master equation approach allows us to enrich the model by relaxing most of the simplifying assumptions The essential structure of the game is preserved across all the enrichment In deterministic settings the hash rate ultimately reaches steady state in which it increases at the rate of technological progress In stochastic settings there exists target for the hash rate for every possible random state As consequence we show that in equilibrium the security of the underlying block chain is either constant or ii increases with the demand for the underlying crypto currency MAP Ecole Polytechnique MR Palais eau France Institut Louis Bache lier Paris France Haas School of Business UC Berkeley Berkeley California Universit Paris Dauphine PS Research University MR CE REMADE Paris France Coll ge de France rue Ulm Paris France

VER IF ABLY SECURE AND PROPORTIONAL COMMITTEE ELECTION RULE PRE PRINT Alfonso Ce val los Alistair Stewart Web Technologies Foundation Web Technologies Foundation Zug Switzerland Zug Switzerland alfonso web foundation alistair web foundation July ABSTRACT The property of proportional representation in approval based committee elections has appeared in the social choice literature for over century and is typically understood as avoiding the under re pre sent ation of minorities However we argue that the security of some distributed systems is directly linked to the opposite goal of avoiding the over representation of any minority goal not prev ou sly formalized which leads us to an optimization objective known as maxim in support closely related to the axiom of proportional jus tied representation JR We provide new in ap proxima bil it result for this objective and propose new election rule inspired in Phra gm ns methods that achieves constant factor approximation guarantee for the objective and the JR property Furthermore structural property allows one to quickly verify that the winning committees at is es the two aforementioned properties even if the algorithm was executed by an un trusted party who only communicates the output Finally we present an efc ent post computation that when paired with any approximation algorithm for maxim in support returns new solution that preserves the approximation guarantee satis esP JR and can beef cie ntl ve ried to satisfy JR Our work is motivated by an application on block chains that implement nominated proof of stake PoS where the community must elect committee of validator to participate in its consensus protocol and where gh ting over representation protects the system against attacks by an ad ver arial minority Our election rule enables validator election protocol with formal and veria ble guarantees on security and proportionality We propose spec ic protocol that can be successfully implemented in spite of the stringent time constraints of block chain architecture and that will be the basis for an implementation in the Polka dot network launched in Keywords social choice approval based committee election approximation algorithms proof of stake block chain

IDENTITY MANAGEMENT ON BLOCK CHAIN PRIVACY AND SECURITY ASPECTS EXTENDED VERSION And ree Elena PANA IT Ru and ra OLI MID Al in STEFAN ESCU Department of Computer Science University of Bucharest Romania The Research Institute of the University of Bucharest CUB Romania Department of Information Security and Communication Technology NT NU Norwegian University of Science and Technology Trondheim Norway mail and ree elena pana it dr uni bu ro ru and ra oli mid al in fm uni bu ro Abstract In the last years identity management solutions on block chain were proposed as possible solution to the digital identity management problem However they are still at an early stage and further research needs to be done to conclude whether identity systems could benefit from the use of block chain or not Motivated by this we investigate identity management solutions on block chain intending to give the reader an overview of the current status and provide better understanding of the pros and cons of using such solutions We conduct an analysis on ten of the most known implementations with focus on privacy and security aspects Finally we identify existing challenges and give new directions for research Key words digital identity identity management block chain self sovereign identity

PARASITE CHAIN DETECTION IN THE IOTA PROTOCOL Andreas Pen of er Bar to sz Ku mie rz Angelo Ca posse le William Sanders Olivia IOTA Foundation Berlin Germany Department of Theoretical Physics Wroclaw University of Science and Technology Poland Department of Applied Mathematics Institute of Mathematics and Statistics University of So Paulo So Paulo Brazil April ABSTRACT In recent years several distributed ledger technologies based on directed cyclic graphs DAG have appeared on the market Similar to block chain technologies DAG based systems aim to build an immutable ledger and are faced with security concerns regarding the rr ever sibi lit of the ledger state However due to their more complex nature and recent popularity the study of adversarial actions has received little attention so far In this paper we are concerned with particular type of attack on the IOTA crypto currency more spec ical lya Parasite Chain attack that attempts to revert the history stored in the DAG structure also called the Tangle In order to improve the security of the Tangle we present detection mechanism for this type of attack In this mechanism we embrace the complexity of the DAG structure by sampling certain aspects of it more particularly the distribution of the number of app rovers We initially describe models that predict the distribution that should be expected for Tangle without any malicious actors We then introduce metrics that compare this reference distribution with the measured is tri but ion Upon detection measures can then betaken to render the attack unsuccessful We show that due to form of the Parasite Chain that is different from the main Tangle it is possible to detect cer tain types of malicious chains We also show that although the attacker may change the structure of the Parasite Chain to avoid detection this is done so at sign cant cost since the attack is rendered less efc ent

SE PAR Towards Regulating Future of Work Multi Platform Crowd working Environments with Privacy Guarantees Mohammad Java Amiri Joris Dug epe roux Tristan All ard Div ya kant Agra wal Amr El Abba di Department of Computer and Information Science University of Pennsylvania Un iv Rennes CNRS IRIS Department of Computer Science University of California Santa Barbara ct mj amiri seas penn edu joris dug epe roux tristan all ard iris fr agra wal amr cs ucsb edu Abstract Crowd working platforms provide the opportunity for diverse workers to execute tasks for die rent requester The popularity of the gig economy has given rise to independent plat forms that provide competing and complementary services Workers as well as requester with spec ic tasks may need to work for or avail from the services of multiple platforms resulting in the rise of multi platform crowd working systems Recently there has been in creasing interest by governmental legal and social institutions to enforce regulations such as minimal and maximal work hours on crowd working platforms Platforms within multi platform crowd working systems therefore need to collaborate to enforce cross platform regulations While collaborating to enforce global regulations requires the transparent shar ing of information about tasks and their participants the privacy of all participants needs to be preserved In this paper we propose an overall vision exploring the regulation privacy and architecture dimensions for the future of work multi platform crowd working en iron ment We then present SE PAR multi platform crowd working system that enforces large sub space of practical global regulations on set of distributed independent platforms in privacy preserving manner SE PAR enforces privacy using lightweight and anonymous tokens while transparency is achieved using fault tolerant block chains shared across multiple platforms The privacy guarantees of SE PAR against covert adversaries are formalized and thoroughly demonstrated while the experiments reveal the ec ien cy of SE PAR in terms of performance and cal ability

Formal Verification of Solidity contracts in Event Jian ZHU Kai HU amoun FILA LI Jean Paul BODE VE IX and Jean Pierre Tal pin State Key Laboratory of Software Development Environment Be ih ng University Beijing China IN RIA Campus de Beaulieu Rennes France IR IT CNRS Un iver site de Toulouse Toulouse France zhu jian hu kai bu edu cn amoun fila li jean paul bode ve ix ir it fr jean pierre tal pin in ria fr Abstract Smart contracts are the artifact of the block chain that provide immutable and verifiable specifications of physical transactions Solidity is domain specific programming language with the purpose of defining smart contracts It aims at reducing the transaction costs occasioned by the execution of contracts on the distributed ledgers such as the there um However Solidity contracts need to adhere safety and security requirements that require formal verification and certification This paper proposes method to meet such requirements by translating Solidity contracts to Event models supporting certification To that purpose we define restrained Solidity subset and transfer function which translates Solidity contracts to Event models Then we take advantage of Event method capabilities to refine models at different levels of abstraction to verify Solidity contracts properties And we can verify the generated proof obligations of the Event model with the help of the Rodin platform Keywords Block chain Smart contract Solidity Event model formal verification for security

Pre print Block chain Architecture for Industrial Applications Lo do vic Marches Michele Marches Roberto Tonelli MI University of Cagliari Abstract The Block chain and the programs running on it called Smart Contracts are more and more applied in alle lds requiring trust and strong cert cations In this work we compare public and permission ed block chains for industrial applications We propose complete original solution based onE there um to implement decentralized application This solution is characterized by set of validator nodes running the block chain using Proof of Authority consensus and including an Explorer enabling users to check block chain state and the source code of the Smart Contracts running on it From time to time the hash digest of the last mined block is written into public block chain to guarantee immutability The right to send transactions is granted by validator nodes to users by endowing them with the local Ether mined Overall the proposed approach has the same transparency and immutability of public block chain without its drawbacks

An Attestation Architecture for Block chain Networks Extended Abstract Thomas Hard ono and Ned Smith Massachusetts Institute of Technology Cambridge MA USA hard ono mit edu Intel Corporation Hillsboro OR USA ned smith intel com May Abstract If block chain networks are to become the building blocks of the infrastructure for the future digital economy then several challenges related to the resiliency and sur viv ability of block chain networks need to be addressed The sur viv ability of block chain network is in en ced by the diversity of its nodes Trustworthy device level attestations permits nodes in block chain network to provide truthful evidence regarding their cur rent cong ration operational state keying material and other system attributes In the current work were view the recent developments towards standard attestation arch it ec ture and evidence conveyance protocols We explore the applicability and be nets of standard attestation architecture to block chain networks Finally we discuss number of open challenges related to node attestations that has arisen due to changing model of block chain network deployments such as the use virtualization and container iz ation technologies for nodes in cloud infrastructures Keywords block chains trusted computing attestations virtual assets

Contra Mechanisms for Countering Spam Attacks on Block chains Memory Pools Muhammad aad Joong he on Kim Dae Hun yang David Moh is en Abstract Block chain based crypto currencies such as Bitcoin have seen on the rise in their popularity and value making them target to several forms of Denial of Service DoS attacks and calling for better understanding of their attack surface from both security and distributed systems standpoints In this paper and in the pursuit of understanding the attack surface of block chains we explore new form of attack that can be carried out on the memory pools mem pools and mainly targets block chain based crypto currencies We study this attack on Bitcoins mem pool and explore the attacks eec ts on transactions fee paid by benign users To counter this attack this paper further proposes Contra set of countermeasures utilizing fee age and size thus Contra Contra and Contra as prior it iz ation mechanisms Contra optimize the mem pool size and help in countering the eec ts of DoS attacks due to spam transactions We evaluate Contra by simulations and analyze their eec ti ve ness under various attack conditions Keywords Block chains DoS Attacks Memory Pool

Multi Party Timed Commitments Yael Dow eck It tay Eyal Tech ni on IC Tech ni on IC Abstract The problem of obtaining secret commitments from multiple parties and revealing them after certain time is useful for sealed bid auctions games and other applications Existing solutions dating back to Rivest Shamir and Wagner either do not scale or rely on synchro ny for the commitment phase and trust of parties We formalize the problem of implementing such commitments with probabilistic delay and without the aforementioned assumptions as Multi Party Timed Commitments MP TC and present solution the Time Capsule protocol Like previous approaches Time Capsule forms puzzle whose solution reveals the committed values But unlike previous solutions no party has an advantage in solving the puzzle and individual commitments cannot be revealed before the entire set is committed particular application of MP TC realizes an advancement in the study of decentralized systems The state of the art in decentralized systems is manifested in block chain systems that utilize Proof of Work to achieve censorship resistance However they are still vulnerable to front running an issue that is plaguing operational systems By adapting Time Capsule we allow it to be used for Proof of Work preventing front running by system operators and tuning the puzzle di cult using the block chain mechanism

Urbana Champaign Block chain systems often employ proof of work consensus protocols to validate and add transactions into hash chains These protocols stimulate competition among miners in solving crypto puzzles SHA hash computation in Bitcoin in exchange for monetary reward Here we model mining as an all pay auction where miners computational or ts are interpreted as bids and the allocation function is the probability of solving the crypto puzzle in single attempt with unit normalized computational capability Such an allocation function capture show block chain systems control the di cult of the crypto puzzle as function of miners computational abilities bids In an attempt to reduce mining costs we investigate designing mining auction mechanism which induces log it equilibrium amongst the miners with choice distributions that are unilaterally decreasing with costs at each miner We show it is impossible to design lenient allocation function that does this Spec ic ally we show that there exists no allocation function that discourages miners to bid higher costs at log it equilibrium if the rate of change of di cult with respect to each miners cost is bounded by the inverse of the sum of costs at all the miners MOTIVATION Permission less block chain systems including the Bitcoin crypto currency rely on proof of work consensus protocols that involve competitions among participants to solved cult computational problems crypto puzzles These participants called miners are bounded by the costs of resources needed for computation such as energy The consensus protocols however are subject to so called for king attacks attacks where miner or pool of miners having large fraction of the computation power in the system can asymptotically almost surely fork the block chain to prevent new transactions from being ve ried double spend coins or destroy the system via dramatic loss of conde ce As such an implicit assumption in ensuring the security of the distributed trust system is that there are large number of independent miners with incentives to follow the protocol In current practice though small number of participants perform the majority of mining often concentrated in locales such as in China where energy costs are low One can view mining as participating in an all pay auction where the bidding strategy captures heterogeneity amongst miners due to non identical computational abilities and diverse electricity costs at die rent geographic locations Recall that in an all pay auction the bid is for fei ted whether win or lose In Bitcoin mining involves computing the SHA hash function over and over as quickly as possible and so the bid can be thought of as the hash rate likewise in other block chain systems Equal hash rates bids incur varying costs to die rent miners depend in gon the basic cost of resources indie rent locales The Nash equilibrium strategies for all pay auctions under complete information are such that only the two strongest players lowest costs of bidding should actively participate and all others should bid zero this is exactly ac once ration of participants On the other hand there is over participation in many practical settings of all pay auctions where there are many more than two participants Several explanations for over bidding behavior have been suggested in the literature including bounded rationality and prospect theoretic explanations Even with rational agents over bidding behavior can emerge In the context of crowd sourcing contests previous work in designing auction systems has demonstrated that reducing information

Block chain Architecture for Auditing Automation and Trust Building in Public Markets Sean Cao Georgia State University Lin William Cong Cornell University Meng Han Kennesaw State University Qi xuan Hou Georgia Institute of Techno Rog Bao zhong Yang Georgia State University Abstract Business transactions by public rms are required to be reported ve ried and audited periodically which is traditionally labor intensive and time consuming process To streamline this procedure we design Future AB Future Auditing Block chain which aims to automate the reporting and auditing process there by allowing auditors to focus on discretionary accounts to better detect and prevent fraud We demonstrate how distributed ledger technologies build investor trust and disrupt the auditing industry Our multi functional design indicates that auditing rms can automate transaction ver cation without the need for trusted third party by collaborating and sharing their information while preserving data privacy commitment scheme and security immutability We also explore how smart contracts and wallets facilitate the computerization and implementation of our system onE there um Finally performance evaluation reveals the efc cy and cal ability of Future ABin terms of both encryption seconds per transaction and ver cation seconds per transaction

Access Control for Distributed Ledgers in the Internet of Things Networking Approach Andrew Cullen Pietro Ferraro William Sanders Luigi Vigne ri and Robert Shorten Abstract In the Internet of Things oT domain devices need platform to transact seamlessly without trusted intermediary Although Distributed Ledger Technologies LTs could provide such platform block chains such as Bitcoin were not designed with oT networks in mind hence are often unsuitable for such applications they offer poor transaction throughput and con rm ation times put stress on constrained computing and storage resources and require high transaction fees In this work we consider class of oT friendly LTs based on directed cyclic graphs rather than block chain and with reputation system in the place of Proof of Work PoW However without PoW im ple ment ation of these LTs requires an access control algorithm to manage the rate at which nodes can add new transactions to the ledger We model the access control problem and present an algorithm that is fair efc ent and secure Our algorithm represents new design paradigm for LTs in which concepts from networking are applied to the LT setting for the rst time For example our algorithm uses distributed rate setting which is similar in nature to transmission control used in the Internet Fig section of peer to peer oT network sharing distributed However our solution features novel adaptations to cope with the ledger Nodes store local copy of the ledger and share transactions with neighbouring nodes over bidirectional communication channels Transactions adversarial environment of LTs in which no individual agent can be trusted Our algorithm guarantees util is ation of resources baen re in cocl rudd ee de ox nc th hae ng leeds go fr currency oT device data or any data required to consistency fairness and resilience against attackers All of this is achieved efc ent ly and with regard for the limitations of oT devices We perform extensive simulations to validate these claims In the oT setting LTs should be designed to facilitate high transaction throughput with low latency and should be Index Terms Distributed Ledger Technology Efc ent Com suitable for large scale networks whilst retaining security and muni cations and Networking Network Architecture Security data integrity These features are of paramount importance and Privacy particularly in applications involving the exchange of sens ti ve data such as those from health monitoring devices

RE Triple Entry Accounting and Block chain Converging Paths to Shared Ledger Systems Current version May Juan Ignacio baez Chris Bayer Paolo as ca Jia hua Xu ABSTRACT The concept of shared ledger systems offering single source of truth has repeatedly called traditional bookkeeping into question Improving upon the long standing double entry systems solutions such as the Resource Event Agent RE accounting framework triple entry accounting TEA and block chain have been advanced However to date the historical development of these concepts remains murky This paper conducts genealogical analysis of shared ledger systems in particular tracing the development of RE TEA and block chain We show how the RE framework has had distinct influence on independent streams of research in the field of TEA and how this interaction may be traced to the present incarnation of shared ledger systems in block chain In doing so we duly acknowledge the influence of key individuals contributing to this development correct common misconceptions and map out how the paths of RE TEA and block chain overlap in the realm of shared ledger systems Keywords triple entry accounting RE accounting model single source of truth block chain distributed ledger technology Centre for Block chain Technologies University College of London Centre for Block chain Technologies University College of London Centre for Block chain Technologies University College of London Centre for Block chain Technologies University College of London This paper also benefited from comments by number of individuals per interview or per written correspondence We would like to gratefully acknowledge Chris Cook Chris dom Craig Wright David Hartley Ken Holman Ian Gr igg Marcos Miranda Melis Baud on Robert Haug en Todd Boyle and Vincent is caer Any mistakes are our own

Why Do Smart Contracts Self Destruct Investigating the Self destruct Function on there um JIA CHICHEN Monash University IN XIA Monash University DAVID LO the School of Information Systems Singapore Management University JOHN GRUNDY Monash University The self destruct function is provided byE there um smart contracts to destroy contract on the block chain system However it is double edged sword for developers On the one hand using self destruct function enables developers to remove smart contracts SC fromE there um and transfers Ether when emergency situations happen being attacked On the other hand this function can increase the complexity for the development and open an attack vector for attackers To better understand the reasons why SC developers include or exclude the self destruct function in their contracts we conducted an online survey to collect feedback from them and summarize the key reasons Their feedback shows that of the developers will deploy an updated contract to the there um after destructing the old contract According to this information we propose method to find the self destructed contracts also called predecessor contracts and their updated version successor contracts by computing the code similarity By analyzing the difference between the predecessor contracts and their successor contracts we found five reasons that led to the death of the contracts two of them Unmatched ER Token and Limits of Permission might affect the lifespan of contracts We developed tool named Life Scope to detect these problems Life Scope reports false positives or negatives in detecting Unmatched ER Token In terms of Limits of Permission Life Scope achieves ofF measure and of UC in average According to the feedback of developers who exclude self destruct functions we propose suggestions to help developers use self destruct function sinE there um smart contracts better Additional KeyWords and Phrases Smart Contract there um Self destruct Function Empirical Study TIME TRAVEL INVESTIGATION TOWARDS BUILDING SCALABLE ATTACK DETECTION FRAMEWORK ON THERE UM PRE PRINT Lei Wu Si wei Wu Yaji Zhou Run huai Li Zhi Wang Xi apu Luo Cong Wang and Kui Ren Zhejiang University Florida State University The HongKong Polytechnic University City University of HongKong October ABSTRACT As one of the representative block chain platforms there um has attracted lots of attacks Due to the existed nanci al loss there is pressing need to perform timely investigation and detect more attack instances Though multiple systems have been proposed they suffer from the cal ability issue due to the following reasons First the tight coupling between malicious contract detection and block chain data importing makes them infeasible to repeatedly detect different attacks Second the coarse grained archive data makes the mine fci ent to replay transactions Third the separation between malicious contract detection and runtime state recovery consumes lots of storage In this paper we present the design of scalable attack detection framework onE there um It over comes the cal ability issue by saving the there um state into database and providing an efc ent way to locate suspicious transactions The saved state is ne grained to support the replay of ar bit ra ry transactions The state is well designed to avoid saving unnecessary state to optimize the storage consumption We implement prototype named Eth Scope and solve three technical chal leng es incomplete there um state cal ability and extensibility The performance evaluation shows that our system can solve the cal ability issue efc ent ly performing large scale an aly is on billions of transactions and speedup of around when replaying transactions It also has lower storage consumption compared with existing systems The result with three different types of information as inputs shows that our system can help an analyst understand attack behaviors and Xi further detect more attacks To engage the community we will release our system and the data set of detected attacks

An Algebraic Model For Quorum Systems Alex Pellegrini Luca Zan olin University of Bern University of Bern alex pellegrini in uni be ch luca zan olin in uni be ch Abstract Quorum systems are key mathematical abstraction in distributed fault tolerant computing for capturing trust assumptions quorum system is collection of subsets of all processes called quo rums with the property that each pair of quorums have an on empty intersection They can be found at the core of many reliable distributed systems such as cloud computing platforms distributed stor age systems and block chains In this paper we give new interpretation of quorum systems starting with classical majority based quorum systems and extending this to Byzantine quorum systems We propose an algebraic representation of the theory underlying quorum systems making use of mul ti variate polynomial ideals incorporating properties of these systems and studying their algebraic varieties To achieve this goal we will exploit properties of Boolean Gro bner bases The nice na ture of Boolean Gro bner bases allows us to avoid part of the combinatorial computations required to check consistency and availability of quorum systems Our results provide novel approach to test quorum systems properties from both algebraic and algorithmic perspectives

From Symmetric to Asymmetric Asynchronous Byzantine Consensus Christian Cach in Luca Zan olin University of Bern University of Bern cach in in uni be ch luca zan olin in uni be ch June Abstract Consensus is arguably one of the most important notions in distributed computing Among syn chrono us randomized and signature free implementations the protocols of Most ef aou iet al POD and ACM represent landmark result which has been extended later and taken up in practical systems The protocols achieve optimal resilience and takes in expectation only constant expected number of rounds of quadratic message complexity Random iz ation is provided through common coin primitive In traditional consensus protocols all involved processes adhere to global symmetric failure model typically only de ned by bounds on the number of faulty processes Motivated by applications to block chains however more ex ble trust assumptions have recently been considered In particular with asymmetric trust process is free to choose which other processes it trusts and which ones might collude against it This paper revisits the optimal asynchronous protocol of Most ef oui et al and shows how to realize it with asymmetric trust The paper starts by pointing out in detail why some versions of this protocol may violate live ness Then it proposes for the protocol that does not affect its properties but lets it regain the simplicity of its original version POD At the same time the paper shows how to realize randomized signature free asynchronous Byzantine consensus with asymmetric quorums This results in an optimal consensus protocol with subjective asymmetric trust and constant expected running time It is suitable for applications to block chains for instance Keywords Consensus Asymmetric trust Quorums Randomized consensus Common coin

Verify Med block chain platform for transparent trust in virtual zed healthcare Proof of concept Jens Andreas Hanssen Rens Danilo Gli goro ski Katina Kr lev ska Anton Has sel gren Ari ld Fax va ag April Abstract Patients living in digitized world can now interact with medical professionals through online services such as chat applications video conferencing or indirectly through consulting services These applications need to tackle several fundamental trust issues Checking and con ming that the person they are interacting with is real person Validating that the healthcare professional has competence within the el in question and Con ming that the healthcare professional has valid license to practice In this paper we present Verify Med the rst proof of concept platform built on there um for transparently validating the authorization and competence of medical professionals using block chain technology Our platform models trust relationships within the healthcare industry to validate professional clinical authorization Furthermore it enables healthcare professional to build portfolio of real lifework experience and further validates the competence by storing outcome metrics reported by the patients The extensive realistic simulations show that with our platform an average cost for creating smart contract for treatment and getting it approved is around USD and the cost for evaluating treatment is around cents Department of Information Security and Communication Technologies Norwegian University of Science and Technology NT NU Department of Neuro medicine and Movement Science Norwegian University of Science and Technology NT NU

Gri eng Penalty Counter measure for Gri eng Attack in Lightning Network Sub hra Ma zum dara Pra bal Banerjee Sus hm it Ru Cryptology and Security Research Unit Indian Statistical Institute Kolkata India CSIRO Data Australia Polygon previously Mati Network Abstract Lightning Network can execute unlimited number of chain payments without incurring the cost of recording each of them in the block chain However conditional payments in such networks is susceptible to Gri eng Attack In this attack an adversary doesnt resolve the payment with the intention of blocking channel capacity of the network We propose an ec ent counter measure for the attack known as Gri eng Penalty If any party in the network mounts gri eng attack it needs to pay penalty proportional to the collateral cost of executing payment The penalty is used for compensating aec ted parties in the network We propose new payment protocol TLC GP or Hashed Time lock Contract with Gri eng Penalty to demonstrate the utility of the counter measure Upon comparing our protocol with existing payment protocol Hashed Time lock Contract we observe that the average revenue earned by the attacker decreases substantially for TLC GP as compared to TLC We also study the impact of path length for routing transaction and rate of gri eng penalty on the budget invested by an adversary for mounting the attack The budget needed for mounting gri eng attack in TLC GP is times more than the budget needed by attacker in TLC given that each payment instance being routed via path length of hop count Keywords Lightning Network Gri eng Attack Gri eng Penalty Reverse Gri eng Hashed Time lock Contract with Gri eng Penalty

Formal Spec cation and Ver cation of Solidity Contracts with Events kos Haj du Dejan Jovan vic and Gabriela Cio car lie Budapest University of Technology and Economics Budapest Hungary haj du mit me hu SRI International New York City USA dejan jovan vic gabriela cio car lie sri com Abstract Events in the Solidity language provide means of communication between the on chain services of decentralized applications and the users of those services Events are commonly used as an abstraction of contract execution that is relevant from the users perspective Users must therefore be able to understand the meaning and trust the validity of the emitted events This paper presents source level approach for the formal spec cation and ver cation of Solidity contracts with the primary focus on events Our approach allows spec cation of events in terms of the on chain data that they track and predicates that de ne the correspondence between the block chain state and the abstract view provided by the events The approach is implemented in sol verify modular verier for Solidity and we demonstrate its applicability with various examples

User behavior and token adoption on ER Alfredo Morales Shahar Som in Yaniv Alt shu ler and Alex Sandy Pent land MIT Media Lab alfredo mit edu Abstract Crypto currencies and Block chain based technologies are disrupting all mar ket While the potential of such technologies remains to be seen there is current need to understand emergent patterns of user behavior and token adoption in or der to design future products In this paper we analyze the social dynamics taking place during one arbitrary day on the ER platform We characterize the net work of token transactions among agents We show heterogeneous roles of user behavior portfolio diversity and token adoption While most users are specialized in transacting with few tokens those that have diverse portfolios are bridging across large parts of the network and may jeopardize the system stability We believe this work to be foundation for unveiling the usage dynamics of crypto currencies networks

Survey on Block chain Interoperability Past Present and Future Trends RAFAEL BELCH OR IN ESC ID Instituto Superior Tc nico Universidade de Lisboa Portugal AND RV SCONCE LOS IN ESC ID Instituto Superior Tc nico Universidade de Lisboa Portugal RGIO GUERRE RO IN ESC ID Instituto Superior Tc nico Universidade de Lisboa Portugal MIGUEL CORREIA IN ESC ID Instituto Superior Tc nico Universidade de Lisboa Portugal Block chain interoperability is emerging as one of the crucial features of block chain technology but the knowledge necessary for achieving it is fragmented This fact makes it challenging for academics and the industry to achieve interoperability among block chains seamlessly Given this new domains novelty and potential we conduct literature review on block chain interoperability by collecting papers and grey literature documents constituting corpus of documents From those documents we systematically analyzed and discussed documents including peer reviewed papers and grey literature Our review classifies studies in three categories Public Connectors Block chain of Block chains and Hybrid Connectors Each category is further divided into sub categories based on defined criteria We classify existing solutions in one subcategory using the Block chain Interoperability Framework providing holistic overview of block chain interoperability Our findings show that block chain interoperability has much broader spectrum than crypto currencies and cross chain asset transfers Finally this paper discusses supporting technologies standards use cases open challenges and future research directions paving the way for research in the area CCS Concepts Computer systems organization Dependable and fault tolerant systems and networks Peer to peer architectures Additional KeyWords and Phrases survey block chain interoperability standards interconnected block chains cross chain transactions cross block chain communication ACM Reference Format Lightweight Block chain Framework for Location aware Peer to Peer Energy Trading Mohsen Khorasan ya Ali Dor rib Reza Razz ag hi Raja Jur akb Department of Electrical and Computer Systems Engineering Monash University Clayton VIC Australia School of Computer Science Queensland University of Technology Brisbane City QLD Australia Abstract Peer to Peer energy trading can facilitate integration of large number of small scale producers and consumers into energy markets Decentralized management of these new market participants is challenging in terms of market settlement participant reputation and consideration of grid constraints This paper proposes block chain enabled framework for energy trading among producer and consumer agents in smart grid fully decentralized market settlement mechanism is designed which does not rely on centralized entity to settle the market and encourages producers and consumers to negotiate on energy trading with their nearby agents truthfully To this end the electrical distance of agents is considered in the pricing mechanism to encourage agents to trade with their neighboring agents In addition reputation factor is considered for each agent re ect in gits past performance in delivering the committed energy Before starting the negotiation agents select their trading partners based on their preferences over the reputation and proximity of the trading partners An Anonymous Proof of Location PoL algorithm is proposed that allows agents to prove their location without revealing their real identity The practicality of the proposed framework is illustrated through several case studies and its security and privacy are analyzed in detail Keywords Distributed energy resource DER Block chain Peer to Peer trading trans active energy TE smart grid Internet of Things oT

Wallet Attestations for Virtual Asset Service Providers and Crypto Assets Insurance Extended Abstract Thomas Hard ono Alexander Lipton Alex Pent land MIT Connection Science Engineering Massachusetts Institute of Technology Cambridge MA USA hard ono mit edu alex lip mit edu pent land mit edu June Abstract The emerging virtual asset service providers VAS industry currently faces number of challenges related to the Travel Rule notably pertaining to customer personal in form tion account number and cryptographic key information ASPs will be handling virtual assets of die rent forms where each maybe bound to die rent private public key pairs on the block chain As such ASPs also face the additional problem of the management of its own keys and the management of customer keys that may reside in customer wallet The use of attestation technologies as applied to wallet systems may provide ASPs with suitable evidence relevant to the Travel Rule regarding cryptographic key information and their operational state Additionally wallet attestations may provide crypto asset insurers with strong evidence regarding the key management aspects of wallet device there by providing the insurance industry with measurable levels of assurance that can become the basis for insurers to perform risk assessment on crypto assets bound to keys in wallets both enterprise grade wallets and consumer grade wallets

shared ledger by performing dig it al speech acts which are cryptographically signed sequentially indexed digital actions Here we address the distributed ledger implementation of digital social contracts in the presence of faulty agents we present design of fault tolerant distributed ledger transition system and show that it implements the abstract shared ledger model of digital social con Securing oT Applications using Block chain Survey ree lakshmi shu tosh Bhat An kit Agra wal Dept of Computer Science Bir la Institute of Technology and Science Pila ni Rajasthan India shu tosh bhat pila ni bits pila ni ac in Abstract The Internet of Things oT has become guiding technology behind automation and smart computing One of the major concerns with the oT systems is the lack of privacy and security preserving schemes for controlling access and ensuring the security of the data majority of security issues arise because of the centralized architecture of oT systems Another concern is the lack of proper authentication and access control schemes to moderate access to information generated by the oT devices So the question that arises is how to ensure the identity of the equipment or the communicating node The answer to secure operations in trust less environment brings us to the decentralized solution of Block chain lot of research has been going on in the area of convergence of oT and Block chain and it has resulted in some remarkable progress in addressing some of the significant issues in the oT arena This work reviews the challenges and threats in the oT environment and how integration with Block chain can resolve some of them Keywords oT Block chain Security

ISSN Volume Issue March Block chain Fog and oT Integrated Framework Review Architecture and Evaluation Tan weer Alam Mohamed Ben aida Faculty of Computer and Information Systems Islamic University of Madina Saudi Arabia Please cite this article as follows Tan weer Alam Mohamed Ben aida Block chain Fog and oT Integrated Framework Review Architecture and Evaluation Technology Reports of Kansai University Vol Abstract In the next generation computing the role of cloud internet and smart devices will be capacious Nowadays we all are familiar with the word smart This word is used number of times in our daily life The Internet of Things oT will produce remarkable different kinds of information from different resources It can store and process big data in the cloud The fogging acts as an interface between cloud and oT The oT nodes are also known as fog nodes these nodes are able to access anywhere within the range of the network The block chain is novel approach to record the transactions in sequence securely Developing new block chains based integrated framework in the architecture of the oT is one of the emerging approaches to solving the issue of communication security among the oT public nodes This research explores novel approach to integrate block chain technology with the fog and oT networks and provides communication security to the internet of smart devices The framework is tested and implemented in the oT network The results are found positive Keywords Internet of Things block chain technology fog computing cloud computing communication security

Sharif University of Technology Tehran Iran habib sharif edu Computer Engineering Department Sharif University of Technology Tehran Iran shams ie ce sharif edu Abstract With recent considerable developments in the Internet of Things oT billions of resource constrained devices are interconnected through the Internet Monitoring this huge number of oT devices which are heterogeneous in terms of underlying communication protocols and data format is challenging The majority of existing oT device monitoring solutions heavily rely on centralized architectures Since using centralized architectures comes at the expense of trusting an authority it has several inherent drawbacks including vulnerability to security attacks lack of data privacy and unauthorized data manipulation Hence new decentralized approach is crucial to remedy these drawbacks One of the most promising technologies which is widely used to provide decentralization is block chain Additionally to ease the burden of communication overhead and computational power on resource constrained oT devices fog computing can be exploited to decrease communication latency and provide better network cal ability In this paper we propose scalable block chain based architecture for monitoring oT devices using fog computing To demonstrate the feasibility and usability of the proposed solution we have implemented proof of concept prototype leveraging there um smart contracts Finally comprehensive evaluation is conducted The evaluation results indicate that the proposed solution is sign cant ly scalable and compatible with resource constrained oT devices Index Terms Internet of things device monitoring fog block chain smart contract there um pfs

citizens Today instead while the society is sur ng the digital tsunami urbs and civitas tend to become much closer almost merging that we might attempt to condensate these into single concept smart grid Internet of things art ici al intelligence block chain quantum cryptography is only few of the paradigms that are likely to contribute to determining the nal portrait of the future smart grid However to understand the effective sustainability of complex grids spec ic tools are required To this end in this article systematic review of the emerging paradigms is presented identifying intersect oral syne gies and limitations with respect to the smart grid concept Further taxonomic framework for assessing the level of sustainability of the grid is proposed Finally from the scenario portrayed set of issues involving engineering regulation security and social frameworks have been derived in theoretical fashion Th endings are likely to suggest the urgent need for multidisciplinary cooperation to wisely address engineering and ontological challenges gravitating around the smart grid concept Highlights systematic holistic review of the smart grid emerging paradigms is presented cyber security issues need to be regulated in are sol uti ve fashion in the short term while space programs might be needed in the long term to ensure space security and research on Sun cycles

Democrat ising block chain minimal agency consensus model Marcin Abram David Gal indo Daniel Hone rk amp Jonathan Ward in Mann Wong Fetch St Johns Innovation Centre Cowley Road Cambridge CB WS UK Abstract We propose novel consensus protocol based on hybrid approach that combines directed cyclic graph DAG and classical chain of blocks This architecture allows us to enforce collective block construction minim is ing the monopolistic power of the round leader In this way we decrease the possibility for collusion among senders and miners as well as miners themselves allowing the use of more incentive compatible and fair pricing strategies We investigate these possibilities alongside the ability to use the DAG structure to minimise the risk of transaction censoring We conclude by providing preliminary benchmarks of our protocol and by exploring further research directions Key words Block chain Consensus Incentive Theory Mechanism Design

Block chain in the management of science conceptual models promises and challenges Block chain has received much attention recently due to its promises of verifiable permanent decentralized and efficient data handling In block chain and associated technologies such as smart contracts has progressed beyond crypto currencies and has been adopted in banking retail healthcare and other fields This study critically examines recent applications of block chain in science touching upon different stages of research cycle from data management to publishing peer review research evaluation and funding The paper is based upon review of block chain projects relevant literature set of interviews and focus groups with startup founders scholars librarians IT experts from the EU USA Russia and Belarus Proponents of block chain for science present this technology as tool to make science free from bias red tape data fraud as well as provide innovative means to secure financial backing for new ideas However these projects face set of challenges One issue concerns introducing crypto economy with its financial incentives into science field that emphasizes disinterested and non pecuniary pursuit of truth Another source of concern relates to the ongoing conflict between the principle of decentralization inherent to block chain and the practice of forcing it from above by the state and other centralized entities cid Keywords block chain management of science research data decentralization incentive design Highlights Block chain technologies have provided solution to challenges on all stages of the research cycle from data sharing to publishing and funding cid This study examines use cases of block chain in science drawing upon systematic review of extant projects and set of sociological interviews with stakeholders There is tension between principles of decentralization and disinter mediation inherent to block chain and the practice of implementing LT solutions in centralized way by states and universities cid
