Leveraging Bitcoin Test net for Bidirectional Botnet Command and Control Systems Federico Franz on Ivan Abell an and Vanes Daz Universitat Pomp eu abra Barcelona Spain federico franz on vanes daz up edu abell an pm me Abstract Over the past twenty years the number of devices connected to the Internet grew exponentially Botnets bene ted from this rise to increase their size and the magnitude of their attacks However they still have weak point in their Command Control system which is often based on centralized services or require complex infrastructure to keep operating without being taken down by authorities The recent spread of block chain technologies may give botnets powerful tool to make them very hard to disrupt Recent research showed how it is possible to embed messages in Bitcoin transactions making them nearly impossible to block Nevertheless transactions have cost and allow very limited amounts of data to be transmitted Because of that only messages from the bot master to the bots are sent via Bitcoin while bots are assumed to communicate through external channels Furthermore for the same reason Bitcoin based messages are sent in clear In this paper we show how using Bitcoin Test net it is possible to overcome these limitations and implement cost free bidirectional and encrypted channel between the bot master and the bots We propose communication protocol and analyze its viability in real life Our results show that this approach would enable bot master to build robust and hard to disrupt system at virtually no cost thus representing realistic threat for which countermeasures should be devised

SIMULATION BASED DIGITAL TWIN DEVELOPMENT FOR BLOCK CHAIN ENABLED END TO END INDUSTRIAL HEMP SUPPLY CHAIN RISK MANAGEMENT Ke qi Wang Wei Xie We nc en Wu Bo Wang in xiang Pei Mike Baker and Qi Zhou Northeastern University Boston MA San Jose State University San Jose CA Willamette Valley Assured LLC Lebanon OR Quark Chain Inc San Mateo CA ABSTRACT With the passage of the Farm Bill Industrial Hemp production is moved from limited pi lot programs to regulated agriculture production system However Industrial Hemp Supply Chain IHS faces critical challenges including high complexity and variability very limited production knowledge lack of data and information tracking In this paper we propose block chain enabled IHS and develop preliminary simulation based digital twin for this distributed cyber physical system CP to support the process learning and risk management Basically we develop two layer block chain with proof of authority smart contract which can track the data and key in for mati on improve the supply chain transparency and leverage local authorities and state regulators to ensure the quality control ver cation Then we introduce stochastic simulation based digital twin for IHS risk management which can characterize the process spatial temporal causal inter de pen den cie and dynamic evolution to guide risk control and decision making Our empirical study demonstrates the promising performance of proposed platform Keywords Industrial Hemp Block chain Enabled oT Supply Chain Risk Management Digital Twin Cyber Physical System Stochastic Simulation

On the Security of Proofs of Sequential Work in Post Quantum World Jeremiah Block Seung hoon Lee Samson Zhou Purdue University Purdue University Carnegie Mellon University block purdue edu lee purdue edu samson zhou gmail com May Abstract Proof of Sequential Work PoS allows pr over to convince resource bounded verier that the pr over invested substantial amount of sequential time to perform some underlying computation PoS Ws have many applications including time stamping block chain design and universally veria ble CPU benchmarks Mahmood Moran and adhan IT CS gave the rst construction of PoS in the random oracle model though the construction relied on expensive depth robust graphs In recent breakthrough Cohen and Pie tr zak EURO CRYPT gave nec ent PoS construction that does not require expensive depth robust graphs In the classical parallel random oracle model it is straightforward to argue that any success ful PoS attacker must produce long sequence and that any malicious party running in sequential time will fail to produce an sequence of length except with negligible pro ability In this paper we prove that any quantum attacker running in sequential time will fail to produce an sequence except with negligible probability even if the attacker submits large batch of quantum queries in each round The proof is substantially more challenging and highlights the power of Zh an drys recent compressed oracle technique CRYPTO We further extend this result to establish post quantum security of non interactive PoS obtained by applying the Fiat Shamir transform to Cohen and Pie tr zak ec ent construction EURO CRYPT

Using Fault Injection to Assess Block chain Systems in Presence of Faulty Smart Contracts kos Haj du Nag meh Iv aki mre Ko csis Attila Kle nik szl Gn czy Nuno Lara nje ro Henrique Madeira And rs Pata ric za IS UC Department of Informatics Engineering University of Coimbra Portugal nag meh nl henrique dei uc pt Department of Measurement and Information Systems Budapest University of Technology and Economics Hungary haj du ik ocs is kle nik gon czy pata ric mit me hu Authors manuscript Published in IEEE Access The nal publication is available at IEEE via http dx doi org ACCESS cid Abstract Block chain has become particularly popular due to its promise to support business critical services in very different domains retail supply chains healthcare Block chain systems rely on complex middle ware like there um or Hyper ledger Fabric that allow running smart contracts which specify business logic in cooperative applications The presence of software defects or faults in these contracts has notably been the cause of failures including severe security problems In this paper we use software implemented fault injection SWI FI technique to assess the behavior of permission ed block chain systems in the presence of faulty smart contracts We emulate the occurrence of general software faults missing variable initialization and also block chain spec ic software faults missing require statement on transactions ender in smart contracts code to observe the impact on the overall system dependability reliability and integrity We also study the effectiveness of formal ver cation done by sol verify and runtime protections using the assert statement mechanisms in detection of injected faults Results indicate that formal ver cation as well as additional runtime protections have to complement built in platform checks to guarantee the proper dependability of block chain systems and applications The work presented in this paper allows smart contract developers to become aware of possible faults in smart contracts and to understand the impact of their presence It also provides valuable information for middle ware developers to improve the behavior overall fault tolerance of their systems Index Terms Block chain Systems Smart Contracts Fault Injection Dependability Formal Ver cation

The Hermes FT for Block chains Mohammad Jalal zai Chen Feng Costas Busch Golden Richard III Jian yu Niu Abstract The performance of partially synchronous FT based consensus protocols is highly dependent on the primary node All participant nodes in the network are blocked until they receive proposal from the primary node to begin the consensus process Therefore an honest but slack node with limited bandwidth can adversely affect the performance when selected as primary Hermes decreases protocol dependency on the primary node and minimizes transmission delay induced by the slack primary while keeping low message complexity and latency Hermes achieves these performance improvements by relaxing strong FT agreement safety guarantees only for specific type of Byzantine faults also called equivocated faults Interestingly we show that in Hermes equivocating by Byzantine primary is unlikely expensive and ineffective Therefore the safety of Hermes is comparable to the general FT consensus We deployed and tested Hermes on Amazon EC instances In these tests Hermes performance was comparable to the state of the art FT protocol for block chains when the network size is large in the absence of slack nodes Whereas in the presence of slack nodes Hermes outperformed the state of the art FT protocol by more than in terms of throughput as well as in terms of latency Index Terms Block chains Byzantine Fault Tolerance Consensus Performance cal ability Security Throughput cid

approach the EOS block chain transparently stores BAC policies Administrative roles con tro access to resources at higher level according to the way organ iz ions perform business An organization Block FLow An Accountable and Privacy Preserving Solution for Federated Learning aik kun th Mu gun than Ravi Rahman SAIL SAIL Massachusetts Institute of Technology Massachusetts Institute of Technology Cambridge MA Cambridge MA aik mit edu rahman mit edu Lala naKa gal SAIL Massachusetts Institute of Technology Cambridge MA lk gal mit edu Abstract Federated learning enables the development of machine learning model among collaborating agents without requiring them to share their underlying data How ever malicious agents who train on random data or worse on datasets with the result classes inverted can weaken the combined model Block FLow is an account able federated learning system that is fully decentralized and privacy preserving Its primary goal is to reward agents proportional to the quality of their contrib tion while protecting the privacy of the underlying datasets and being resilient to malicious adversaries Spec ic ally Block FLow incorporates differential pri vac introduces novel auditing mechanism for model contribution and uses there um smart contracts to in centi viz good behavior Unlike existing auditing and accountability methods for federated learning systems our system does not require centralized test data set sharing of datasets between the agents or one or more trusted auditors it is fully decentralized and resilient up to collusion attack in malicious trust model When run on the public there um block chain Block FLow uses the results from the audit to reward parties with crypto currency based on the quality of their contribution We evaluated Block FLow on two datasets that offer classic ation tasks solvable via logistic regression models Our results show that the resultant auditing scores re ect the quality of the honest agents datasets Moreover the scores from dishonest agents are statistically lower than those from the honest agents These results along with the reasonable block chain costs demonstrate the effectiveness of Block FLow as an accountable federated learning system

Green PoW An Energy Efc ent Block chain Proof of Work Consensus Algorithm Nou red dine Las la Member IEEE Lina Salim Als ahan Mohamed Abdallah Senior Member IEEE and Mohamed Younis Senior Member IEEE Abstract This paper opts to mitigate the energy in efc ien cy of the Block chain Proof of Work PoW consensus algorithm by rationally re purposing the power spent during the mining process The original PoW mining scheme is designed to consider one block at time and assign reward to the rst place winner of computation race To reduce the mining related energy consumption we propose to compensate the computation effort of the runner up of mining round by granting them exclusivity of solving the upcoming block in the next round This will considerably reduce the number of competing nodes in the next round and consequently the consumed energy Our proposed scheme divides time into epochs where each comprises two mining rounds in the stone all network nodes can participate in the mining process whereas in the second round only runners up can take part Thus the overall mining energy consumption can be reduced to nearly To the best of our knowledge our proposed scheme is the rst to considerably improve the energy consumption of the original PoW algorithm Our analysis demonstrates the effectiveness of our scheme in reducing energy consumption the probability of fork occurrences the level of mining centralization presented in the original PoW algorithm and the effect of transaction censorship attack Index Terms Block chain Consensus algorithm Proof of Work Energy efc ien cy

CONSENT MODEL FOR BLOCK CHAIN BASED DISTRIBUTED DATA SHARING PLATFORMS PRE PRINT Vi as Jai man Vi sara Uro vi Institute of Data Science IDS Institute of Data Science IDS Maastricht University Maastricht University LK Maastricht The Netherlands LK Maastricht The Netherlands jai man maastricht university nl uro vi maastricht university nl July ABSTRACT In modern healthcare systems being able to share electronic health records is crucial for providing quality care and for enabling larger spectrum of health services Health data sharing is dependent on obtaining individual consent which in turn is hindered by lack of resources To this extend block chain based platforms facilitate data sharing by inherently creating trusted distributed network of users These users are enabled to share their data without depending on the time and resources of spec ic players such as the health services In block chain based platforms data governance mechanisms become very important due to the need to specify and monitor data sharing and data use conditions In this paper we present block chain based data sharing consent model for access control over individual health data We use smart contracts to dynamically represent the individual consent over health data and to enable data requester to search and access them The dynamic consent model extends upon two on to logie the Data Use Ontology DUO which models the individual consent of users and the Automata ble Discovery and Access Matrix ADA which describes queries from data requester We deploy the model onE there um block chain and evaluate different data sharing scenarios The contribution of this paper is to create an individual consent model for health data sharing platforms Such model guarantees that individual consent is respected and that there is accountability for all the participants in the data sharing platform The evaluation of our solution indicates that such data sharing model provides ex ble approach to decide how the data is used by data requester Our experimental evaluation shows that the proposed model is efc ent and adapts to personalized access control policies in data sharing Keywords Block chain Data sharing Distributed ledger sEHR exchange Individual consent

Percolation framework reveals limits of privacy in Conspiracy Dark Web and Block chain networks Louis Shek htm an Al on Sela and Shl omo Havl in Network Science Institute Northeastern University Boston USA Department of Industrial Engineering Ariel University Ariel Israel Department of Physics Bar Ilan University Ramat Gan Israel Dated July Abstract We consider the privacy of interactions between individuals in network For many networks while nodes are anonymous to outside observers the existence of link between individuals implies the possibility of one node revealing identifying information about its neighbor Moreover while the identities of the accounts are likely hidden to an observer the network of interaction between two anonymous accounts is often available For example in block chain crypto currencies transactions between two anonymous accounts are published openly Here we consider what happens if one or more parties in such network are dean ony miz ed by an outside identity These compromised individuals could leak information about others with whom they interacted which could then cascade to more and more nodes information being revealed We use percolation framework to analyze the scenario outlined above and show for die rent likelihoods of individuals possessing information on their counter parties the fraction of accounts that can bei den tied and the idealized minimum number of steps from dean ony miz ed node to an anonymous node measure of the ort required to dean ony miz that individual We further develop greedy algorithm to estimate the actual number of steps that will be needed to identify particular node based on the noisy information available to the attacker We apply our framework to three real world networks block chain transaction network network of interactions on the dark web and political conspiracy network We nd that in all three networks beginning from one compromised individual it is possible to dean ony miz sign cant fraction of the network within less than steps Overall these results provide guidelines for investigators seeking to identify actors in anonymous networks as well as for users seeking to maintain their privacy

Block chain Based Process Control and Monitoring Architecture for Vertical Integration of Industry Charles Garr ochoa Ce lio Ferreira Carlos Cava can tib Ricardo Oliveira Minas Gerais Federal Institute of Education Science and Technology Computer Science Department Federal University of Our Preto Abstract Industrial Internet of Things is new milestone that will require new industry paradigms and investments In this context cyber physical systems are consid ered the bridge to the fourth revolution Centralized approaches and observance of real time constraints are two important challenges that must be overcome for the advancement of Industry To solve these problems block chain based vertical integration architecture of the process automation systems is proposed in which it performs the control and monitoring of industrial processes Proof of concept experiments reveal the feasibility and performance of the proposal Keywords Block chain Smart Contracts Industry Integration

Radium Improving Dynamic PoW Targeting George is si as ICS UMass Amherst gb is cs umass edu July Abstract Most PoW block chain protocols operate with simple mechanism whereby threshold is set for each block and miners generate block hashes until one of those values falls below the threshold Although largely ef fec ti ve this mechanism produces blocks at highly variable rate and also leaves block chain susceptible to chain death abandonment in the event that the threshold is set too high to attract any miners recent innovation called real time block rate targeting orR TT xe the sep rob lem by reducing the target throughout the mining interval RT exhibits much less variable block times and even features the ability to fully adjust the target after each block However as we show in this paper RT also sue rs from critical vulnerability whereby miners deviate form the pro to col to increase their prot We introduce the Radium protocol which mitigates this vulnerability in RT while retaining lower variance block times responsive target adjustment and lowering the risk of chain death We also show that Radium susceptibility to the double spend attack and orphaned blocks remains similar to Bitcoin

The is DAO On the Privacy Cost of Participation Liam Hickey and Martin Harri gan Department of Computing Institute of Technology Carlow Republic of Ireland Abstract The is DAO is core component of is decentralized cry to currency exchange The purpose of the is DAO is to decentralize the governance and nance functions of the exchange However by in ter acting with the is DAO participants necessarily publish data to the Bitcoin block chain and broadcast additional data to the is peer to peer network We examine the privacy cost to participants in sharing this data Spec ic ally we use novel address clustering heuristic to construct the one to many mappings from participants to addresses on the Bitcoin block chain and augment the address clusters with data stored within the is peer to peer network We show that this technique aggregates ac iv it performed by each participant trading voting transfers etc We identify instances where participants are operating under multiple aliases some of which are real world names We identify the dominant trans ac tors and their role in two sided market We conclude with suggestions to better protect the privacy of participants in the future

Multi Utility Market Framework for Block chain Exchange Platform for Sustainable Development Jacques Bou Ab do her ali Zea dally Notre Dame University Lebanon bou ab do du edu lb University of Kentucky USA sze dally uk edu Water and other resources are becoming scarcer every day and developing countries are the neediest for an immediate intervention Water as national need is considered to be one of the main causes for conflicts in the st century Peer to peer trading is one of the most convenient scalable and sustainable solutions but faces organization challenges such as the absence of suitable business models motivating normal users to sell their generated resources currency and financial settlement complexities and single utility markets We propose multi utility trading platform based on block chain technology which can address the challenges faced by peer to peer trading This platform meets the needs of developing countries in particular as well as rural areas of developed countries The open nature of our proposed design makes it suitable for adoption and use by various stakeholders Keywords Block chain credit debit system distributed water systems hybrid water systems urban water market peer to peer water trading

unt edu Email elias kou gian os unt edu Abstract Considering todays lifestyle people just sleep forgetting the be nets it provides to the human body The reasons for not having productive sleep could be many Smart Yoga Pillow SaY Pillow is envisioned as device that may help in recognizing the importance of good quality sleep to alleviate stress while establishing measurable relationship between stress and sleeping habits system that analyzes the sleeping habits by continuously monitoring the physiological changes that occur during rapid eye movement REM and non rapid eye movement NREM stages of sleep is proposed in the current work In addition to the physiological parameter changes factors such as sleep duration snoring range eye movement and limb movements are also monitored The SaY Pillow system is processed at the edge level with the storage being at the cloud Not having to compromise the users privacy SaY Pillow proposes secure data transmission for both uploading and retrieving and secure storage and communications as an attempt to reduce malicious attacks on healthcare user interface is provided for the user to control data accessibility and visibility SaY Pillow has accuracy which is close to other existing research works However SaY Pillow is the only work with security features as well as only work that considers sleeping habits for stress Index terms Internet of Things oT Internet of Medical Things IoM Smart Healthcare Smart Home Block chain Machine Learning Privacy Assurance Stress Sleep Stress Detection Sleeping Habit

Wendy the Good Little Fairness Widget Klaus ursa we klaus vega xyz Version July Abstract The advent of decentralized trading markets introduces number of new challenges for consensus protocols In addition to the usual attacks subset of the validator trying to prevent disagreement there is now the possibility of nanci al fraud which can abuse properties not normally considered critical in consensus protocols We investigate the issues of attackers manipulating or exploiting the order in which transactions are scheduled in the block chain More concretely we look into relative order fairness ways we can assure that the relative order of transactions is fair We show that one of the more intuitive den it ions of fairness is impossible to achieve We then present Wendy group of low overhead protocols that can implement die rent concepts of fairness Wendy acts as an adit ional widget for an existing block chain and is largely agnostic to the underlying block chain and its security assumptions Furthermore it is possible to apply the protocol only for subset of the transactions and thus run several independent fair markets on the same chain

Block chain based Iterative Double Auction Protocol using Multiparty State Channels TRU CD NGUYEN University of Florida MY THAI University of Florida Although the iterative double auction has been widely used in many different applications one of the major problems in its current implementations is that they rely on trusted third party to handle the auction process This imposes the risk of single point of failures monopoly and bribery In this paper we aim to tackle this ul problem by proposing novel decentralized and trust less framework for iterative double auction based on block chain Our design adopts the smart contract and state channel technologies to enable double auction process among parties that do not need to trust each other while minimizing the block chain transactions In specific we propose an extension to the original concept of state channels that can support multiparty computation Then we provide formal development of the proposed framework and prove the security of our design against adversaries Finally we develop proof of concept implementation of our framework using Elixir and Solidity on which we conduct various experiments to demonstrate its feasibility and practicality CCS Concepts Security and privacy Software and application security Distributed systems security Computer systems organization Peer to peer architectures Additional KeyWords and Phrases iterative double auction block chain state channel trust less ACM Reference Format Tru cD Nguyen and My Thai Block chain based Iterative Double Auction Protocol using Multiparty State Channels ACM Trans Internet Techno Article January pages https doi org

Performance Evaluation of Differential Privacy Mechanisms in Block chain based Smart Metering Mu neeb Ul Hassan Mu bashir Hus in Rehman and injun Chen The concept of differential privacy emerged as strong notion to protect database privacy in an un trusted environment Later on researchers proposed several variants of differential privacy in order to preserve privacy in certain other scenarios such as real time cyber physical systems Since then differential privacy has rigorously been applied to certain other domains which has the need of privacy preservation One such domain is decentralized block chain based smart metering in which smart meters acting as block chain nodes sent their real time data to grid utility databases for real time reporting This data is further used to carry out statistical tasks such as load forecasting demand response calculation etc However in case if any intruder gets access to this data it can leak privacy of smart meter users In this context differential privacy can be used to protect privacy of this data In this chapter we carry out comparison of four variants of differential privacy Laplace Gaussian Uniform and Geometric in block chain based smart metering scenario We test these variants on smart metering data and carry out their performance evaluation by varying different parameters Experimental outcomes shows at low privacy budget and at low reading sensitivity value these privacy preserving mechanisms provide high privacy by adding large amount of noise However among these four privacy preserving parameters Geometric parameters is more suitable for protecting high peak values and Laplace mechanism is more suitable for protecting low peak values at

Karl Marx and the Block chain Dev raj Bas Murdoch abbay Strathclyde University Scotland UK He riot Watt University Scotland UK Abstract Block chain is often presented as technological development however clearly it is not only that the Block chain buzz exists in the context of current social and political developments In this essay we analyse block chain technology and its social and political context from perspective of Marxist economic theory Since arguably the last great in ect ion point in society and technology was analysed by Marx in terms of labour and capital and since we seem to be experiencing shift in the balance between these forces today it makes sense to revisit the Marxist ideas and apply them to the current situation to see how well they still apply and if necessary to update them for current events Keywords New factor of production labour versus capital block chain tech no logy evolution data driven value creation Marxian economic theory tech no logy and society Bitcoin and Distributed Ledger Technology Consider Block chain In block chain was just research idea which was commercialised as digital time stamping service called Surety in In design for crypto coin Bitcoin scraped USD Bitcoin at the end of fell back but then rallied and reached USD Bitcoin on December Un surprisingly there came crash but Bitcoin was not wiped out and its reputation was not utterly destroyed it survived and at time of writing Bitcoin trades at around USD bitcoin for trading volume of roughly ten million transactions per month That is fold increase in value in ten years Its not just as store of value that Block chain technology has shown re si lien ce it has shown real in en ce Innumerable elaborations on the underlying ideas have been spun Some are foolish some are fraudulent some are sen sib le However it is clear that at the time of writing the world is awash with Its still running

CARE Block chain Based Framework for Secure Vehicle Health Record System Prana Kumar Singh Member IEEE Rosh an Singh and Su kumar and Senior Member IEEE Abstract One of the biggest challenges associated with connected and autonomous vehicles CAV is to maintain and make use of vehicles health records VH VH can facilitate different entities to offer various services in proactive transparent secure reliable and in an efficient manner The state of the art solutions for maintaining the VH are centralized in nature mainly owned by manufacturer and authorized in vehicle device developers Owners drivers and other key service providers have limited accessibility and control to the VH We need to change the strategy from single or limited party access to multi party access to VH in secured manner so that all stakeholders of intelligent transportation systems ITS can be benefited from this Any unauthorized attempt to alter the data should also be prevented Block chain is one such potential candidate which can facilitate the sharing of such data among die rent participating organizations and individuals For example owners manufacturers trusted third parties road authorities insurance companies charging stations and car selling ventures can access VH stored on the block chain in permission ed secured and with higher level of confidence In this paper block chain based decentralized secure system for CARE is proposed to manage records in an interoperable framework that leads to improved ITS services in terms of safety availability reliability ec ien cy and maintenance Insurance based on pay how you drive PH YD and sale and purchase of used vehicles can also be made more transparent and reliable without compromising the confidentiality and security of sensitive data

AGREEMENTS BETWEEN ENTERPRISES DIGITIZED BY SMART CONTRACTS IN THE DOMAIN OF INDUSTRY Kevin Wallis Jan todt Eugen as tre sko and Christoph Reich Furtw an gen University of Applied Science Germany ABSTRACT The digital transformation of companies is expected to increase the digital interconnection between different companies to develop optimized customized hybrid business models These cross company business models require secure reliable and traceable logging and monitoring of contractually agreed information sharing between machine tools operators and service providers This paper discusses how the major requirements for building hybrid business models can be tackled by the block chain for building chain of trust and smart contracts for digitized contracts machine maintenance use case is used to discuss the readiness of smart contracts for the automation of work flows defined in contracts Furthermore it is shown that the number of failures is significantly improved by using these contracts and block chain KEYWORDS Block chain Smart Contracts Industry Digitized Agreements Maintenance

DATA CONFIDENTIALITY IN COMMUNICATION AND SMART CONTRACTS OF BLOCK CHAIN IN INDUSTRY Jan todt and Christoph Reich Institute for Data Science Cloud Computing and IT Security at the University of Applied Sciences Furtw an gen Furtw an gen Baden rttemberg Germany ABSTRACT Increased collaborative production and dynamic selection of production partners within industry manufacturing leads to ever increasing automatic data exchange between companies Automatic and unsupervised data exchange creates new attack vectors which could be used by malicious insider to leak secrets via an otherwise considered secure channel without anyone noticing In this paper we reflect upon approaches to prevent the exposure of secret data via block chain technology while also providing audi table proof of data exchange We show that previous block chain based privacy protection approaches offer protection but give the control of the data to potentially not trustworthy third parties which also can be considered privacy violation The approach taken in this paper is not utilize centralized data storage for data It realizes data confidentiality of communication and data processing in smart contracts of block chains KEYWORDS block chain privacy protection communication smart contracts industry

Juggling Swap Script less Atomic Cross Chain Swaps Omer Sh lom ov its Oded Leib Zen Research Abstract The block chain space is changing constantly New chains are being implemented frequently with die rent use cases in mind As more and more types of crypto assets are getting real world value there is an increasing need for block chain interoperability Exchange services today are still dominated by central parties which require custody of funds This trust imposes costs and security risks as frequent breaches testify Atomic cross chain swaps CCS allow mutual distrusting parties tose cu rely exchange crypto assets in peer to peer manner while preserving self custody Fundamental CCS protocols leveraged the script ing capabilities of block chains to conditional ize the transfer of funds between trading parties Recent work showed that such proto cols can be realized in script less setting This has many be nets to block chains throughput ec ien cy of swap protocols and also to fungi bil it and privacy The proposed protocols are limited to block chains supporting either Sch nor or CDS signatures that are sharing the same elliptic curve parameters In this work we present Juggling Swap script less atomic cross chain swap protocol with higher degree of interoperability We weaken the assumptions about block chains that can be included in the CCS proto col and only require that threshold variant exists to the underlying digital signature scheme and it is based on the elliptic curve discrete logarithm problem CD LP The fair exchange is achieved by grad al release of secrets To achieve this we use new building block we call Juggling public key veria ble encryption scheme to transfer segments of secret shares between parties which can also be of separate interest Juggling is then tailored to spec ic private key management system design with threshold signatures security

Di LeNA Distributed Ledger Network Analyzer LUCA SERENA IRI ICT Italy STEFANO FERRET TI University of Urbino Italy GABRIELE ANGELO University of Bologna Italy This paper describes the Distributed Ledger Network Analyzer Di LeNA new software tool for the analysis of the transactions network recorded in Distributed Ledger Technologies LTs The set of transactions in aD LT forms complex network Studying its characteristics and peculiarities is of paramount importance in order to understand how users interact in the distributed ledger system The tool design and implementation is introduced and some results are provided In particular the Bitcoin and there um block chains the most famous and used LTs at the time of writing have been analyzed and compared Additional KeyWords and Phrases Distributed Ledger Technologies Block chain Network Analysis Complex Networks ACM Reference Format Luca Serena Stefano Ferret ti and Gabriele Angelo Di LeNA Distributed Ledger Network Analyzer In rd Workshop on Crypto currencies and Block chains for Distributed Systems Cry Block September London United Kingdom ACM New York NY USA pages https doi org

Editorial Understanding Crypto currencies Wolfgang Karl Hard le Humboldt Universitat zu Berlin Germany Wang Yanan Institute for Studies in Economics Xiamen University China Sim Kee Boon Institute for Financial Economics Singapore Management University Singapore Faculty of Mathematics and Physics Charles University Czech Republic hae rd le at hu berlin de Campbell Harvey Duke University Durham NC USA National Bureau of Economic Research Cambridge MA USA cam harvey at duke edu Raphael Re ule Humboldt Universitat zu Berlin Germany irt wi wi at hu berlin de th July Abstract Crypto currency refers to type of digital asset that uses distributed ledger or block chain technology to enable secure transaction Although the technology is widely misunderstood many central banks are considering launching their own na ional crypto currency In contrast to most data in nanci al economics detailed data on the history of every transaction in the crypto currency complex are freely avail able Furthermore empirically oriented research is only now beginning presenting an extraordinary research opportunity for academia We provide some insights into the mechanics of crypto currencies describing summary statistics and focusing on potential future research avenues in nanci al economics EL Classic ation Keywords Crypto currency Block chain bitcoin Economic bubble Peer to Peer Finance Cryptographic hashing Consensus Proof of work Proof of stake Volatility The financial support of Czech Science Foundation under grant no is acknowledged

Foundational Oracle Patterns Connecting Block chain to the Off chain World Roman hl berger Stefan Bach of ner Eduardo Castell Ferrer Claudio Di Cicci In go Weber Maximilian hrer and Uwe dun Vienna University of Economics and Business Vienna Austria Massachusetts Institute of Technology Cambridge United States pienza University of Rome Rome Italy Technische Universitaet Berlin Berlin Germany University of Vienna Vienna Austria Abstract Block chain has evolved into platform for decentralized applications with beneficial properties like high integrity transparency and resilience against censorship and tampering However block chains are closed world systems which do not have access to external state To overcome this limitation oracles have been introduced in various forms and for different purposes However so far common oracle best practices have not been dissected classified and studied in their fundamental aspects In this paper we address this gap by studying foundational block chain oracle patterns in two foundational dimensions character ising the oracles the data flow direction inbound and outbound data flow from the viewpoint of the block chain and ii the in ti at or of the data flow whether it is push or pull based communication We provide structured description of the four patterns in detail and discuss an implementation of these patterns based on use cases On this basis we conduct quantitative analysis which results in the insight that the four different patterns are characterized by distinct performance and costs profiles Keywords Block chain Design patterns Software patterns Oracles

Implications of Dissemination Strategies on the Security of Distributed Ledgers LUCA SERENA IRI ICT Italy GABRIELE ANGELO University of Bologna Italy STEFANO FERRET TI University of Urbino Italy This paper describes simulation study on security attacks over Distributed Ledger Technologies LTs We specifically focus on attacks at the underlying peer to peer layer of these systems that is in charge of disseminating messages containing data and transaction to be spread among all participants In particular we consider the Sybil attack according to which malicious node creates many Sybil that drop messages coming from specific attacked node or even all messages from honest nodes Our study shows that the selection of the specific dissemination protocol as well as the amount of connections each peer has have an influence on the resistance to this attack Additional KeyWords and Phrases block chain distributed ledger technologies simulation security data dissemination ACM Reference Format Luca Serena Gabriele Angelo and Stefano Ferret ti Implications of Dissemination Strategies on the Security of Distributed Ledgers In rd Workshop on Crypto currencies and Block chains for Distributed Systems Cry Block September London United Kingdom ACM New York NY USA pages https doi org

Framework for LT Based OVID Passport rang Chau hari Michael Clear Philip radish and Hi tesh Te war Indian Institute of Technology Delhi Trinity College Dublin Ireland Abstract Uniquely identifying individuals across the various networks they interact with on daily basis remains challenge for the digital world that we live in and therefore the development of secure and cie nt privacy preserving identity mechanisms has become an important el of research In addition the popularity of de centralised decision making networks such as Bitcoin has seen huge interest in making use of distributed ledger technology to store and securely disseminate end user identity credentials In this paper we describe mechanism that allows one to store the OVID vaccination details of individuals on publicly readable de centralised immutable block chain and makes use of two factor authentication system that employs biometric crypto graphic hashing techniques to generate unique den tier for each user Our main contribution is the employment of provably secure input hiding locality sensitive hashing algorithm over an iris extraction tech ni que that can be used to authenticate users and anonymously locate vaccination records on the block chain without leaking any personally ident able information to the block chain

Survey of Smart Contract Formal Specification and Verification PALIN TO MACH Nanyang Technological University Singapore and Institute of High Performance Computing STAR Singapore YI LI SHANG WEIL IN and YANG LIU Nanyang Technological University Singapore ZENG XIANG LI Institute of High Performance Computing STAR Singapore smart contract is computer program which allows users to automate their actions on the block chain platform Given the significance of smart contracts in supporting important activities across industry sectors including supply chain finance legal and medical services there is strong demand for verification and validation techniques Yet the vast majority of smart contracts lack any kind of formal specification which is essential for establishing their correctness In this survey we investigate formal models and specifications of smart contracts presented in the literature and present systematic overview in order to understand the common trends We also discuss the current approaches used in verifying such property specifications and identify gaps with the hope to recognize promising directions for future work Additional KeyWords and Phrases Smart contract formal verification formal specification properties

Cerberus Minimalist ic Multi shard Byzantine resilient Transaction Processing elle Hell in gs Daniel Hughes Joshua Prime ro Mohammad Sad oghi Exploratory Systems Lab Department of Computer Science University of California Davis CA USA Radix LT Ltd Argyle Works Euston Road London NW SD Abstract To enable high performance and scalable block chains we need to step away from traditional consensus based fully replicated designs One direction is to explore the usage of harding in which we partition the managed data set over many shards that independently operate as block chains harding requires nec ent fault tolerant primitive for the ordering and execution of multi shard transactions however In this work we seek to design such primitive suitable for distributed ledger networks with high transaction throughput To do so we propose Cerberus set of minimalist ic primitives for processing single shard and multi shard UT XO like transactions Cerberus aims at maximizing parallel processing at shards while minimizing coordination within and between shards First we propose Core Cerberus that uses strict environmental requirements to enable simple yet powerful multi shard transaction processing In our intended UT XO environment Core Cerberus will operate perfectly with respect to all transactions proposed and approved by well behaved clients but does not provide any guarantees for other transactions To also support more general purpose environments we propose two generalizations of Core Cerberus we propose Optimistic Cerberus protocol that does not require any additional coordination phases in the well behaved optimistic case while requiring intricate coordination when recovering from attacks and we propose Pessimistic Cerberus protocol that adds uci ent coordination to the well behaved case of Core Cerberus allowing it to operate in general purpose fault tolerant environments without sign cant costs to recover from attacks Finally we compare the three protocols showing their potentials cal ability and high transaction throughput in practical environments

HOLDOUT SGD BYZANTINE TOLERANT FEDERATED LEARNING Shahar Azula Li or Raz The Blava nik School of Computer Science The Blava nik School of Computer Science Tel Aviv University Israel Tel Aviv University Israel shahar azula mail tau ac il li or raz mail tau ac il Amir Globe rs on Tome rKo ren The Blava nik School of Computer Science The Blava nik School of Computer Science Tel Aviv University Israel Tel Aviv University Israel tko ren tau ex tau ac il Yehuda Af ek The Blava nik School of Computer Science Tel Aviv University Israel af ek tau ex tau ac il August ABSTRACT This work presents new distributed Byzantine tolerant federated learning algorithm HoldOutS GD for Stochastic Gradient Descent SGD optimization HoldOutS GD uses the well known machine learning technique of holdout estimation in distributed fashion in order to select parameter updates that are likely to lead to models with low loss values This makes it more effective at discarding Byzantine workers inputs than existing methods that eliminate outliers in the parameter space of the learned model HoldOutS GDr st randomly selects set of workers that use their private data in order to propose gradient updates Next voting committee of workers is randomly selected and each voter uses its private data as holdout data in order to select the best proposals via voting scheme We propose two possible mechanisms for the coordination of workers in the distributed computation Xi of HoldOutS GD The rst uses truthful central server and corresponds to the typical setting of current federated learning The second is fully distributed and requires no central server paving the way to fully decentralized federated learning The fully distributed version implements HoldOut SGD via ideas from the block chain domain and spec ic ally the lg or and committee selection and consensus processes We provide formal guarantees for the HoldOutS GD process in terms of its convergence to the optimal model and its level of resilience to the fraction of Byzantine workers The analysis assumes convexity of the loss but the method is applicable to general learning scenarios including deep learning Empirical evaluation shows that HoldOutS GD is Byzantine resilient and efc ent ly converges to an effectual model for deep learning tasks as long as the total number of participating workers is large and the fraction of Byzantine workers is less than half for the fully distributed variant We show trade offs between the fraction of Byzantine workers the convergence conde ce of the algorithm and the number of participating workers

Security Analysis on Tangle based Block chain through Simulation Full Version cid Boz hi Wang cid cid Qin Wang cid cid Ship ing Chen Yang Xiang University of New South Wales boz hi wang student nsw edu au Swinburne University of Technology qin wang yi ang win edu au CSIRO Data Ship ing Chen data csiro au Abstract The Tangle based structure becomes one of the most promis ing solutions when designing DAG based block chain systems The ap roach improves the cal ability by directly con ming multiple trans ac ions in parallel instead of single blocks in linear However the per for man ce gain may bring potential security risks In this paper we construct three types of attacks with comprehensive evaluations namely parasite attack PS double spending attack DS and hybrid attack HB To achieve that we deconstruct the Tangle based projects IOTA and abstract the main components to rebuild simple but ex ble network for the simulation Then we informally de ne the three smallest actions to buildup the attack strategies layer by layer Based on that we provide analyses to evaluate the die rent attacks in multiple dimensions To the best of our knowledge this is the rst study to provide comprehensive security analysis of Tangle based block chains Keywords Tangle DAG Block chain Attack IOTA

BLOCK CHAIN ENABLED INTERNET OF THINGS PLATFORM FOR END TO END INDUSTRIAL HEMP SUPPLY CHAIN Ke qi Wang We nc en Wu Wei Xie in xiang Pei and Qi Zhou Northeastern University Boston MA San Jose State University San Jose CA Quark Chain Inc San Mateo CA ABSTRACT After being legalized as an agricultural commodity by the Farm Bill the Industrial Hemp production is moved from limited pilot programs to regulated agriculture production system and the market keeps increasing since then However Industrial Hemp Supply Chain IHS faces several critical challenges including high complexity and variability data tampering and lack of immutable information tracking system In this paper we develop block chain enabled internet of things oT platform for IHS to support process tracking cal ability interoperability and risk management Basically we create two layer block chain with proof of authority based smart con tract which can leverage local authorities with state federal regulators to ensure and accelerate qu al it control ver cation and regulatory compliance Then we develop user friendly mobile app so that each participant can use smartphone to real time collect and upload their data to the cloud and further share the process ver cation and tracking information through the block chain network Our study indicates the proposed platform can support interoperability improve the efc ien cy of quality control ver cation and ensure the safety of regulated IHS Keywords Block chain Industrial Hemp Supply Chain Safety Regulation Supply Chain Risk Management Internet of Things oT StateS harding Parallel Processing CBD Oil

Proof of Person hood Review Who Watches the Watchmen Review of Subjective Approaches for Sybil resistance in Proof of Person hood Protocols Div ya Sid darth Sergey Iv liev Santiago Siri Paula Berman Correspondence Paula Berman paula democracy earth Keywords decentralized identity Sybil protection crypto governance Abstract Most self sovereign identity systems consist of strictly objective claims cryptographically signed by trusted third party attest or Lacking protocols in place to account for subjectivity these systems do not form new sources of legitimacy that can address the central question concerning identity authentication Who verifies the ver fier Instead the legitimacy of claims is derived from traditional centralized institutions such as national ID issuers and KY providers This architecture has been employed in part to safeguard protocols from vulnerability previously thought to be impossible to address in peer to peer identity systems the Sybil attack which refers to the abuse of digital network by creating many illegitimate virtual person as Inspired by the progress in crypto currencies and block chain technology there has recently been surge in networked protocols that make use of subjective inputs such as voting vouching and interpreting to arrive at decentralized and sybil resistant consensus for identity In doing so these projects illustrate that the best technologies do not abstract away subjectivity but instead embrace it as necessity and strength In this review we will outline the approaches of these new and natively digital sources of authentication their attributes methodologies strengths and weaknesses and sketch out possible directions for future developments

Pro ling Gas Leaks in Solidity Smart Contracts Gerardo Can for Andrea Di Sorbo Sonia Laud anna Anna Vacca Corrado Visa gg io Abstract Nowadays more and more applications are developed for running on distributed ledger technology namely Apps The business logic of Apps is usually implemented within smart contracts developed through Solidity programming language for writing smart contracts on different block chain platforms including the popular there um In there um the smart contracts run on the machines of miners and the gas corresponds to the execution fee compensating such computing resources However the deployment and execution costs of smart contract depend on the implementation choices done by developers Un appropriated design choices could lead to higher gas consumption than necessary In this paper we identify set of Solidity code smells affecting the deployment and transaction costs of smart contract and ii assess the relevance of such smells through survey involving participants On top of these smells we propose Gas Met suite of metrics for statically evaluating the code quality of smart contract from the gas consumption perspective An experiment involving smart contracts demonstrates that the proposed metrics have direct associations with deployment costs The metrics in our suite can be used for more easily identifying source code segments that need optimization Index Terms Software Engineering for Block chain Technologies Smart Contracts Optimization Code Quality Software Metrics Empirical Study cid

pak is pav los papadopoulos napier ac uk Received July Accepted August Published August Abstract The Domain Name System DNS was created to resolve the IP addresses of the web servers to easily remembered names When it was initially created security was not major concern nowadays this lack of inherent security and trust has exposed the global DNS infrastructure to malicious actors The passive DNS data collection process creates database containing various DNS data elements some of which are personal and need to be protected to preserve the privacy of the end users To this end we propose the use of distributed ledger technology We use Hyper ledger Fabric to create permission ed block chain which only authorized entities can access The proposed solution supports queries for storing and retrieving data from the block chain ledger allowing the use of the passive DNS database for further analysis for the ident cation of malicious domain names Additionally it effectively protects the DNS personal data from unauthorized entities including the administrators that can act as potential malicious insiders and allows only the data owners to perform queries over these data We evaluated our proposed solution by creating proof of concept experimental setup that passively collects DNS data from network and then uses the distributed ledger technology to store the data in an immutable ledger thus providing full historical overview of all the records Keywords Passive DNS Privacy Preserving Distributed Ledger Block chain Hyper ledger Fabric Private Data Collection

No name manuscript No will be inserted by the editor Discouraging Pool Block Withholding Attacks in Bitcoins Zhi huai Chen Bo Li Xiao han Shan Xiao ming Sun Ji al in Zhang Received date Accepted date Abstract The arisen of Bitcoin has led to much enthusiasm for block chain research and block mining and the extensive existence of mining pools helps its participants miners gain reward more frequently Recently the mining pools are proved to be vulnerable for several possible attacks and pool block withholding attack is one of them one strategic pool manager sends some of her miners to other pools and these miners pretend to work on the puzzles but actually do nothing And these miners still get reward since the pool manager can not recognize these malicious miners In this work were visit the game theoretic model for pool block withholding attacks and propose revised approach to reallocate the reward to the miners Fortunately in the new model the pool managers have strong incentive to not launch such attacks We show that for any number of mining pools no pool attacks is always Nash equilibrium Moreover with only two minority mining pools participating no pool attacks is actually the unique Nash equilibrium Keywords Block chain Mining Pool Block Withholding Attack Game Theory Zhi huai Chen Jia linZ hang Xiao ming Sun University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing China CAS Key Lab of Network Data Science and Technology Institute of Computing Technology Chinese Academy of Sciences CAS Beijing China mail chen zhi huai zhang ji al in sun xiao ming ict ac cn BoLi Department of Computer Science University of Oxford OX QD Oxford United Kingdom mail boli cs ox ac uk Xiao hanS han Department of Computer Science and Technology Tsinghua University Beijing China mail shanxi oh an tsinghua edu cn

An Incentive Compatible Smart Contract for Decentralized Commerce Nikola Schwartz bach Department of Computer Science Aarhus University Abstract We propose smart contract that allows two mutually distrusting parties to transact any non digital good or service by deploying smart contract on block chain to act as escrow The contract settles disputes by letting parties wager that they can convince an arbiter that they were the honest party We analyse the contract as an extensive form game and prove that the honest strategy is secure in strong game theoretic sense if and only if the arbiter is biased in favor of honest parties By relaxing the security notion we can replace the arbiter by random coin toss Finally we show how to generalize the contract to multiparty transactions in away that amortizes the transaction fees Keywords smart contract game theory electronic commerce block chain is tribute systems

Decentralized Asset Custody Scheme with Security against Rational Adversary Zhao hua Chen and Guang Yang CFCS Computer Science Dept Peking University Con ux chen zhao hua pku edu cn guang yang con flux network org Abstract Asset custody is core nanci al service in which the cus to dian holds in safekeeping assets on behalf of the client Although tra it ional custody service is typically endorsed by centralized authorities decentralized custody scheme has become technically feasible since the emergence of digital assets and furthermore it is greatly needed by new applications such as block chain and DeF Decentralized Finance In this work we propose framework of decentralized asset custody scheme that is able to support large number of custodians and safely hold customer assets of multiple times the value of the total security deposit The proposed custody scheme distributes custodians and assets into many custodian groups via combinatorial designs where each group fully controls the assigned assets Since every custodian group is small the overhead cost is sign cant ly reduced The live ness is also improved because even single alive group would be able to process transactions The security of this custody scheme is guaranteed under the rational adversary model such that any adversary corrupting abounded fraction of custodians cannot move assets more than the security deposit paid We further analyze the security and performance of our constructions from both theoretical and experimental sides and give explicit examples with concrete numbers and gur es for better understanding of our results Keywords Block chain application Decentralized asset custody Ra ional adversary

Share Withholding Attack in Block chain Mining Technical Report Sang Yoon Chang University of Colorado Colorado Springs Colorado Springs CO USA chang ucc edu Abstract Crypto currency achieves distributed consensus using proof of work PoW Prior research in block chain security den tied nan ci ally in centi viz ed attacks based on withholding blocks which have the attacker compromise victim pool and pose as PoW contributor by submitting the shares earning credit for mining but withholding the blocks no actual contributions to the pool We advance such threats to generate greater reward advantage to the attackers while undermining the other miners and introduce the share withholding attack WH WH withholds shares to increase the attackers reward pay out within the pool in contrast to the prior threats withholding blocks and rather builds on the block withholding threats in order to exploit the in form tion about the impending block submission timing challenging the pop la rly established assumption that the block submission time is completely random and unknown to miners We analyze WH incentive com pati bil it and the vulnerability scope by identifying the critical systems and environmental parameters which determine the attacks impact Our re sul ts show that WH in conjunction with block withholding yield unfair reward advantage at the expense of the protocol complying victim min ers and that rational miner will sel shl launch WH to maximize its reward prot We in form the block chain and crypto currency research of the novel WH threat and include the potential counter measure dire ions to facilitate such research and development Keywords Crypto currency Block chain Rational mining Block withholding

dong Lin School of Cyber Science and Technology Bei hang University Beijing China Faculty of Computer Science University of New Brunswick Fredericton BE Canada School of Computer Science University of Guelph Guelph ON Canada Correspondence zo ngyang zhang bu edu cn liu jian wei bu edu cn https doi org patter THE BIGGER PICTURE Smart contracts are one of the most promising and appealing notions in block chain technology We provide comprehensive review of state of the art smart contract construction and exec tion schemes We classify three major categories design paradigms that give examples and patterns on contract construction design tools that facilitate the development of secure smart contracts and ex tensions and alternatives that improve privacy or efc ien cy We found that frequently occurred vu lner bil ties incomplete paradigms in efc ent analysis tools low processing rate limited contract complexity and the lack of privacy are the main challenges that hinder the adoption of smart contracts We identify several future research directions including fair off chain networks practical implementations scalable and automatic analysis tools and private contracts with practical compilers SUMMARY Smart contracts are regarded as one of the most promising and appealing notions in block chain technology Their self enforcing and event driven features make some online activities possible without trusted third party Nevertheless problems such as miscellaneous attacks privacy leakage and low processing rates pre vent them from being widely applied Various schemes and tools have been proposed to facilitate the con struct ion and execution of secure smart contracts However comprehensive survey for these proposals is absent hindering new researchers and developers from quick start This paper surveys the literature and online resources on smart contract construction and execution over the period We divide the studies into three categories design paradigms that give examples and patterns on contract construction design tools that facilitate the development of secure smart contracts and extensions and alternatives that improve the privacy or efc ien cy of the Contract Service Provider Model for Virtual Assets THOMAS HARD ONO MIT Connection Science ALEXANDER LIPTON MIT Connection Science ALEX PENT LAND MIT Connection Science With the recent rise in the cost of transactions on block chain platforms there is need to explore other service models that may provide more predictable cost to customers and end users We discuss the contract service provider CSP model as counterpart of the successful Internet ISP model Similar to the ISP business model based on peered routing networks the CSP business model is based multiple CSP entities forming CSP community or group offering contract service for specific types of virtual assets We discuss the contract domain construct which encapsulates well defined smart contract primitives policies and contract ledger We offer number of design principles borrowed from the design principles of the Internet architecture Additional KeyWords and Phrases Block chains Fa aS smart contracts virtual assets contract service providers contract domains

Immutable Log Storage as Service on Private and Public Block chains William Pour majid Lei Zhang John Steinbach er Tony Erwin and Andriy Miran sky Department of Computer Science Ry ers on University Toronto Canada IBM Canada Lab Toronto Canada IBM Watson and Cloud Platform Austin USA william pour majid ry ers on ca lei zhang ry ers on ca stein ca ibm com erwin us ibm com vm ry ers on ca Abstract During the normal operation of Cloud solution noone pays attention to the logs except the system reliability engineers who may periodically check them to ensure that the Cloud platforms performance conforms to the Service Level Agreements SLA However the moment component fails or cus to mer complains about breach of SLA the importance of logs increases sign cant ly All departments including management customer support and even the actual customer may turn to logs to determine the cause and timeline of the issue and to nd the party responsible for the issue The party at fault may be motivated to tamper with the logs to hide their role Given the number and volume of logs generated by the Cloud platforms many tampering opportunities exist We argue that the critical nature of logs calls for immutability and ver cation mechanism without the presence of single trusted party This paper proposes such mechanism by describing block chain based log system called Log chain which can be integrated with existing private and public block chain solutions Log chain uses the im mutability feature of block chain to provide tamper resistance storage platform for log storage Add tion ally we propose hierarchical structure to combine the hash binding of two block chains to address block chains cal ability issues To validate the mechanism we integrate Log chain into two die rent types of block chains We choose there um as public permission less block chain and IBM Block chain as private permission based one We show that the solution is scalable on both the private and pub li block chains Additionally we perform the analysis of the cost of ownership for private and public block chains implementations to help reader selecting an implementation that would be applicable to their needs The Log chains cal ability improvement on block chain is achieved without any alteration on the fundamental architecture of block chains As shown in this work it can function on private and public block chains and therefore can be suitable alternative for organizations that need secure immutable log storage platform

Hierarchical Coding for Cloud Storage Topology Adapt iv it cal ability and Flexibility Si yi Yang Student Member IEEE Ahmed Ha reedy Member IEEE Robert Calder bank Fellow IEEE and Lara Dole ek Senior Member IEEE Abstract In order to accommodate the ever growing data from various possibly independent sources and the dynamic nature of data usage rates in practical applications modern cloud data storage systems are required to be scalable ex ble and heterogeneous The recent rise of the block chain technology is also moving various information systems towards decentralization to achieve high privacy at low costs While codes with hierarchical locality have been intensively studied in the context of centralized cloud storage due to their effectiveness in reducing the average reading time those for decentralized storage networks SNs have not yet been discussed In this paper we propose joint coding scheme where each node receives extra protection through the cooperation with nodes in its neighborhood in heterogeneous DS with any given topology This work extends and subsumes our prior work on coding for centralized cloud storage In particular our proposed construction not only preserves desirable properties such as cal ability and ex bil it which are critical in dynamic networks but also adapts to arbitrary topologies property that is essential in SNs but has been overlooked in existing works Index Terms Joint hierarchical coding cooperative data protection decentralized storage networks cal ability ex bil it

SP Chain Block chain based Medical Data Sharing and Privacy preserving Health System Ren peng Zo Xi xiang Lv Jing song Zhao School of Cyber Engineering Xi dian University Xian China Abstract The sharing of electronic medical records MRs has great positive sign can ce for research on disease and epidemic prevention Recently block chain based Health systems have achieved great success in terms of MRs sharing and management but there still remain some challenges Permission ed block chain based solutions provide high throughput and cal ability but may sue from rollback attacks and lead to privacy leakage Designs based on the public block chain on the other hand are more open and secure but sac rice cal ability and have no incentives for medical institutions to join into the systems Moreover data retrieval in block chain based Health systems is in ec ent be cause of the basic block chain structure To solve the above problems we propose block chain based medical data sharing and privacy preserving Health system named SP Chain To achieve quick retrieval we devise special key blocks and micro blocks for patients to store their MRs reputation system is also con struct ed to motivate medical institutions to participate in SP Chain By using proxy re encryption schemes SP Chain achieves medical data sharing for pa ti ents in privacy preserving manner To evaluate SP Chain we leverage the distribution of miners in the real world to test the systems performance and ability to resist mentioned attacks The results show that SP Chain can achieve high throughput TPS with low storage overhead Compared with the Corresponding author Email address xlv mail xi dian edu cn Xi xiang Lv The work of Xi xiang Lv Ren peng Zo and Jing song Zhao is supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China Grant No Pre print submitted to Journal of Information processing management April

Constraint Programming Algorithms for Route Planning Exploiting Geometrical Information Alessandro Bert agnon Department of Engineering University of Ferrara Ferrara Italy alessandro bert agnon uni fe it Problems affecting the transport of people or goods are plentiful in industry and commerce and they also appear to be at the origin of much more complex problems In recent years the logistics and transport sector keeps growing supported by technological progress companies to be competitive are resorting to innovative technologies aimed at efc ien cy and effectiveness This is why companies are increasingly using technologies such as Art ici al Intelligence Block chain and Internet of Things oT Art ici al intelligence in particular is often used to solve optimization problems in order to provide users with the most efc ent ways to exploit available resources In this work we present an overview of our current research activities concerning the development of new algorithms based on Constraint Logic Programming LP techniques for route planning problems exploiting the geometric information intrinsically present in many of them or in some of their variants The research so far has focused in particular on the Euclidean Traveling Salesperson Problem Euclidean TSP with the aim to exploit the results obtained also to other problems of the same category such as the Euclidean Vehicle Routing Problem Euclidean RP in the future

An Incentive Based Mechanism for Volunteer Computing using Block chain ISMA EEL AL RIDHA WI Kuwait College of Science and Technology Kuwait MOA YAD ALO QA LY AlAin University UAE YA SERJ ARAR WE Jordan University of Science and Technology Jordan The rise of fast communication media both at the core and at the edge has resulted in unprecedented numbers of sophisticated and intelligent wireless oT devices Tactile Internet has enabled the interaction between humans and machines within their environment to achieve revolutionized solutions both on the move and in real time Many applications such as intelligent autonomous self driving smart agriculture and industrial solutions and self learning multimedia content filtering and sharing have become attainable through cooperative distributed and decentralized systems namely volunteer computing This article introduces block chain enabled resource sharing and service composition solution through volunteer computing Device resource computing and intelligence capabilities are advertised in the environment to be made discover able and available for sharing with the aid of block chain technology Incentives in the form of on demand service availability are given to resource and service providers to ensure fair and balanced cooperative resource usage Block chains are formed whenever service request is initiated with the aid of fog and mobile edge computing ME devices to ensure secure communication and service delivery for the participants Using both volunteer computing techniques and tactile internet architectures we devise fast and reliable service provisioning framework that relies on reinforcement learning technique Simulation results show that the proposed solution can achieve high reward distribution increased number of block chain formations reduced delays and balanced resource usage among participants under the premise of high oT device availability CCS Concepts Networks Network management Network mobility TAXONOMY OF CENTRALIZATION IN PUBLIC BLOCK CHAIN SYSTEMS SYSTEMATIC LITERATURE REVIEW PRE PRINT shish Rajendra Sai Jim Buckley ero Irish Software Research Centre ero Irish Software Research Centre University of Limerick University of Limerick Limerick Ireland Limerick Ireland student mail ul ie Brian Fitzgerald Andrew Le Gear ero Irish Software Research Centre Horizon Globe Ireland DAC University of Limerick Nexus Center University of Limerick Limerick Ireland Limerick Ireland September ABSTRACT Bitcoin introduced delegation of control over monetary system from select few to all who participate in that system This delegation is known as the decentralization of controlling power and is powerful security mechanism for the ecosystem After the introduction of Bitcoin the el of crypto currency has seen widespread attention from industry and academia so much so that the original novel contribution of Bitcoin decentralization maybe overlooked due to decentralization assumed fundamental existence for the functioning of such crypto assets However recent studies have observed trend of increased centralization in crypto currencies such as Bitcoin and there um As this increased centralization has an impact the security of the block chain it is crucial that it is measured towards adequate control This research derives an initial taxonomy of centralization present in decentralized block chains through rigorous synthesis using systematic literature review This is followed by iterative rene ment through expert interviews We systematically analyzed research papers published between and Our study contributes to the existing body of knowledge by highlighting the multiple den it ions and measurements of centralization in the literature We identify different aspects of centralization and propose an encompassing taxonomy of centralization concerns This taxonomy is based on empirically observable and measurable characteristics It consists of aspects of centralization class ed over six architectural layers Governance Network Consensus Incentive Operational and Application We also discuss how the implications of centralization can vary depending on the aspects studied We believe that this review and taxonomy provides comprehensive overview of centralization in decentralized block chains involving various conceptualizations and measures Keywords Decentralized Block chain Centralization Classic ation Measurement Taxonomy Security
