Online Rating System Development using Block chain based Distributed Ledger Technology Mon ir Shaker Fer eido on Shams Ali ee Reza Foto hi Abstract In most websites the online rating system provides the ratings of products and services to users Lack of trust in data integrity and its manipulation has hindered fulfilling user satisfaction Since existing online rating systems deal with central server all rating data is stored on the central server Therefore all rating data can be removed modified and manipulated by the system manager to change the ratings in favor of the service or product provider In this paper an online rating system using distributed ledger technologies has been presented as the proposed system to solve all the weaknesses of current systems Distributed ledger technologies are completely decentralized and there is no centralization on them by any institution Distributed ledger technologies have different variants Among distributed ledger technologies block chain technology has been used in the proposed rating system because of its support for smart contracts In the proposed online rating system the there um platform has been chosen from different block chain platforms that have public permission network In this system the rate rs cannot rate unless they submit request to the system and be authorized to take part in the online product rating process The important feature of the there um platform is its support for smart contracts which can be used to write the rating contract in the Solidity language Also using Proof of Authority PoA consensus mechanisms all rating transactions are approved by the surveyors Since in the real there um system each rating transaction is sent to the network by the rate rs some gas must be paid for each rating transaction However since this method is expensive Test Net block chain can be used in the rating system Finally the proposed rating system was used for rating the restaurants of website and its features were tested Keywords Online Rating System Distributed Ledger Technology Block chain Proof of Authority PoA Test Ne Mon ir Shaker one er shaker gmail com Fer eido on Shams Ali ee shams bu ac ir Reza Foto hi foto hi bu ac ir Foto hi reza gmail com Faculty of Computer Science and Engineering Shahid Be he sh ti University Evin Tehran Iran

SHARING PANDEMIC VACCINATION CERTIFICATES THROUGH BLOCK CHAIN CASE STUDY AND PERFORMANCE EVALUATION Jose Hernandez Ramos Georgios Karo poul os Dimitri Gene iata is Tani Martin Georgios Kam bou rak is and Igor Na iF ovi no European Commission Joint Research Centre Is pra Italy jose luis hernandez ramos georgios karo poul os dimitrios gene iata is tani martin georgios kam pour ak is igor nai fo vino ec europa eu January ABSTRACT This work proposes scalable block chain based platform for the secure sharing of OVID or other disease vaccination cert cates As an indicative use case we simulate large scale deploy ment by considering the countries of the European Union The proposed platform is evaluated through extensive simulations in terms of computing resource usage network response time and bandwidth Based on the results the proposed scheme shows satisfactory performance across all major evaluation criteria suggesting that it can set the pace for real implementations Vis vis the related work the proposed platform is novel especially through the prism of large scale full edged implementation and its assessment

Towards Mobile Distributed Ledgers Dimitri Chat zo poul os Anura Jain Su it Gujar Boi Fal tings and Pan Hui Abstract Advances in mobile computing have paved the way for new types of distributed applications that can be executed solely by mobile devices on device to device ecosystems crowd sensing Sophisticated applications like crypto currencies need distributed ledgers to function Distributed ledgers such as block chains and directed cyclic graphs DAG employ consensus protocols to add data in the form of blocks However such protocols are designed for resourceful devices that are interconnected via the Internet Moreover existing distributed ledgers are not deploy able toD ecosystems since their storage needs are continuously increasing In this work we introduce and analyse Mneme DAG based distributed ledger that can be maintained solely by mobile devices Mneme utilizes two novel consensus protocols Proof of Context Po and Proof of Equivalence PoE Po employs users context to add data on Mneme PoE is executed periodically to summarize data and produce equivalent blocks that require less storage We analyze Mneme security and justify the ability of Po and PoE to guarantee the characteristics of distributed ledgers persistence and live ness Furthermore we analyze potential attacks from malicious users and prove that the probability of successful attack is inversely proportional to the square of the number of mobile users who maintain Mneme Index Terms Distributed Ledgers Consensus Protocols ecosystems cid

On the Synchronization Power of Token Smart Contracts Or est is Al pos Christian Cach in University of Bern University of Bern or est is al pos in uni be ch cach in in uni be ch Giorgi Az zur raM arson Luca Zan olin University of Bern University of Bern giorgi mars on in uni be ch luca zan olin in uni be ch Abstract Modern block chains support variety of distributed applications beyond crypto currencies including smart contracts which let users execute arbitrary code in distributed and decentralized fashion Regardless of their intended application block chain platforms implicitly assume consensus for the correct execution of smart contract thus requiring that all transactions are totally ordered It was only recently recognized that consensus is not necessary to prevent double spending in crypto cur ren cy Guerra oui et al POD contrary to common belief This result suggests that current implementations maybe sacr icing efc ien cy and cal ability because they synchronize transactions much more tightly than actually needed In this work we study the synchronization requirements of there um ER token contract one of the most widely adopted smart contacts Namely we model smart contract token as con current object and analyze its consensus number as measure of synchronization power We show that the richer set of methods supported byE RC tokens compared to standard crypto currencies re sul ts in strictly stronger synchronization requirements More surprisingly the synchronization power of ER tokens depends on the objects state and can thus be mo died by method invocations To prove this result we develop dedicated framework to express how the objects state affects the needed synchronization level Our dings indicate that ER tokens as well as other token standards are more powerful and versatile than plain crypto currencies and are subject to dynamic re quire ment Developing spec ic synchronization protocols that exploit these dynamic requirements will pave the way towards more robust and scalable block chain platforms

Block chain Assisted Decentralized Federated Learning BLADE FL Performance Analysis and Resource Allocation Jun Li Yu meng Shao Kang Wei Ming Ding Chuan Ma Long Shi Zhu Han and Vincent Poor Abstract Federated learning FL as distributed machine learning paradigm promotes personal privacy by local data processing at each client However relying on centralized server for model aggregation standard FL is vulnerable to server malfunctions untrustworthy server and external attacks To address this issue we propose decentralized FL framework by integrating block chain into FL namely block chain assisted decentralized federated learning BLADE FL In around of the proposed BLADE FL each client broadcasts the trained model to other clients aggregates its own model with received ones and then competes to generate block before its local training of the next round We evaluate the learning performance of BLADE FL and develop an upper bound on the global loss function Then we verify that this bound is convex with respect to the number of overall aggregation rounds and optimize the computing resource allocation for minimizing the upper bound We also note that there is critical problem of training dec ien cy caused by lazy clients who plagiarize other strained models and add art ici al noises to disguise their cheating behaviors Focusing on this problem we explore the impact of lazy clients on the learning performance of BLADE FL and characterize the relationship among the optimal the learning parameters and the proportion of lazy clients Based on NIST and Fashion NIST datasets we show that the experimental results are consistent with the analytical ones To be spec ic the gap between the developed upper bound and experimental results is lower than and the optimized based on the upper bound can effectively minimize the loss function Index Terms Federated learning block chain lazy client computing resource allocation cid

How Much Communication Resource is Needed to Run Wireless Block chain Network Lei Zhang Hao Xu Ol uwa kay ode On ire ti Muhammad Ali Imran and Bin Cao Abstract Block chain is built on peer to peer network that relies on frequent communications among the distributive ly located nodes In particular the consensus mechanisms CMs which play pivotal role in block chain are communication resource demanding and largely determines block chain security bound and other key performance metrics such as transaction throughput latency and cal ability Most block chain systems are designed in stable wired communication network running in advanced devices under the assumption of ufc ent communication resource provision However it is envisioned that the majority of the block chain node peers will be connected through the wireless network in the future Constrained by the highly dynamic wireless channel and scarce frequency spectrum communication can sign cant ly affect block chains key performance metrics Hence in this paper we present wireless block chain networks WB under various commonly used CMs and we answer the question of how much communication resource is needed to run such network We rst present the role of communication in the four stages of the block chain procedure We then discuss the relationship between the communication resource provision and the WB Ns performance for three of the most used block chain CMs namely Proof of Work PoW practical Byzantine Fault Tolerant PB FT and Raft Finally we provide analytical and simulated results to show the impact of the communication resource provision on block chain performance Index Terms Lei Zhang Lei Zhang glasgow ac uk Hao Xu Ol uwa kay ode On ire ti and and Muhammad Ali Imran are with the James Watt School of Engineering University of Glasgow Glasgow QQ UK Bin Cao is with Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications China

Atomic Swaps between Bitcoin and Mon ero Philipp Ho en isch and Lucas Soriano del Pino COMIT first name comit network CoB loX Pty Ltd first name cob lox tech Abstract Due to the ever growing block chain ecosystem inter opera bil it has become matter of great importance Atomic swaps allow con nec ting otherwise isolated block chains while adhering to the core pr in ip les of censorship resistance and permission less nes Up until recently atomic swap protocols have mostly relied on complex script support ex clu ding certain types of block chains With advances in cryptography it is now possible to build bridge between almost any two block chains In this work we give an explanation of one such protocol which applies adaptor signatures on Bitcoin to procure atomic swaps between Mon ero and Bitcoin We dive into the cryptographic details discuss its limit ions and give an outlook on our current work where we use adaptor signatures on theM on ero signature scheme Keywords Block chain Atomic Swap Bitcoin Mon ero Adaptor Signatures

BLOCK CHAIN EMPOWERED DATA DRIVEN NETWORKS SURVEY AND OUTLOOK PRE PRINT Xi Li Ze hua Wang Victor Leung Hong Ji lix up edu cn wang ece bc ca leung ieee org ji hong up edu cn Yi ming Liu He li Zhang liu yi ming up edu cn zhang he li up edu cn February ABSTRACT The paths leading to future networks are pointing towards data driven paradigm to better cater to the explosive growth of mobile services as well as the increasing heterogeneity of mobile devices many of which generate and consume large volumes and variety of data These paths are also hampered by sign cant challenges in terms of security privacy services provisioning and network management Block chain which is technology for building distributed ledgers that provide an immutable log of transactions recorded in distributed network has become prominent recently as the underlying technology of crypto currencies and is revolutionizing data storage and processing in computer network systems For future data driven networks DNs block chain is considered as promising solution to enable the secure storage sharing and analytics of data privacy protection for users robust trustworthy network control and decentralized routing and resource management However many important challenges and open issues remain to be addressed before block chain can be deployed widely to enable future DNs In this article we present survey on the existing research works on the application of block chain technologies in computer networks and identify challenges and potential solutions in the applications of block chains in future DNs We identify application scenarios in which future block chain empowered DNs could improve the efc ien cy and security and generally the effectiveness of network services Keywords data driven networks block chain networking technologies block chain empowered data driven networks

Open problems in cross chain protocols Thomas Ei zinger Philipp Ho en isch and Lucas Soriano del Pino CoB loX Pty Ltd Australia first name cob lox tech Abstract Block chain interoperability is prominent research el which aims to build bridges between otherwise isolated block chains With ad vance in cryptography novel protocols are published by academia and applied indie rent applications and products in the industry In theory these innovative protocols provide strong privacy and security guarantees by including formal proofs However pure theoretical work often lacks the perspective of real world applications In this work we describe number of hardly researched problems which developers encounter when building cross chain products Keywords Block chain cross chain bitcoin

Fed Chain Secure Proof of Stake based Framework for Federated block chain Systems Cong Nguyen Dinh Thai Ho ang Die Nguyen Yong Xiao Ho ang An Pham ry Du kiew cz and Nguyen Huy nh Tuo ng Abstract In this paper we propose Fed Chain novel framework for federated block chain systems to enable effective transferring of tokens between different block chain networks Particularly we rst introduce federated block chain system together with across chain transfer protocol to facilitate the secure and decentralized transfer of tokens between chains We then develop novel PoS based consensus mechanism for Fed Chain which can satisfy strict security requirements prevent various block chain spec ic attacks and achieve more desirable performance compared to those of other existing consensus mechanisms Moreover Stack el berg game model is developed to examine and address the problem of centralization in the Fed Chain system Furthermore the game model can enhance the security and performance ofFed Chain By analyzing interactions between the stakeholders and chain operators we can prove the uniqueness of the Stack el berg equilibrium and nd the exact formula for this equilibrium These results are especially important for the stakeholders to determine their best investment strategies and for the chain operators to design the optimal policy to maximize their be nets and security protection for Fed Chain Simulations results then clearly show that the Fed Chain framework can help stakeholders to maximize their prot and the chain operators to design appropriate parameters to enhance Fed Chains security and performance Index Terms Block chain Proof of Stake cross chain transfer side chain multiple block chain and Stack el berg game cid

The Longest Chain Protocol Under Random Delays Surya narayana Sankagiri Shreyas and lu Bruce Haj ek University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign Princeton University February Abstract In the el of distributed consensus and block chains the synchronous communication model assumes that all messages between honest parties are delayed at most by known constant Recent literature establishes that the longest chain block chain protocol is secure under the synchronous model However for ed mining rate the security guarantees degrade with We analyze the performance of the longest chain protocol under the assumption that the communication delays are random independent and identically distributed This communication model allows for distributions with unbounded support and is strict generalization of the synchronous model We provide safety and live ness guarantees with simple explicit bounds on the failure probabilities These bounds hold for in nite horizon executions and decay exponentially with the security parameter In particular we show that the longest chain protocol has good security guarantees when delays are sporadically large and possibly unbounded which is re ect ive of real world network conditions

Statistical privacy preserving message broadcast for peer to peer networks David Mo dinger Jan Hendrik Lorenz Franz Ha uck Institute of Distributed Systems Ulm University Germany Institute of Theoretical Computer Science Ulm University Germany david moe dinger uni ulm de Abstract Privacy concerns are widely discussed in research and society in general For the public infrastructure of financial block chains this discussion encompasses the privacy of the originator of transaction broadcasted on the underlying peer to peer network Adaptive diffusion is an approach to expose an alternative source of message to attackers However this approach assumes an unsuitable attacker model and non realistic network model for current peer to peer networks on the Internet We transform adaptive diffusion into new statistical privacy preserving broadcast protocol for realistic current networks We model class of unstructured peer to peer networks as organically growing graphs and provide models for other classes of such networks We show that the distribution of shortest paths can be modelled using normal distribution We determine statistical estimators for via multivariate models The model behaves logarithmic over the number of nodes and proportional to an inverse exponential over the number of added edges per node These results facilitate the computation of optimal forwarding probabilities during the dissemination phase for maximum privacy with participants having only limited information about network topology

The Discrepancy Attack on Poly shard ed Block chains Nasta ran bad Khoo she me hr Mohammad Ali Madda Ali Sharif University of Technology Sharif University of Technology Email bad nasta ran ee sharif ir Email madda ali sharif edu Abstract harding splitting the miners or validator to form and run several sub chains in parallel is known as one of the main solutions to the cal ability problem of block chains The drawback is that as the number of miners expanding each sub chain becomes small it becomes vulnerable to security attacks To solve this problem framework named as Poly shard has been proposed in which each validator ve ries coded combination of the blocks introduced by different sub chains thus helping to protect the security of all sub chains In this paper we introduce an attack on Poly shard called the discrepancy attack which is the result of malicious nodes controlling few sub chains and dispersing different blocks to different nodes We show that this attack undermines the security of Poly shard and is undetectable in its current setting

SMART PROOFS VIA SMART CONTRACTS SUCCINCT AND INFORMATIVE MATHEMATICAL DERIVATIONS VIA DECENTRALIZED MARKETS SYLVAIN CARR FRANCK GABRIEL CL MEN THO NGLER GUSTAVO LAC ERDA AND GLORIA CAP NO Abstract Modern mathematics is built on the idea that proof should be be transl table into formal proof whose validity is an objective question de cid able by computer In practice however proofs are informal succinct and omit numerous uninteresting details their goal is to share insight among community of agents An agent considers proof valid if they trust that it could in principle be expanded into machine veria ble proof proofs validity can thus become subjective matter possibly leading to debate if agents incentives are not aligned it maybe hard to reach consensus Hence while the concept of valid proof is well de ned in principle the process to establish proofs validity is itself complex multi agent problem In this paper we introduce the SPRIG protocol which allows agents to propose and verify succinct and informative proofs in decentralized fashion the trust is established by agents being able to request more details at steps where they feel there could be problems debates if they arise need to isolate spec ic details of proofs if they persist they must go down to machine level details where they can be settled automatically structure of fees bounties and stakes is set to in centi viz the agents to act in good faith to not publish problematic proofs and to not ask for trivial details We propose game theoretic discussion of SPRIG interactions illustrating how agents with die rent types of information interact leading to ver cation tree with an appropriate level of detail and to the invalidation of problematic proofs and we discuss resilience against various attacks We then provide an in depth treatment of implied model characterize its qui libri and analytically compute the agents level of trust The SPRIG protocol is designed so that it can run fully autonomously as smart contract on de central zed block chain platform without need for central trusted institution This allows agents to participate anonymously in the ver cation debate being in centi viz ed to contribute with their information The smart contract mediates all the interactions between the agents and settles debates on the validity of proofs and guarantees that bounties and stakes are paid as specie by the protocol SPRIG also allows for number of other applications in particular the issuance of bounties for solving open problems and the creation of derivatives markets enabling agents to inject more information pertaining to mathematical proofs

Vote Delegation and Misbehavior Hans Gers bach kaki Mam age ish vili Man vi Schneider CER ETH and EPR CER ETH CER ETH Zurich bergstra sse Zurich bergstra sse Zurich bergstra sse Zurich Switzerland Zurich Switzerland Zurich Switzerland gers bach et hz ch mam age ish vili et hz ch man vi schneider et hz ch Last updated May Abstract We study vote delegation with well behaving and misbehaving agents and compare it with conventional voting Typical examples for vote delegation are validation or governance tasks on block chains There is majority of well behaving agents but they may abstain or delegate their vote to other agents since voting is costly Misbehaving agents always vote We compare conventional voting allowing for abstention with vote delegation Preferences of voters are private information and positive outcome is achieved if well behaving agents win We illustrate that vote delegation leads to quite die rent outcomes than conventional voting with abstention In particular we obtain three insights First if the number of misbehaving voters denoted by is high both voting methods fail to deliver positive outcome Second if takes an intermediate value conventional voting delivers positive outcome while vote delegation fails with probability one Third if is low delegation delivers positive outcome with higher probability than conventional voting Finally our results characterize worst case outcomes that can happen in liquid democracy

decentralized FAIR platform to facilitate data sharing in the life sciences Pavel Va zquez Ka yoko Shoji Steffen Novi Stefan Krauss and Simon Rayner Hybrid Technology Hub Centre of Excellence Institute of Basic Medical Sciences University of Oslo Oslo Norway Department of Informatics Faculty of Mathematics and Natural Sciences University of Oslo Oslo Norway Department of Medical Genetics Oslo University Hospital and University of Oslo Oslo Norway Corresponding author Dictionary GADD Global Accessible Distribution Data Sharing Machine physical hardware that can execute commands Node machine in network Cluster group of machines Organization group of nodes sharing domain name Domain network address Channel permission ed network where organizations communicate Consortium group of organizations that share common channel Meta data data and metadata Project data and metadata dupl Abstract The Hybrid Technology Hub and many other research centers work in cross functional teams whose work flow is not necessarily linear and where in many cases technology advances are done through parallel work The lack of proper tools and platforms for collaborative environment can create time lags in coordination and limited sharing of research findings To solve this we have developed simple user friendly platform built for academic and scientific research collaboration To ensure FAIRness compliance the platform consists of metadata quality control based on block chain technologies The data is stored separately in distributed object storage that functions as cloud The platform also implements version control system it provides history track of the project along with the possibility of reviewing the projects development This platform aims to be standardized tool within the Hybrid Technology Hub to ease collaboration speed research work flow and improve research quality

Australia Munster Technological University Rossa Avenue Bishops town Cork Ireland Swinburne University of Technology Hawthorn VIC Australia Abstract Permission ed block chain such as Hyper ledger fabric enables secure supply chain model in Industrial Internet of Things II oT through multichannel and private data collection mechanisms Sharing of Industrial data including private data exchange at every stage be tween supply chain partners helps to improve product quality enable future forecast and enhance management activities However the ex is ting data sharing and querying mechanism in Hyper ledger fabric is not suitable for supply chain environment in II oT because the queries are evaluated on actual data stored on ledger which consists of sens ti ve information such as business secrets and special discounts oe red to retailers and individuals To solve this problem we propose die ent al privacy based permission ed block chain using Hyper ledger fabric to enable private data sharing in supply chain in II oT DH II oT We integrate dieren ti al privacy into the chain code smart contract of Hy per ledger fabric to achieve privacy preservation As result the query response consists of perturbed data which protects the sensitive in form tion in the ledger The proposed work DH II oT is evaluated by imu latin permission ed block chain using Hyper ledger fabric We compare our dieren ti al privacy integrated chain code of Hyper ledger fabric with the default chain code setting of Hyper ledger fabric for supply chain sce na rio The results con rm that the proposed work maintains of accuracy in the shared data while guarantees the protection of sensitive ledgers data Keywords II oT Hyper ledger fabric block chain Privacy preservation Dieren ti al privacy Supply chain Industrial data sharing

business analysis of the recorded operations challenging Existing block chain visualization and analytics tools such as block explorers tend to rely on this low level data and complex interfacing to Dynamical Analysis of the IP there um Fee Market Stefano Leonardo Barn be Mon not Daniel Rei js bergen Strat is koul ak is and Georgios Pili our as Singapore University of Technology and Design stefano leonardo daniel rei js bergen ef st ratios georgios utd edu sg there um Foundation barn be mon not there um org Abstract Participation in permission less block chains results in competition over system resources which needs to be controlled with fees there um current fee mechanism is implemented via rst price auction that results in unpredictable fees as well as other in ec ien cie IP is recent improved proposal that introduces number of innovative features such as dynamically adaptive base fee that is burnt instead of being paid to the miners Despite intense interest in understanding its properties several basic questions such as whether and under what conditions does this protocol self stabilize have remained elusive thus far We perform thorough analysis of the resulting fee market dynamic mechanism via combination of tools from game theory as well as dynamical systems West art by providing bounds on the step size of the base fee update rule that su ce for global convergence to equilibrium via Lyapunov arguments In the negative direction we show that for larger step sizes instability and even formal Li Yorke chaos are possible under wide range of settings We complement these topological results with quantitative bounds on the possible range of base fees We conclude our analysis with thorough experimental case study that corroborates our theoretical dings

version of this paper will appear in the IEEE International Conference on Block chain and Crypto currency IEEE CBC This is full version FASTEN FAIR AND SECURE DISTRIBUTED VOTING USING SMART CONTRACTS Sankar shan Dam le and Su it Gujar Machine Learning Lab International Institute of Information Technology III TH Hyderabad India sankar shan dam le research ii it ac in su it gujar ii it ac in Mo in Hussain Mot The HongKong University of Science and Technology HongKong mh mot se ust hk February ABSTRACT Electing democratic representatives via voting has been common mechanism since the th century However these mechanisms raise concerns about fairness privacy vote concealment fair calculations of tally and proxies voting on their behalf for the voters Ballot voting and in recent times electronic voting via electronic voting machines VMs improves fairness by relying on centralized trust Homo orphic encryption based voting protocols also assure fairness but cannot scale to large scale elections such as presidential elections In this paper we leverage the block chain technology of distributing trust to propose smart contract based protocol namely FASTEN There are many existing protocols for voting using smart contracts We observe that these either are not scalable or leak the vote tally during the voting stage do not provide vote concealment In contrast we show that FASTEN preserves voters privacy ensures vote concealment immutability and avoids double voting We prove that the probability of privacy breaches is negligibly small Further our cost analysis of executing FASTEN over there um is comparable to most of the existing cost of elections

of Block chained Federated Learning for Threat Defense Konstantino De mer tz is Laboratory of Complex Systems Department of Physics Faculty of Sciences International Hellenic University Kavala Campus St Lou as Greece kde mer tz is tei emt gr Faculty of Mathematics Programming and General Courses Department of Civil Engineering School of Engineering Democritus University of Thrace Kim meri Xanthi Greece kde mer tz men du th gr Abstract Given the increasing complexity of threats in smart cities the changing environment and the weakness of traditional security systems which in most cases fail to detect serious threats such as zero day attacks the need for alternative more active and more effective security methods keeps increasing Such approaches are the adoption of intelligent solutions to prevent detect and deal with threats or anomalies under the conditions and the operating parameters of the infrastructure in question Intelligent systems are capable of displaying logical empirical and non human decision making since they are trained appropriately by historical data representative of the problem they are trying to solve In most cases it is either not possible or it is inappropriate to centrally store all smart cities data Thus we should perform real time knowledge mining and we should obtain subset of data flow containing small but recent percentage of observations This fact raises serious objections to the accuracy and reliability of the employed intelligent system class if ers who have been tame over time and they become incapable of detecting serious threats This research paper introduces the development of an intelligent Threat Defense system employing Block chain Federated Learning which seeks to fully upgrade the way passive intelligent systems operate aiming at implementing an Advanced Adaptive Cooperative Learning CL mechanism for smart cities networks The CL is based on the most advanced methods of computational intelligence while ensuring privacy and anonymity for participants and stakeholders The proposed framework combines Federated Learning for the distributed and continuously validated learning of the tracing algorithms Learning is achieved through encrypted smart contracts within the block chain technology for unambiguous validation and control of the process The aim of the proposed Framework is to intelligently classify smart cities networks traffic derived from Industrial oT II oT by Deep Content Inspection DCI methods in order to identify anomalies that are usually due to Advanced Persistent Threat APT attacks Keywords Smart City Federated Learning II oT Big Data Analytics Cyber Threat Defense Advanced Persistent Threat Deep Content Inspection SCAD

Brunswick Fredericton Canada Abstract harding is the prevalent approach to breaking the tri lemma of simultaneously achieving decentralization security and cal ability in traditional block chain dynamically partitioning nodes in block chain system into subsets shards that perform storage communication and computation tasks without ne grained synchronization with each other Despite much recent research on harding block chains much remains to be explored in the design space of these systems Towards that aim we conduct systematic analysis of existing harding block chain systems and derive conceptual decomposition of their architecture into functional components and the underlying assumptions about system models and attackers they are built on The functional com po ents den tied are node selection epoch randomness node assignment intra shard consensus cross shard transaction processing shard recon gu ration and motivation mechanism We describe interfaces function ali ty and properties of each component and show how they compose into harding block chain system For each component we systematically review existing approaches identify potential and open problems and propose future research directions We focus on potential security attacks and performance problems including system throughput and latency concerns such as con rm ation delays We believe our modular architectural decomposition and in depth analysis of each component based on comprehensive literature study provides systematic basis for conceptualizing state of the art harding block chain systems proving or improving security and performance properties of components and developing new harding block chain system designs Keywords harding Block chain Byzantine Fault Tolerance cal ability ETS Trusted Block chain based Emissions Trading System for Vehicle to Vehicle Networks Lam Duc Nguyen mari Lewis Israel Ley va Mayor ga Amelia Regan and Petar Pop ovsk Department of Electronic Systems Aalborg University Denmark Department of Computer Science University of California Irvine United States mail nd ilm petar es aau dk amar il regan uci edu Abstract Urban areas are negatively impacted by Carbon Dioxide CO and Nitrogen Oxide NO emissions In order to achieve cost effective reduction of greenhouse gas emissions and to combat climate change the European Union EU introduced an Emissions Trading System ETS where organizations can buy or receive emission allowances as needed The current ETS is centralized one consisting of set of complex rules It is currently administered at the organizational level and is used for ed point sources of pollution such as factories power plants and rene ries However the current ETS cannot efc ent ly cope with vehicle mobility even though vehicles are one of the primary sources of CO and NO emissions In this study we propose new distributed Block chain based emissions allowance trading system called ETS This system enables transparent and trustworthy data exchange as well as trading of allowances among vehicles relying on vehicle to vehicle communication In addition we introduce an economic incentive based mechanism that appeals to individual drivers and leads them to modify their driving behavior in order to reduce emissions The efc ien cy of the proposed system is studied through extensive simulations showing how increased vehicle connectivity can lead to reduction of the emissions generated from those vehicles We demonstrate that our method can be used for full life cycle monitoring and fuel economy reporting This leads us to conjecture that the proposed system could lead to important behavioural changes among the drivers Index Terms Distributed Ledger Technology Block chain Data Trading Emission Trading EU ETS

LEVERAGED TRADING ON BLOCK CHAIN TECHNOLOGY Research in Progress Johannes Rude Jensen Victor von Wachter University of Copenhagen University of Copenhagen To roX Labs victor von wachter di ku dk johannes rude jensen gmail com Omri Ross University of Copenhagen To roX Labs omri di ku dk Abstract We document an ongoing research process towards the implementation and integration of digital ar te fact executing the lifecycle of leveraged trade with permission less block chain technology By em plo ying core functions of the Dai Stable coin system deployed on the there um block chain we produce the equivalent exposure of leveraged position while deterministic ally automating the monitoring and liquidation processes We demonstrate the implementation and early integration of the artefact into hardened exchange environment through micro service utilizing standardized API calls The early re sul ts presented in this paper were produced in collaboration with team of stakeholders at hosting organization multi national online brokerage and crypto currency exchange We utilize the design sci en ce research methodology SR guiding the design development and evaluation of the artefact Our findings indicate that while it is feasible to implement the lifecycle of leveraged trade on the block chain the integration of the artefact into traditional exchange environment involves multiple com pro mises and drawback Generalizing the tentative findings presented in this paper we introduce three propositions on the implementation integration and implications of executing key business processes with permission less block chain technologies By conducting computational design science research we contribute to the information systems discourse on the applied utility of permission less block chain tech no logie in finance and beyond Keywords Block chain Technology Distributed Ledger Technology Leveraged Trading Design Sci en ce Research Decentralized Finance DeF

Deciphering Bitcoin Block chain Data by Cohort Analysis Yul in Liu Lu yao Zhang and Yin hong Zhao ochs ler Finance As soci esS Gotthard stra sse Zug Switzerland Duke Kun shan University Kun shan Jiangsu China Duke University Durham NC United States Corresponds to lz duke edu These authors contributed equally to this work ABSTRACT Bitcoin is peer to peer electronic payment system that popularized rapidly in recent years Usually we need to query the complete history of Bitcoin block chain data to acquire variables with economic meaning This becomes increasingly if cult now with over billion historical transactions on the Bitcoin block chain It is thus important to query Bitcoin transaction data in away that is more efc ent and provides economic insights We apply cohort analysis that interprets Bitcoin block chain data using methods developed for population data in social science Spec ic ally we query and process the Bitcoin transaction input and output data within each daily cohort which enables us to create datasets and visualization for some key indicators of Bitcoin transactions including the daily lifespan distributions of spent transaction output ST XO and the daily age distributions of the accumulated un spent transaction output UT XO We provide computationally feasible approach to characterize Bitcoin transactions which paves the way for the future economic studies of Bitcoin Background and Summary Bitcoin BTC is peer to peer electronic payment system that popularized rapidly in recent years Bitcoin relies on recording the Un spent Transaction Outputs UT XO to efc ent ly verify newly generated transactions thus eliminating the needs of intermediaries like banks and reducing transaction costs AUT XO is generated either as block rewards or the output of transaction The timestamp is recorded when aUT XO is generated AUT XO is spent and converted into Spent Transaction Output ST XO when it is used as the input of transaction The timestamp is again recorded when nUT XO is spent Each UT XO can only be spent once Such unique feature allows us to calculate the age of each UT XO and the lifespan of each ST XO as population data Noticing the unique structure of the Bitcoin block chain data we apply cohort analysis developed for population data to analyze it To analog ize with the population data we say aUT XO is born when it is generated as block rewards or the output of transaction and we say aUT XO is dead when it is spent as the input of another transaction In this way all UT XO generated on the same day form daily birth cohort while all UT XO spent on the same day form daily death cohort We de ne the age of aUT XO to be the difference between now the date on which we are working on and the time when it was born and the lifespan of an ST XO to be the difference between the time when it was dead and the time when it was born Thus all UT XO within an age range for manage cohort and all ST XO within lifespan range belong to lifespan cohort With this framework we naturally replicate in Bitcoin block chain data the trinity of birth death and age cohorts from population cohort analysis Usually we need to query the complete history of Bitcoin block chain data to acquire variables of economic meaning With over billion historical transactions on the Bitcoin block chain it becomes increasingly if cult and computation intensive now It is thus important to query Bitcoin transaction data in away that is more efc ent and provides economic insights Cohort analysis provides new perspective from which we can analyze data within each cohort separately before integrating them into time series with economic meanings We query and process Bitcoin transaction input and output data within each daily cohort With this we successfully create datasets and visualization for some key indicators of bitcoin transactions including the daily lifespan distributions of ST XO in percentage Figure and the daily age distributions of the accumulated UT XO in BTC Figure The visualization can be used to study the functions of bitcoin as currency The three functions of currency include store of value unit of account and medium of exchange For example Figure shows the number of bitcoins in UT XO bitcoins that have not been spent by age distribution By the end of around million bitcoins have not been transacted for more than years There are also million million and million bitcoins that remained inactive in the past years years and years

Note on Privacy in Constant Function Market Makers Guillermo Anger is Alex Evans Ta run Chitra anger is stanford edu alex placeholder vc ta run gauntlet network February Abstract Constant function market makers CFM Ms such as Uni swap Balancer Curve and Stable among many others make up some of the largest decentralized exchanges on there um and other block chains Because all transactions are public in current im ple ment at ions natural next question is if there exist similar decentralized exchanges which are privacy preserving if transactions quantities are hidden from the public view then an adversary cannot correctly reconstruct the traded quantities from other public information In this note we show that privacy is impossible with the usual implementations of CFM Ms under most reasonable models of an adversary and provide some mitigating strategies

Spam Prevention Using NARKs for Anonymous Peer to Peer Content Sharing Systems Alberto In sel in November Abstract Decentralized un permission ed peer to peer networks are inherently vulnerable to spam when they allow arbitrary participants to submit con tent to common public index or registry preventing this is di cult due to the absence of central arbitrator who can act as gate keeper For this reason indexing of new content even in otherwise decentralized networks Bittorrent with HT PFS has generally been left to centralized services such as torrent sites Decentralized methods for spam prevention such as Web of Trust already exist but they require submitters to assume pseudonym us identities and establish trust overtime In this paper we present method of spam prevention that works under the assumption that the participants are fully anonymous and do not want die rent submissions of their to be linked to each other By spam we do not spec ic ally mean unsolicited advertising rather it is the practice of adding large amount of content in short time saturating the capacity of the network and causing denial of service to peers The purpose of our solution is to prevent users from saturating the system and can be described as rate limiting The system should be censorship resistant it should not be possible for submissions to be excluded because of the content itself or for users to be excluded based on what they submit We rst discuss solution based on single centralized rate limit er that is censorship resistant and anonymous then we extend this to fully decentralized block chain based system and present methods to make it economical and scalable

promising technology to make network sex ble and agile NF decreases operators OP EX and CAPE by decoupling the physical hardware from the functions they perform In NF users service request can be viewed as service function chain FC consisting of several virtual network functions NFs which are connected through virtual links Resource allocation in NF Vis done through centralized authority called NF Orchestrator NF VO This centralized authority suffers from some drawbacks such as single point of failure and security Block chain BC technology is able to address these problems by decentralizing resource allocation The drawbacks of NF VO in NF architecture and the exceptional BC characteristics to address these problems motivate us to focus on NF resource allocation to users FCs without the need for an NF VO To this end we assume there are two types of users users who sendS FC requests FC requesting users and users who perform mining process miner users For FC requesting Block chain in Cyber defence Technology Review from Swiss Perspective Luca Gamba zz Patrick Schaller Alain Mer oud Vincent Lenders Cyber Defence Campus arma suisse Science and Technology Switzerland Abstract Since the advent of bitcoin in the concept of block chain has widely spread Besides crypto currencies and trading activities there is wide range of potential application areas where block chains are providing the main building block for secure solutions From technical point of view block chain involves set of cryptographic primitives to provide data structure with security and trust properties However block chain is not golden bullet It may be well suited for some problems but often an inappropriate data structure for many applications In this paper we review the high level concept of block chain and present possible applications in the military field Our review is targeted to readers with little prior domain knowledge as support to decide where it makes sense to use block chain and where block chain might not be the right tool at hand March Corresponding author luca gamba zz ar admin ch Disclaimer Opinions expressed in this report are solely our own and do not express the views or opinions of our employer the Swiss government

The Effect of Network Topology on Credit Network Throughput VI BHA LAKSHMI SIVA RAMAN Massachusetts Institute of Technology USA WEI ZHAO TANG Carnegie Mellon University USA HAILE SH HBO JJ AVEN KATA KRISHNA The Ohio State University USA GIULIA ANTI Carnegie Mellon University USA MOHAMMAD LIZA DEH Massachusetts Institute of Technology USA Credit networks rely on decentralized pairwise trust relationships channels to exchange money or goods Credit networks arise naturally in many financial systems including the recent construct of payment channel networks in block chain systems An important performance metric for these networks is their transaction throughput However predicting the throughput of credit network is nontrivial Unlike traditional com muni cation channels credit channels can become imbalanced they are unable to support more transactions in given direction once the credit limit has been reached This potential for imbalance creates complex dependency between networks throughput and its topology path choices and the credit balances state one very channel Even worse certain combinations of these factors can lead the credit network to dead locked states where no transactions can make progress In this paper we study the relationship between the throughput of credit network and its topology and credit state We show that the presence of deadlocks completely characterizes networks throughput sensitivity to different credit states Although we show that identifying deadlocks in an arbitrary topology is NP hard we propose peeling algorithm inspired by decoding algorithms for erasure codes that upper bounds the severity of the deadlock We use the peeling algorithm as tool to compare the performance of different topologies as well as to aid in the synthesis of topologies robust to deadlocks

Lightweight Selective Disclosure for Veria ble Documents on Block chain Kenji Saito toki Watanabe Abstract To achieve lightweight selective disclosure for protecting privacy of document holders we propose an XML format for documents that can hide arbitrary elements using cryptographic hash function and salts which allows to be partially digitally signed and cie ntl ve ried as well as JSON format that can be converted to such XML The documents can be cie ntl proven to exist by representing multiple such structures as Mer kle tree and storing its root in block chain We show that our proposal has advantages over known methods that represent the document itself as Mer kle tree and partially hide it Keywords Selective disclosure Content extraction signature Privacy Proof of existence Block chain

Privacy Preserving Infection Exposure Not cation without Trust in Third Parties Kenji Saito Mitsuru Iwa mura Abstract In response to the OVID pandemic Bluetooth based contact tracing has been deployed in many countries with the help of the de vel oper of smartphone operating systems that provide APIs for privacy preserving exposure not cation However it has been assumed by the design that the OS developers smartphone vendors or governments will not violate peoples privacy We propose privacy preserving exposure not cation under situ at ions where none of the middle entities can be trusted We believe that it can be achieved with small changes to the existing mechanism random numbers are generated on the application side instead of the OS and the positive test results are reported to public ledger block chain rather than to government server with endorsements from the medical institutes with blind signatures We also discuss how to in centi viz the peer to peer maintenance of the public ledger if it should be newly built We show that the level of ver ability is much higher with our pro posed design if consumer group were to verify the privacy protections of the deployed systems We believe that this will allow for safer contact tracing and con tribute to healthier lifestyles for citizens who may want to or have to go out under pandemic situations Keywords Contact tracing Exposure not cation Privacy Blind signature Block chain

BLOWN Block chain Protocol for Single Hop Wireless Networks under Adversarial IN Ming hui Xu Student Member IEEE Feng Zhao Member IEEE Yi fei Zo Chun chi Liu Xi zhen Cheng Fellow IEEE Falk Dress ler Fellow IEEE Abstract Known as distributed ledger technology LT block chain has attracted much attention due to its properties such as decentralization security immutability and transparency and its potential of servicing as an infrastructure for various applications Block chain can empower wireless networks with identity management data integrity access control and high level security However previous studies on block chain enabled wireless networks mostly focus on proposing architectures or building systems with popular block chain protocols Nevertheless such existing protocols have obvious shortcomings when adopted in wireless networks where nodes have limited physical resources fall short of well established reliable channels variable bandwidth impacted by environments or jamming attacks In this paper we propose novel consensus protocol named Proof of Channel Po leveraging the natural properties of wireless communications and BLOWN protocol BLOck chain protocol for Wireless Networks for wireless networks under an adversarial IN model We formalize BLOWN with the universal composition framework and prove its security properties namely persistence and live ness as well as its strengths in countering against adversarial jamming double spending and Sybil attacks which are also demonstrated by extensive simulation studies Index Terms Block chain Proof of Channel wireless networks adversarial IN jamming Sybil attacks cid

BL OFF Block chain based Forensic Model in oT Promise Ag bed anu Dong hua University Shanghai CN email ricardo promise gmail com https or cid org Anca Delia Jur cut University College Dublin Ireland email anca jur cut ucd ie https or cid org ABSTRACT In this era of explosive growth in technology the internet of things oT has become the game changer when we consider technologies like smart homes and cities smart energy security and surveillance and healthcare The numerous benefits provided by oT have become attractive technologies for users and cyber criminals Cyber criminals of today have the tools and the technology to deploy millions of sophisticated attacks These attacks need to be investigated this is where digital forensics comes into play However it is not easy to conduct forensic investigation in oT systems because of the heterogeneous nature of the oT environment Additionally forensic investigators mostly rely on evidence from service providers situation that can lead to evidence contamination To solve this problem the authors proposed block chain based oT forensic model that prevents the admissibility of tampered logs into evidence

Understanding Smart Contracts Hype or Hope Elizaveta Zinovy eva Raphael Re ule Block chain Research Center Humboldt Universitat zu Berlin Germany International Research Training Group Humboldt Universitat zu Berlin Germany elizaveta zinovy eva at wi wi hu berlin de irt wi wi at wi wi hu berlin de Wolfgang Karl Hard le Block chain Research Center Humboldt Universitat zu Berlin Germany Wang Yanan Institute for Studies in Economics Xiamen University China Sim Kee Boon Institute for Financial Economics Singapore Management University Singapore Faculty of Mathematics and Physics Charles University Czech Republic National Chia Tung University Taiwan hae rd le at wi wi hu berlin de March Abstract Smart Contracts are commonly considered to be an important component or even key to many business solutions in an immense variety of sectors and promises to securely increase their individual ec ien cy in an ever more digitized environment Introduced in the early the technology has gained lot of attention with its application to block chain technology to an extent that can be considered ver it ble hype Ree ting the growing institutional interest this intertwined exploratory study between statistics information technology and law contrasts these idealistic stories with the data reality and provides mandatory step of understanding the matter before any further relevant applications are discussed as being factually able to replace traditional constructions Besides fundamental aw and app lica tion di cul ties of currently employed Smart Contracts the technological drive and enthusiasm backing it may however serve as jump board for future develop ment thrusting well in the presently unshakeable traditional structures EL Classic ation Keywords Crypto currency Smart Contract there um CRI

Learning in Markets Greed Leads to Chaos but Following the Price is Right Yun Kuen Cheung Stefano Leonardo and Georgios Pili our as Royal Holloway University of London yun kuen cheung rh ul ac uk Singapore University of Technology and Design stefano leonardo georgios utd edu sg Abstract We study learning dynamics in distributed production economies such as block chain mining peer to peer le sharing and crowd sourcing These economies can be modelled as multi product Cour not competitions or all pay auctions Tul lock contests when individual rms have market power or as Fisher markets with quasi linear utilities when every rm has negligible in en ce on market outcomes In the former case we provide formal proof that Gradient Ascent GA can beLi Yorke chaotic for step size as small as where is the number of rms In stark contrast for the Fisher market case we derive Proportional Response PR protocol that converges to market equilibrium The positive results on the convergence of the PR dynamics are obtained in full generality in the sense that they hold for Fisher markets with any quasi linear utility functions Conversely the chaos results for the GA dynamics are established even in the simplest possible setting of two rms and one good and they hold for wide range of price functions with die rent demand elastic ties Our dings suggest that by considering multi agent interactions from market rather than game theoretic perspective we can formally derive natural learning protocols which are stable and converge to eec ti ve outcomes rather than being chaotic

Block chain based Digital Twins Research Trends Issues and Future Challenges SABAH SU HAIL Kyung Hee University South Korea RAS HEED HUSSAIN In no polis University Russia RAJA JUR DAK Queensland University of Technology Australia ALMA OR ACE VIC In no polis University Russia KHALED SALAH Khalifa University UAE CHOON SEON HONG Kyung Hee University South Korea Industrial processes rely on sensory data for decision making processes risk assessment and performance evaluation Extracting actionable insights from the collected data calls for an infrastructure that can ensure the dissemination of trustworthy data For the physical data to be trustworthy it needs to be cross validated through multiple sensor sources with overlapping fields of view Cross validated data can then be stored on block chain to maintain its integrity and trustworthiness Once trustworthy data is recorded on the block chain product lifecycle events can be fed into data driven systems for process monitoring diagnostics and optimized control In this regard Digital Twins DT can be leveraged in industry to draw intelligent conclusions from data by identifying the faults and recommending precautionary measures ahead of critical events Empowering DT with block chain in industrial use cases targets key challenges of disparate data repositories untrustworthy data dissemination and the need for predictive maintenance In this survey while highlighting the key benefits of using block chain based DT we present comprehensive review of the state of the art research results for block chain based DT Based on the current research trends we discuss in detail framework for trustworthy block chain based DT Furthermore we also discuss current and future research and deployment challenges along with essential measures that must betaken by the block chain based DT CCS Concepts General and reference Surveys and overviews Security and privacy Distributed systems security HaPPY Mine Designing Mining Reward Function Lucian na Ki er and Raj mohan Raja raman Northeastern University Boston MA USA lk if fer raj ccs neu edu Abstract In crypto currencies the block reward is meant to serve as the incentive mechanism for miners to commit resources to create blocks and in eec secure the system Existing systems primarily divide the reward in proportion to expended resources and follow one of two static models for total block reward axed reward for each block there um or ii one where the block reward halves every set number of blocks the Bitcoin model of halving roughly every years but otherwise remains ed between halving In recent work game theoretic anal ys is of the static model under asymmetric miner costs showed that an equilibrium always exists and is unique Their analysis also reveals how asymmetric costs can lead to large scale centralization in block chain mining phenomenon that has been observed in Bitcoin and there um and highlighted by other studies including In this work we introduce novel family of mining reward functions HaPPY Mine HAsh Pegged Proportional Yield which peg the value of the reward to the hash rate of the system decreasing the reward as the hash rate increases HaPPY Mine distributes rewards in proportion to ex pended hash rate and inherits the safety properties of the generalized proportional reward function established in We study HaPPY Mine under heterogeneous miner cost model and show that an equilibrium always exists with unique set of miner participants and unique to tal hash rate Sign cant ly we prove that HaPPY Mine equilibrium is more decentralized than the static model equilibrium under set of met ric including number of mining participants and hash rate distribution Finally we show that any HaPPY Mine equilibrium is also safe against collusion and sybil attacks and explore how the market value of the currency ect the equilibrium

Security of Healthcare Data Using Block chains Survey May ank Pandey Rac hit Agar wal San deep Shukla Nish chal Ver ma Department of Electrical Engineering Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur India Department of SE Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur India pandey nish chal it ac in ra chi tag san deeps se it ac in Corresponding author Abstract The advancement in the healthcare sector is entering into new era in the form of Health The integration of innovative technologies like Cyber Physical Systems CP Big Data Cloud Computing Machine Learning and Block chain with Healthcare services has led to improved performance and efficiency through data based learning and interconnection of systems On the other hand it has also increased complexities and has brought its own share of vulnerabilities due to the heavy influx sharing and storage of healthcare data The protection of the same from cyber attacks along with privacy preservation through authenticated access is one of the significant challenges for the healthcare sector For this purpose the use of block chain based networks can lead to considerable reduction in the vulnerabilities of the healthcare systems and secure their data This chapter explores block chain's role in strengthening healthcare data security by answering the questions related to what data use when we need why we need who needs and how state of the art techniques use block chains to secure healthcare data As case study we also explore and analyze the state of the art implementations for block chain in healthcare data security for the OVID pandemic In order to provide path to future research directions we identify and discuss the technical limitations and regulatory challenges associated with block chain based healthcare data security implementation Keywords Block chain Healthcare Cyber Security Authentication Decentralized networks Data security Data integrity Trusted data sharing

An in De lega table Crypto currency System Full Version Ru jia Li Qin Wang in rui Zhang Qi Wang David Gal indo and Yang Xiang Southern University of Science and Technology Shenzhen Guangdong China University of Birmingham Edgbaston TT Birmingham United Kingdom Swinburne University of Technology Melbourne VIC Australia CSIRO Data Sydney NSW Australia Nankai University Tianjin China xl ham ac uk qin wang win edu au wang qi sus tech edu cn Abstract Block chain based crypto currencies facilitating the convenience of payment by providing decentralized online solution have not been widely adopted so far due to slow con rm ation of transactions in delegation oe rsa nec ent way to exchange coins However in such an approach the coins that have been delegated confront the risk of being spent twice since the de le gators behaviour cannot be restricted easily on account of the absence of eec ti ve supervision Even if third party can be regarded as judge between the de leg at or and delegate to secure transactions she still faces the threat of being compromised or providing misleading assure Moreover the approach equipped with third party contradicts the real intention of decentralized crypto currency systems In this paper we propose De lega Coin an in de lega table crypto currency system to mitigate such an issue We exploit trusted execution environments TEEs as decentralized virtual agents to prevent malicious delegation In De lega Coin an owner can delegate his coins through in transactions without interacting with the block chain network formal model and analysis prototype implementation and further evaluation demonstrate that our scheme is provably secure and practically feasible Keywords Crypto currency Payment Trusted Execution Environments TEEs in Delegation preliminary version was accepted by IEEE CBC poster version was shown in NDS These authors contributed equally to the work Corresponding author

TRUSTED ANONYMOUS DATA EXCHANGE THREAT SHARING USING BLOCK CHAIN TECHNOLOGY PRE PRINT Yair All ouch Nac hike Tapas IBM Cyber Security Center of Excellence Department of Engineering Beer Sheva Israel Universit degli Studi di Messina yair il ibm com Messina Italy tapas uni me it Francesco Longo Asaf Shab tai Department of Engineering Department of Software and Information Universit degli Studi di Messina Systems Engineering Messina Italy Ben Gurion University of the Negev longo uni me it Beer Sheva Israel shab tai gu ac il Yar on Wolfs thal IBM Cyber Security Center of Excellence Beer Sheva Israel wolf stal il ibm com March ABSTRACT Cyber attacks are becoming more frequent and sophisticated introducing sign cant challenges for organizations to protect their systems and data from threat actors Today threat actors are highly motivated persistent and well founded and operate in coordinated manner to commit diversity of attacks using various sophisticated tactics techniques and procedures Given the risks these threats present it has become clear that organizations need to collaborate and share cyber threat information TI and use it to improve their security posture In this paper we present TRADE TRusted Anonymous Data Exchange collaborative distributed trusted and an ony miz ed TI sharing platform based on block chain technology TRADE uses block chain based access control framework designed to provide essential features and requirements to in centi viz and encourage organizations to share threat intelligence information In TRADE organizations can fully control their data by de ning sharing policies enforced by smart contracts used to control and manage TI sharing in the network TRADE allows organizations to preserve their anonymity while keeping organizations fully accountable for their action in the network Finally TRADE can be easily integrated within existing threat intelligence exchange protocols such as trusted automated exchange of intelligence information TAXI and OpenD XL there by allowing fast and smooth technology adaptation Keywords Cyber threat intelligence Threat intelligence exchange protocols Block chain Smart contracts

WEB MINING FOR ESTIMATING REGULATORY BLOCK CHAIN READINESS Elias Iosif Kli to Christo dou lou Department of Digital Innovation School of Business Department of Digital Innovation School of Business Institute For the Future IFF Institute For the Future IFF University of Nicosia University of Nicosia Cyprus Cyprus iosif uni ac cy christo dou lou kl uni ac cy Andreas la chos Department of Digital Innovation School of Business University of Nicosia Cyprus la chos uni ac cy March ABSTRACT The regulatory framework of crypto currencies and in general block chain tokens is of paramount importance This framework drives nearly all key decisions in the respective business areas In this work computational model is proposed for quantitatively estimating the regulatory stance of countries with respect to crypto currencies This is conducted via web mining utilizing web search engines The proposed model is experimentally validated In addition unsupervised learning clu te ring is applied for better analyzing the automatically derived estimations Overall very good performance is achieved by the proposed algorithmic approach Keywords Block chain Regulation Block chain Business Intelligence Web Mining

oT Data Quality Issues and Potential Solutions Literature Review Tah Mansour Mohammad Reza Sade hi Mogh adam Fate meh Mon shi za deh had are rava san School of Science Engineering and Environment University of Salford Greater Manchester UK Department of Production and Operation Management Faculty of Management University of Tehran Tehran Iran Department of Corporate Economy Faculty of Economics and Administration Masaryk University Brno Czech Republic Abstract The Internet of Things oT is paradigm that connects everyday items to the Internet In the recent decade the oTs spreading popularity is promising opportunity for people and industries oT utilizes in wide range of respects such as agriculture healthcare smart cities and manufacturing sectors oT data quality is crucial in oT real life applications oT data quality dimensions and issues should be considered because we require data to make accurate and timely decisions produce commodities and gain insights about events people and the environment It is essential to point out that we cannot reach valuable results by using poor quality data This paper aims to develop new category for oT data quality Hence we examine existing oT data quality dimensions and oT data quality issues in general and specific domains and oT data quality dimensions categories It is worth considering that categories in the context of oT are not many We developed new category in which oT data quality dimensions and issues are separated Concerning this category we can get familiar with related dimensions and issues in each category To enhance data quality dimensions and minimize data quality issues we suggest potential solutions using Block chain to overcome oT's security issues Keyword Data quality Internet of Things oT oT Data quality dimensions

On Chain Auctions with Deposits JAN CHRISTOPH SCHLEGEL City University of London United Kingdom AK AKIMA MAGE ISH VILI ETH Zurich Switzerland Second price auctions with deposits are frequently used in block chain environments An auction takes place on chain bidders deposit an amount that fully covers their bid but possibly exceeds it in smart contract The deposit is used as insurance against bidders not honoring their bid if they win The deposit but not the bid is publicly observed during the bidding phase of the auction The visibility of deposits can fundamentally change the strategic structure of the auction if bidding happens sequentially Bidding is costly since deposit are costly to make Thus deposits can be used as costly signal for high valuation This is the source of multiple inefficiencies To engage in costly signalling bidder who bids first and has high valuation will generally over deposit in equilibrium deposit more than he will bid If high valuations are likely there can moreover been try deterrence through high deposits bidder who bids first can deter subsequent bidders from entering the auction Pooling can happen in equilibrium where bidders of different valuations deposit the same amount The auction fails to allocate the item to the bidder with the highest valuation ACM Reference Format Jan Christoph Schlegel and Ak akiMa mage ish vili On Chain Auctions with Deposits June pages

State Dependent Processing in Payment Channel Networks for Throughput Optimization NIKOLAOS PAPA IS Electrical Engineering Institute for Network Science Yale University USA LEANDRO ST AS SIU LAS Electrical Engineering Institute for Network Science Yale University USA Payment channel networks CNs have emerged as as cal ability solution for block chains built on the concept of payment channel setting that allows two nodes to safely transact between themselves in high frequencies based on pre committed peer to peer balances Transaction requests in these networks maybe declined because of un availability of funds due to temporary uneven distribution of the channel balances In this paper we investigate how to alleviate unnecessary payment blockage via proper prior it iz ation of the transaction execution order Specifically we consider the scheduling problem in CNs as transactions continuously arrive on both sides of channel nodes need to decide which ones to process and when in order to maximize their objective which in our case is the channel throughput We introduce stochastic model to capture the dynamics of payment channel under random arrivals and propose that channels can hold incoming transactions in buffers up to some deadline in order to enable more elaborate processing decisions We describe policy that maximizes the channel success rate throughput for uniform transaction requests of fixed amounts both in the presence and absence of buffering capabilities and formally prove its optimal it We also develop discrete event simulator of payment channel and evaluate different heuristic scheduling policies in the more general heterogeneous amounts case with the results showing superiority of the heuristic extension of our policy in this case as well Our work opens the way for more formal research on improving PC performance via joint consideration of routing and scheduling decisions

Optimal Fees for Geometric Mean Market Makers Alex Evans Guillermo Anger is and Ta run Chitra alex placeholder vc guill an stanford edu ta run gauntlet network Abstract Constant Function Market Makers CFM Ms are family of automated market makers that enable censorship resistant de central zed exchange on public block chains Arb it rage trades have been shown to align the prices reported by CFM Ms with those of external markets These trades impose costs on Liquidity Providers LPs who supply re serves to CFM Ms Trading fees have been proposed as mechanism for compensating LPs for arb it rage losses However large fees reduce the accuracy of the prices reported by CFM Ms and can cause reserves to deviate from desirable asset compositions CFM designers are there fore faced with the problem of how to optimal ly select fees to attract liquidity We develop framework for determining the value to LPs of supplying liquidity to CFM with fees when the underlying process follows general diu sion Focusing on popular class of CFM Ms which we call Geometric Mean Market Makers Ms our approach also al lows one to select optimal fees for maximizing LP value We illustrate our methodology by showing that an LP with mean variance utility will prefer aG overall alternative trading strategies as fees approach zero

Block chain and smart contract for oT enabled smart agriculture Tah mid Has an Pr an to Abdull All No man tik Mahmud and KM Bah al ul Ha que Electrical and Computer Engineering North South University Dhaka Bangladesh These authors contributed equally to this work ABSTRACT The agricultural sector is still lagging behind from all other sectors in terms of using the newest technologies For production the latest machines are being introduced and adopted However pre harvest and post harvest processing are still done by following traditional methodologies while tracing storing and publishing agricultural data As result farmers are not getting deserved payment consumers are not getting enough information before buying their product and intermediate person processors are increasing retail prices Using block chain smart contracts and oT devices we can fully automate the process while establishing absolute trust among all these parties In this research we explored the different aspects of using block chain and smart contracts with the integration of oT devices in pre harvesting and post harvesting segments of agriculture We proposed system that uses block chain as the backbone while oT devices collect data from the el level and smart contracts regulate the interaction among all these contributing parties The system implementation has been shown in diagrams and with proper explanations Gas costs of every operation have also been attached for better understanding of the costs We also analyzed the system in terms of challenges and advantages The overall impact of this research was to show the immutable available transparent and robustly secure characteristics of block chain in the el of agriculture while also emphasizing the vigorous mechanism that the collaboration of block chain smart contract and oT presents Submitted November Accepted February Subjects Algorithms and Analysis of Algorithms Computer Networks and Communications Published March
