Submitted on th Feb Accepted on th March Digital Object Identifier ACCESS GDP Compliant Block chains Systematic Literature Review KM Bah al ul Ha que KM Najm ul Islam Sami Hy ry sal mi Bilal Na qv and Kari mo lander Software Engineering LENS LU University Lapp een rant Finland Corresponding author KM Bah al ul Ha que mail najm ul islam lu fi This work was funded by Business Finland project ABSTRACT Although block chain based digital services promise trust accountability and transparency multiple paradoxes between block chains and GDP have been highlighted in the recent literature Some of the recent literature also proposed possible solutions to these paradoxes This article aims to conduct systematic literature review on GDP compliant block chains and synthesize the findings In particular the goal was to identify the GDP articles that have been explored in prior literature the relevant research domains that have been explored and the research gaps Our findings synthesized that the block chains relevant GDP articles can be categorized into six major groups namely data deletion and modification Article and protection by design by default Article responsibilities of controllers and processors Article and consent management Article data processing principles and lawfulness Article and and territorial scope Article We also found seven research domains where GDP compliant block chains have been discussed which include oT financial data healthcare personal identity online data information governance and smart city From our analysis we have identified few key research gaps and present future research direction INDEX TERMS Block chain General Data Protection Regulation GDP Systematic Literature Review

First Look into the Structural Properties and Resilience of Block chain Overlays ARIS TO DEMOS PAP HIT IS Cyprus University of Technology Cyprus NICOLAS OUR TELL IS Telefonica Research Spain MICHAELS RIVI ANOS Cyprus University of Technology Cyprus Block chain BC systems are highly distributed peer to peer networks that offer an alternative to centralized services and promise robustness to coordinated attacks However the resilience and overall security of aBC system rests heavily on the structural properties of its underlying peer to peer overlay Despite their success BC overlay networks critical design aspects connectivity properties and network layer inter dependencies are still poorly understood In this work we set out to fill this gap by studying the most important overlay structural properties and the resilience to targeted attacks of seven distinct BC networks In particular we probe and crawl these BC networks over days We construct at frequent intervals connectivity graphs for each BC network consisting of all potential connections between peers We analyze the structural graph properties of these networks their temporal characteristics and their topological resilience We show that by targeting fewer than highly connected peers major BCs such as Bitcoin can be partitioned into disjoint disconnected components Finally we uncover hidden overlap between different BC networks where certain peers participate in more than one BC network This finding has serious implications for the robustness of the overall BC network ecosystem

Light PIR Privacy Preserving Route Discovery for Payment Channel Networks Krzysztof Pie tr zak Iosif Salem krzysztof pie tr zak is ac at iosif salem uni vie ac at Stefan Schmid Michelle Yeo stefan schmid uni vie ac at michelle yeo is ac at IS Austria Faculty of Computer Science University of Vienna Abstract Payment channel networks are promising approach to improve the cal ability of crypto cur ren cie they allow to perform transactions in peer to peer fashion along multi hop routes in the net work without requiring consensus on the block chain However during the discovery of cost ec ent routes for the transaction critical information may be revealed about the transacting entities This paper initiates the study of privacy preserving route discovery mechanisms for payment channel networks In particular we present Light PIR an approach which allows source toe cie ntl discover shortest path to its destination without revealing any information about the endpoints of the transaction The two main observations which allow for nec ent solution in Light PIR are that surprisingly hub labelling algorithms which were developed top reprocess street network like graphs so one can later cie ntl compute shortest paths also work well for the graphs underlying payment channel networks and that hub labelling algorithms can be directly combined with private information retrieval Light PIR relies on simple hub labeling heuristic on top of existing hub labeling algorithms which leverages the spec ic topological features of crypto currency networks to further minimize storage and bandwidth overheads In case study considering the Lightning network we show that our approach is an order of magnitude more ec ent compared to privacy preserving baseline based on using private information retrieval on database that stores all pairs shortest paths

On performance of PB FT for oT applications with constrained devices Yar slav Mesh cher yakov Anna Melman Oleg Ev ut in Vladimir Moro zo evgeni Kou che rya vy Senior Member IEEE National Research University Higher School of Economics Moscow Russia Tomsk State University of Control Systems and Radio electronics Tomsk Russia Tampere University Tampere Finland Corresponding author Oleg Ev ut in mail ev ut in oo gmail com ABSTRACT Cyber physical systems and the Internet of things oT is becoming an integral part of the digital society The use of oT services improves human life in many ways Protection against cyber threats is an important aspect of the functioning of oT devices Malicious activities lead to confidential data leakages and incorrect performance of devices are becoming critical Therefore development of effective solutions that can protect both oT devices data and data exchange networks turns in to real challenge This study provides critical analysis of the feasibility of using block chain technology to protect constrained oT devices data justifies the choice of Practical Byzantine Fault Tolerance PB FT consensus algorithm for implementation on such devices and simulates the main distributed ledger scenarios using PB FT The simulation results demonstrate the efficiency of the block chain technology for constrained devices and make it possible to evaluate the applicability limits of the chosen consensus algorithm INDEX TERMS Block chain Consensus algorithm Constrained devices Internet of things Practical Byzantine Fault Tolerance

there um Name Service the Good the Bad and the Ugly PENG CHENG XIA Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications China HAO YU WANG Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications China ZHOU YU Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications China IN YU LIU Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications China XI APU LUO The HongKong Polytechnic University China GUO AIX Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications China DNS has always been criticized for its inherent design flaws making the system vulnerable to kinds of attacks Besides DNS domain names are not fully controlled by the users which can be easily taken down by the authorities and registrars Since block chain has its unique properties like immutability and decentralization it seems to be promising to build decentralized name service on block chain there um Name Service ENS as novel name service built at opEth eru em has received great attention from the community Yet no existing work has systematically studied this emerging system especially the security issues and misbehavior in ENS To fill the void we present the first large scale study of ENS by collecting and analyzing millions of event logs related to ENS We characterize the ENS system from number of perspectives Our findings suggest that ENSis showing gradually popularity during its four years evolution mainly due to its distributed and open nature that ENS domain names can be set to any kinds of records even censored and malicious contents We have identified several security issues and misbehavior including traditional DNS security issues and new issues introduced by ENS smart contracts Attackers are abusing the system with thousands of squatting ENS names number of scam block chain addresses and malicious websites etc Our exploration suggests that our community should invest more effort into the detection and mitigation of issues in Block chain based Name Services towards building an open and trustworthy name service

Management Systems Institute Athena Research Center Artem ido Maro usi Greece Abstract Programming errors in there um smart contracts can result in catastrophic nanci al losses from stolen crypto currency While vulnerability detectors can prevent vu lner ble contracts from being deployed this does not mean that such contracts will not be deployed Once vulnerable contract is instantiated on the block chain and becomes the target of attacks the ident cation of exploit transactions becomes indispensable in assessing whether it has been actually exploited and identifying which malicious or subverted accounts were involved In this work we study the problem of post fact um investigation of there um attacks using Indicators of Compromise IoC specially crafted for use in the block chain IoC den it ions need to capture the side effects of successful exploitation in the context of the there um block chain Therefore wed enea model for smart contract execution comprising multiple abstraction levels that mirror the multiple views of code execution on block chain Subsequently we compare IoC de ned across the different levels in terms of their effectiveness and practicality through Ether Clue prototype tool for investigating there um security incidents Our results illustrate that coarse grained IoC de ned over blocks of transactions can detect exploit transactions with less com put ation however they are contract spec ic and suffer from false negatives On the other hand ne grained IoC de ned over virtual machine instructions can avoid these pitfalls at the expense of increased computation which are nevertheless applicable for practical use Keywords Block chain Forensics there um Attacks Indicators of Compromise there um Operational Semantics Corresponding author Email An Overview of Federated Learning at the Edge and Distributed Ledger Technologies for Robotic and Autonomous Systems Yu Xian jia Jorge Pena Quer alta Ju kka He ikk one and To mi Wester lund Turku Intelligent Embedded and Robotic Systems Lab University of Turku Turku Finland xian jia yu jop qu ju khei to ve we tu fi https tiers tu fi Abstract Autonomous systems are becoming inherently ubiquitous with the advancements of computing and communication solutions enabling low latency oo ding and real time collaboration of distributed devices Decentralized technologies with block chain and distributed ledger tech no logie LTs are playing key role At the same time advances in deep learning DL have sign cant ly raised the degree of autonomy and level of intelligence of robotic and autonomous systems While these technological revolutions were taking place raising concerns in terms of data security and end user privacy has become an inescapable re search consideration Federated learning FL is promising solution to privacy preserving DL at the edge with an inherently distributed na ture by learning on isolated data islands and communicating only model updates However FL by itself does not provide the levels of security and robustness required by todays standards in distributed autonomous systems This survey covers applications of FL to autonomous robots analyzes the role of LT and FL for these systems and introduces the key background concepts and considerations in current research Keywords Robotics Cloud Robotics Fog Robotics Federated Learn ing Federated Reinforcement Learning Federated Edge Learning is tribute Learning Distributed Ledger Technologies

Modular Verification of Collaborating Smart Contracts CHRISTIAN BRM ETH Zurich Switzerland MARC OEIL ERS ETH Zurich Switzerland PETER LLER ETH Zurich Switzerland ROBIN SIERRA ETH Zurich Switzerland ALEXANDER SUMMERS University of British Columbia Canada Smart contracts are programs that execute inside block chains such as there um to manipulate digital assets Since bugs in smart contracts may lead to substantial financial losses there is considerable interest informally proving their correctness However the specification and verification of smart contracts faces challenges that do not arise in other application domains Smart contracts frequently interact with unverified potentially adversarial outside code which substantially weakens the assumptions that formal analyses can soundly make Moreover the core functionality of smart contracts is to manipulate and transfer resources describing this functionality concisely requires dedicated specification support Current reasoning techniques do not fully address these challenges being restricted in their scope or expressiveness in particular in the presence of re entrant calls and offering limited means of expressing the resource transfers contract performs In this paper we present novel specification methodology tailored to the domain of smart contracts Our specification constructs and associated reasoning technique are the first to enable sound and precise re so ning in the presence of unverified code and arbitrary re entr an cy modular reasoning about collaborating smart contracts and domain specific specifications based on resources and resource transfers which allow expressing contracts behaviour in intuitive and concise ways and exclude typical errors by default We have implemented our approach in Vy per an SMT based automated verification tool forE there um smart contracts written in the Vy per language and demonstrated its effectiveness in succinctly capturing and verifying strong correctness guarantees for real world contracts Additional KeyWords and Phrases there um smart contracts specification software verification resources

Which Event Happened First Deferred Choice on Block chain Using Oracles cid Jan Ladle if Mathias Wes ke Has so Platt ner Institute University of Potsdam Potsdam Germany Abstract First come rst served Critical choices between alternative actions are often made based on events external to an organization and reacting promptly to their occurrence can be major advantage over the competition In Business Process Management BPM such deferred choices can be expressed in process models and they are an important aspect of process engines Block chain based process execution approaches are no exception to this but are severely limited by the inherent properties of the platform The closed world environment pre vents direct access to external entities and data and the passive runtime based entirely on atomic transactions impedes continual monitoring and detection of events In this paper we provide an in depth examination of the semantics of deferred choice and transfer them to environments such as the block chain We introduce and compare several oracle architectures able to satisfy certain requirements and show that they can be implemented using state of the art block chain technology Keywords processes block chain smart contracts events deferred choice

University of ABC Brazil Self Sovereign Identity SSI Block chain based technology for digital identity management is promising concept for handling health data It could represent step forward in empowering users granting them control over their data This work conducts systematic literature review to investigate state of the art measures based on SSI and Block chain technologies for dealing with electronic health records HRs identifying gaps and determining the key questions for future research As result this review shows growing interest in Block chain methods to handle HRs but few works consider using the self sovereign identity approaches The results obtained in this work also suggest that Block chain technologies provide viable alternative to deliver HR solutions such as patient monitoring healthcare data trading and prescription control consolidated Block chain technologies are the preferred core components of most effective strategies keeping raw health data off chain helps to create scalable solutions health data standards make searching medical records in Block chain structures feasible Smart Contracts are essential components of Block chain based HR solutions the concepts of data ownership and Self Sovereign Identity have been neither adequately defined nor employed in the health context CCS Concepts Applied computing Health care information Priv Chain Provenance and Privacy Preservation in Block chain enabled Supply Chains Si draMa lika Volk anD ede og lub lil Kan here Raja Jur akc University of New South Wales Sydney NSW Australia CSIRO Data Pullen vale Queensland University of Technology Brisbane QLD Australia Abstract Block chain erst race ability and transparency to supply chain event data and hence can help overcome many challenges in supply chain management such as data integrity provenance and trace ability However data privacy concerns such as the protection of trade secrets have hindered adoption of block chain technology Although consortium block chains only allow authorised supply chain entities to read write to the ledger privacy preservation of trade secrets cannot be ascertained In this work we propose privacy preservation framework Priv Chain to protect sensitive data on block chain using zero knowledge proofs Priv Chain provides provenance and trace ability without revealing any sensitive information to end consumers or supply chain entities Its novelty stems from its ability to allow data owners to protect trade related information and instead provide proofs on the data and an integrated incentive mechanism for entities providing valid proofs over provenance data In particular Priv Chain uses Zero Knowledge Range Proofs RPs nec ent variant of KP to provide origin information without disclosing the exact location of supply chain product Furthermore the framework allows to compute proofs and commitment so line decoupling the computational overhead from block chain The proof ver cation process and incentive payment initiation are automated using block chain transactions smart contracts and events proof of concept implementation on Hyper ledger Fabric reveals minimal overhead of using Priv Chain for block chain enabled supply chains Keywords zero knowledge proofs provenance trace ability privacy permission ed block chain supply chain

Block chain Based Decentralized Energy Management Platform for Residential Distributed Energy Resources in Virtual Power Plant Qing Yanga Hao Wang Tao tao Wang Sheng li Zhang Xiao xiao Wu Hui Wang College of Electronics and Information Engineering CE Shenzhen University Shenzhen Guangdong Province China Department of Data Science and Faculty of Information Technology Monash University Melbourne VIC Australia Stanford Sustainable System sLab Stanford University CA USA Abstract The advent of distributed energy resources DER such as distributed renewables energy storage electric vehicles and controllable loads brings sign cant ly disruptive and transformation al impact on the centralized power system It is widely accepted that paradigm shift to decentralized power system with bidirectional power ow is necessary to the integration of DER The virtual powerplant VP emerges as promising paradigm for managing DER to participate in the power system In this paper we develop block chain based VP energy management platform to facilitate rich set of trans active energy activities among residential users with renewables energy storage and ex ble loads in VP Spec ic ally users can interact with each other to trade energy for mutual be nets and provide network services such as feed in energy reserve and demand response through the VP To respect the users independence and preserve their privacy we design decentralized optimization algorithm to optimize the users energy scheduling energy trading and network services Then we develop prototype block chain network for VP energy management and implement the proposed algorithm on the block chain network By experiments using real world data trace we validated the feasibility and eec ti ve ness of our algorithm and the block chain system The simulation results demonstrate that our block chain based VP energy management platform reduces the users cost by up to and reduces the overall system cost by Keywords Smart grid virtual powerplant VP distributed energy resource DER energy management distributed optimization block chain

Fund ment In format cae XXI DOI FI IOS Press Three Party Integer Comparison and Applications Jie Maa Bin Qi Ke weiL va State Key Laboratory of Information Security Institute of Information Engineering Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing China Data Assurance Communication Security Research Center Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing China School of Cyber Security University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing China ma jie ii ac cn qi bin ii ac cn lv ke wei ii ac cn Abstract Secure integer comparison has been popular research topic in cryptography both for its simplicity to describe and for its applications The aim is to enable two parties to compare their inputs without revealing the exact value of those inputs In this paper we highlight three party integer comparison PIC where judge with no private input wants to know the comparison result while two competitors hold secret integers to do privacy preserving comparison The judge actively obtains the result rather than passively waiting for it sent by competitor We give two PIC constructions considering Mixed adversaries Address for correspondence Corresponding author Ke weiL State Key Laboratory of Information Security Institute of Information Engineering Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing China

Vulnerability of Block chain Technologies to Quantum Attacks Joseph Kearney Carlos Perez Delgado School of Computing University of Kent Canterbury Kent CT NF United Kingdom Abstract Quantum computation represents threat to many cryptographic protocols in operation today It has been estimated that by there will exist quantum computer capable of breaking the vital cryptographic scheme RSA Block chain technologies rely on cryptographic protocols for many of their essential sub routines Some of these protocols but not all are open to quantum attacks Here we analyze the major block chain based crypto currencies deployed today including Bitcoin there um Lite coin and Cash and determine their risk exposure to quantum attacks We nish with comparative analysis of the studied crypto currencies and their underlying block chain technologies and their relative levels of vulnerability to quantum attacks

Quantum Advantage on Proof of Work Dan Bard Joseph Kearney and Carlos Perez Delgado School of Computing University of Kent Canterbury Kent CT NF United Kingdom Proof of Work PoW is fundamental underlying technology behind most major block chain crypto currencies It has been previously pointed out that quantum devices provide computational advantage in performing PoW in the context of Bitcoin Here we make the case that this quantum advantage extends not only to all existing PoW mechanisms but to any possible Po Was well This has strong consequences regarding both quantum based attacks on the integrity of the entirety of the block chain as well as more legitimate uses of quantum computation for the purpose of mining Bitcoin and other crypto currencies For the rst case we estimate when these quantum attacks will become feasible for various crypto currencies and discuss the impact of such attacks For the latter we derive precise formula to calculate the economic incentive for switching to quantum based crypto currency miners Using this formula we analyze several test scenarios and conclude that investing in quantum hardware for crypto currency mining has the potential to payoff immensely

This is the authors pre print version Software Engineering for Block chain Based Software Systems Foundations Survey and Future Directions Mahdi Fah mid eh University of Wollongong Australia John Grundy Monash University Australia kash Ahmed University of Adelaide Australia Jun Shen Jun Yan Dav oud Mou go uei Peng Wang Aditya hose Anu radha Gun award an University of Wollongong Australia Uwe ckel in The University of Melbourne Australia Baba Abed in Macquarie University Australia Many scientific and practical areas have shown increasing interest in reaping the benefits of block chain technology to empower software systems However the unique characteristics and requirements associated with Block chain Based Software BBS systems raise new challenges across the development lifecycle that entail an extensive improvement of conventional software engineering This article presents systematic literature review of the state of the art in BBS engineering research from software engineering perspective We characterize BBS engineering from the theoretical foundations processes models and roles and discuss rich repertoire of key development activities principles challenges and techniques The focus and depth of this survey not only gives software engineering practitioners and researchers consolidated body of knowledge about current BBS development but also underpins starting point for further research in this field CCS CONCEPTS General and reference Surveys and overviews Software engineering Software and its engineering Software development process management Block chain Additional Keywords and Phrases Software engineering Systems development methods Block chain Block chain based software systems

Managing Block chain Systems and Applications Process Model for Block chain Configurations Olga Lab azov Ero Kazan Tobias Dehli ng University of Cologne IT University of Copenhagen Karlsruhe Institute of Technology lab azov wi so uni ko el de er ka it dk dehli ng kit edu Tu ure Tu una nen Ali Suny ev University of Jyv skyl Karlsruhe Institute of Technology tu ure tu una nen yu fi suny ev kit edu Abstract Block chain is radical innovation with unique value proposition that shifts trust from institutions to algorithms Still the potential of block chains remains elusive due to knowledge gaps between computer science research and socio economic research Building on information technology governance literature and the theory of coevolution this study develops process model for block chain configurations that captures block chain capability dimensions and application areas We demonstrate the applicability of the proposed block chain config ration process model on four block chain projects The proposed block chain configuration pro ces model assists with the selection and configuration of block chain systems based on set of known requirements for block chain project Our findings contribute to research by bridging knowledge gaps between computer science and socio economic research on block chain pe ci fic ally we explore existing block chain concepts and integrate them in process model for block chain configurations

Homogeneous Properties of Automated Market Makers THE HOMOGENEOUS PROPERTIES OF AUTOMATED MARKET MAKERS Johannes Rude Jensen Mohsen Pour po une University of Copenhagen DIK University of Copenhagen IF RO To roX Labs mohsen if ro ku dk jensen di ku dk Kurt Nielsen Omri Ross University of Copenhagen IF RO University of Copenhagen DIK kun if ro ku dk To roX Labs omri di ku dk Abstract Automated market makers MM have grown to obtain significant market share within the crypto cur ren cy ecosystem resulting in proliferation of new products pursuing exotic strategies for horizontal differentiation Yet their theoretical properties are curiously homogeneous when set of basic as sump ions are met In this paper we start by presenting universal approach to deriving formula for liquidity provisioning for MM Next we show that the constant function market maker and token swap market maker models are theoretically equivalent when liquidity reserves are uniform Proceeding with an ex ami nation of MM market micro structure we show how non linear price effect translates into slippage for traders and impermanent losses for liquidity providers We proceed by showing how impermanent losses are function of both volatility and market depth and discuss the implications of these findings within the context of the literature Keywords Automated Market Making DeF Block chain

LT based Smart Contract Architecture for Atomic and Scalable Trading Jan Kalb ant ner Student Member IEEE Konstantino Mark an to nak is Darren Hurley Smith Carlton Shepherd and Benjamin Sem al Abstract Distributed Ledger Technology LT has an enormous potential but also downsides One downside of many LT systems such as block chain is their limited transaction throughput that hinders their adoption in many use cases real time payments State channels have emerged as potential solution to enhance throughput by allowing transactions to process off chain While current proposals can increases cal ability they require high collateral and lack support for dynamic systems that require asynchronous state transitions Additionally the latency of channel initial is at ions can cause issues especially if fast interactions are required In this paper we propose anatomic scalable and privacy preserving protocol that enables secure and dynamic updates We develop smart contract based Credit Note System CNS that allows participants to lock funds before state channel initial is ation which enhances ex bil it and efc ien cy We formalise our model using the Universal Com pos ability UC framework and demonstrate that it achieves the stated design goals of privacy cal ability and atom city Moreover we implement dispute process in the state channel to counter availability attacks Finally we analyse the protocol in the context of an asynchronous smart grid based marketplace Index Terms LT block chain state channel computer security privacy smart contracts smart grid energy trading cid

Switzerland ZH Block chain Center Universitat Zurich Andreas stra sse CH Zurich Switzerland UR PP Social Networks Universitat Zurich Andreas stra sse CH Zurich Switzerland dade cs aau dk ABSTRACT Bitcoin is built on block chain an immutable de centralised ledger that allows entities users to exchange Bitcoins in pseudonym us manner Bitcoins are associated with alpha numeric addresses and are transferred via transactions Each transaction is composed of set of input addresses associated with un spent outputs received from previous transactions and set of output addresses to which Bitcoins are transferred Despite Bi to in was designed with anonymity in mind different heuristic approaches exist to detect which addresses in spec ic transaction belong to the same entity By applying these heuristics we build an Address Correspondence Network in this representation addresses are nodes are connected with edges if atleast one heuristic detects them as belonging to the same entity In this paper we analyse for the rst time the Address Correspondence Network and show it is characterised by complex topology signalled by abroad skewed degree distribution and power law component size distribution Using large scale data set of addresses for which the controlling entities are known we show that combination of external data coupled with standard community detection algorithms can reliably identify entities The complex nature of the Address Correspondence Network reveals that usage patterns of individual entities create statistical regularities and that these regularities can be leveraged to more accurately identify entities and gain deeper understanding of the Bitcoin economy as whole

Taxonomy Study on Securing Block chain based Industrial Applications An Overview Application Perspectives Requirements Attacks Countermeasures and Open Issues Kh zar Hameed Mut zB arika Saura bh Gar ga Muhammad Bilal Amina yeong Kang Discipline of ICT School of Technology Environments and Design University of Tasmania Australia Abstract Block chain technology has taken on leading role into days industrial applications by providing salient features and showing sign cant performance since its beginning Block chain began its journey from the concept of crypto currency and is now part of range of core applications to achieve resilience and automation between various tasks With the integration of Block chain technology into die rent industrial applications many application designs security and privacy challenges present themselves posing serious threats to users and their data Although several approaches have been proposed to address the spec ic security and privacy needs of targeted applications with functional parameters there is still need for research study on the application ecu rit and privacy challenges and requirements of Block chain based industrial applications along with possible security threats and countermeasures This study presents state of the art survey of Block chain based Industry applications focusing on crucial application and security and privacy requirements as well as corresponding attacks on Block chain systems with potential counter measures We also analyse and provide the classic ation of die rent security and privacy techniques used in these applications to enhance the advancement of security features Furthermore we highlight some open issues in industrial applications that help to design secure Block chain based applications as future directions Keywords Block chain industrial applications Application requirements Security requirements Privacy preserving Security attacks Countermeasures

The Giving Game Dr Wei land Delft University of Technology May Keywords Giving gift economy community effect stabilization computational complexity corruption micro economics game theory stock trading distributed computing crypto Abstract currency block chain Assume you are with players in room One player has ball Once you have the ball you must choose player not being yourself and pass the ball to her him The game repeats itself from then onwards Every time you receive the ball you get point Question which strategy is optimal to receive as many points possible One strategy would be to play the ball to the player from whom you received the ball most times in the past assuming this creates the best chance to receive the ball in return Receiving the ball creates an increase of preference for the submitting player who has just granted you point This seems rational to do game described above is called Giving Game This paper reveals the fundamental structure of such game and how the chosen strategy works out Main result is that the game necessarily stabilizes into repetitive pattern within subgroup in this case pair of players Furthermore will show that the path towards stabilization consists of series of elementary cycles each further enhancing the preferred pair Example applications are where computers are sharing processing power for complex calculations or when commodity traders are making transactions in some professional community The name Giving Game has positive connotation However it may equally well be viewed as basic model of client elis or corruption

Ve rico Ver cation and Communication Architecture for oT based Block chain Ali Dor ria haile sh Mishra Raja Jur dak School of Computer Science QU Australia Department of Electrical Engineering IT Kh arag pur India Abstract Block chain has received tremendous attention as secure distributed and anonymous framework for the Internet of Things oT As distributed system block chain trades cal ability for distribution which limits the technology adaptation for large scale networks such as oT All transactions and blocks must be broadcast and ve ried by all participants which limits cal ability and incurs computational and communication overheads The existing solutions to scale block chains have so far led to partial re centralization limiting the tech no logy original appeal In this paper we introduce distributed yet cal able Ver cation and Communication architecture for block chain referred to as Ve rico Ve rico concurrently achieves high cal ability and distribution using hash function outputs to shift block chains from broadcast to multi cast com muni cation Unlike conventional block chains where all nodes must verify new transactions blocks Ve rico uses the hash of oT tra to randomly select set of nodes to verify transactions blocks which in turn reduces the processing overhead Ve rico incorporates two layers transmission layer where ran do miz ed multi casting method is introduced along with backbone network to route tra transactions and blocks from the source to the destination and ii ver cation layer where set of randomly selected nodes are allocated to verify each transaction or block The performance evaluation shows that Ver com reduces the packet and processing overhead as compared with conventional block chains In the worst case packet overhead in Ve rico scales linearly with the number of nodes while the processing overhead remains scale independent Pre print submitted to Journal of LATEX Templates May

manner In this paper we focus on FL over wireless environments with varying channels and energy harvesting at clients We are interested in proposing dynamic resource allocation transmit power computation frequency for model training and block mining for each client and client scheduling DR ACS to maximize the long term time average LTA training data size with an LTA energy consumption constraint Spec ic ally we rst de ne the Lyapunov drift by converting the LTA energy consumption to queue stability constraint Then we construct Lyapunov drift plus penalty ratio function to de couple the original stochastic problem into multiple deterministic optimization along the time line Our construction is capable of dealing with uneven durations of communication rounds To make the one shot deterministic optimization problem of combinatorial fractional form tractable we next convert the fractional problem into subtractive form one by Dink el bach method which leads to the asymptotically optimal solution in an iterative way In addition the closed form of the optimal resource allocation and client scheduling is obtained in each iteration with low complexity Furthermore we conduct the performance analysis for the proposed algorithm and discover that the LTA training data size and energy consumption obey an trade off Our experimental results show that the proposed algorithm can optimization resource allocation client scheduling

Topological Anomaly Detection in Dynamic Multilayer Block chain Networks Of ori Boateng cid Segovia Dominguez Akc or Kant rcio lu and Gel Portland State University USA dorcas of ori boateng pd edu University of Texas at Dallas USA University of Manitoba Canada Abstract Motivated by the recent surge of criminal activities with cross crypto currency trades we introduce new topological perspective to structural anomaly detection in dynamic multilayer networks We postulate that anomalies in the underlying block chain transaction graph that are composed of multiple layers are likely to also be manifested in anomalous patterns of the network shape properties As such we invoke the machinery of clique persistent homolog on graphs to systematically and cie ntl track evolution of the network shape and as result to detect changes in the underlying network topology and geometry We develop new persistence summary for multilayer networks called stacked persistence diagram and prove its stability under input data perturbations We validate our new topological anomaly detection frame work in application to dynamic multilayer networks from the there um Block chain and the Ripple Credit Network and demonstrate that our stacked PD approach substantially outperforms state of art techniques Keywords Anomaly Detection Dynamic Multilayer Network Block ch in Transaction Topological Data Analysis Clique Persistent Homolog

Interlacing Results for Hyper graphs Ra ella Mul as The Alan Turing Institute London NW DB UK University of Southampton Southampton SO BJ UK Received March Hyper graphs are generalization of graphs in which edges can connect any number of ver tice They allow the modeling of complex networks with higher order interactions and their spectral theory studies the qualitative properties that can be inferred from the spectrum the multiset of the eigenvalues of an operator associated to hyper graph It is expected that small perturbation of hyper graph such as the removal of few vertices or edges does not lead to major change of the eigenvalues In particular it is expected that the eigenvalues of the original hyper graph interlace the eigenvalues of the perturbed hyper graph Here we work on hyper graphs where in addition each vertex edge incidence is given real number and we prove interlacing results for the adj ace cy matrix the Kir cho La plac ian and the normalized La plac ian Tightness of the inequalities is also shown KEYWORDS networks hyper graphs eigenvalues spectral theory interlacing

Block chain Based Trust Management Framework with Veria ble Interactions Shan tan Pala Ambrose Hill Tahir Rabe haj ad Michael Hitchens School of Computer Science Queensland University of Technology Brisbane QLD Australia School of Computer Science and Engineering University of New South Wales Sydney NSW Australia Distributed Sensing Systems Group CSIRO Data Brisbane QLD Australia Risk Frontiers Sydney NSW Australia Department of Computing Macquarie University Sydney NSW Australia Abstract There has been tremendous interest in the development of formal trust mod els and metrics through the use of analytics Belief Theory and Bayesian models logic Epistemic and Subjective Logic and other ma the mati cal models The choice of trust metric will depend on context circumstance and user requirements and there is no single best metric for use in all ir cum stances Where die rent users require die rent trust metrics to be em ploy ed the trust score calculations should still be based on all available trust evidence Trust is normally computed using past experiences but in practice especially in centralised systems the validity and accuracy of these ex peri en ces are taken for granted In this paper we provide formal framework and practical block chain based implementation that allows independent trust providers to implement die rent trust metrics in distributed manner while still allowing all trust providers to base their calculations on common set of trust evidence Further our design allows experiences to be provably linked to interactions without the need for central authority This leads to the notion of evidence based trust with provable interactions Leveraging block chain allows the trust providers too er their services in competitive manner charging fees Corresponding author Email address shan tan pal qu edu au Shan tan uP al Pre print submitted to Else vier June

Security and Privacy for Healthcare Block chains Rui Zhang Rui Xue and Ling Liu Fellow IEEE Abstract Healthcare block chains provide an innovative way to store healthcare information execute healthcare transactions and build trust for healthcare data sharing and data integration in decentralized open healthcare network environment Although the healthcare block chain technology has attracted broad interests and attention in industry government and academia the security and privacy concerns remain the focus of debate when deploying block chains for information sharing in the healthcare sector from business operation to research collaboration This paper focuses on the security and privacy requirements for medical data sharing using block chain and provides comprehensive analysis of the security and privacy risks and requirements accompanied by technical solution techniques and strategies First we discuss the security and privacy requirements and attributes required for electronic medical data sharing by deploying the healthcare block chain Second we categorize existing efforts into three reference block chain usage scenarios for electronic medical data sharing and discuss the technologies for implementing these security and privacy properties in the three categories of usage scenarios for healthcare block chain such as anonymous signatures attribute based encryption zero knowledge proofs ver cation techniques for smart contract security Finally we discuss other potential block chain application scenarios in healthcare sector We conjecture that this survey will help healthcare professionals decision makers and healthcare service developers to gain technical and intuitive insights into the security and privacy of healthcare block chains in terms of concepts risks requirements development and deployment technologies and systems Index Terms Healthcare block chain medical data sharing security privacy preserving cid

Sol Trans Towards machine translation of Solidity smart contract source code haochen Shia Yong Xiang Jiang hanYu Long xiang Gao and Kesha vS ood Deakin Block chain Innovation Lab School of Information Technology Deakin University Geelong Australia Monash Block chain Technology Centre Faculty of Information Technology Monash University Australia Centre for Cyber Security Research and Innovation School of Information Technology Deakin University Geelong Australia ARTICLE INFO ABSTRACT Keywords Context Decentralized applications on block chain platforms are realized through smart contracts Solidity However participants who lack programming knowledge often have di cul ties reading the smart Smart contract contract source codes which leads to potential security risks and barriers to participation Machine translation Objective Our objective is to translate the smart contract source codes into natural language de scrip ions to help people better understand operate and learn smart contracts Method This paper proposes an automated translation tool for Solidity smart contracts termed Sol Trans based on an abstract syntax tree and formal grammar We have investigated smart contracts and determined the part of speeches of corresponding block chain terms Among them we further lte red out contract snippets without detailed comments and left snippets to evaluate the translation quality of Sol Trans Results Experimental results show that even with small corpus Sol Trans can achieve similar per form ance to the state of the art code comments generation models for other programming languages In addition Sol Trans has consistent performance when dealing with code snippets with die rent lengths and gas consumption Conclusion Sol Trans can correctly interpret Solidity codes and automatically convert them into comprehensible English text We will release our tool and data set for supporting reproduction and further studies in related lds

Stochastic modelling of block chain consensus Claudio Tess one Paolo as ca and Flavio anne lli ZH Block chain Center Universitat Zurich Andreas stra sse CH Zurich Switzerland UR PP Social Networks Universitat Zurich Andreas stra sse CH Zurich Switzerland Centre for Block chain Technologies University College London United Kingdom claudio tess one zh ch ABSTRACT Block chain and general purpose distributed ledgers are foundational technologies which bring sign cant innovation in the infrastructures and other underpinnings of our socio economic systems The seP technologies are able to securely diffuse information within and across networks without need for trustees or central authorities to enforce consensus In this contribution we propose minimalist ic stochastic model to understand the dynamics of block chain based consensus By leveraging on random walk theory we model block propagation delay on different network topologies and provide classic ation of block chain systems in terms of two emergent properties Firstly we identify two performing regimes functional regime corresponding to an optimal system function and non functional regime characterised by congested or branched state of sub optimal block chains Secondly we discover phase transition during the emergence of consensus and numerically investigate the corresponding critical point Our results provide important insights into the consensus mechanism and sub optimal states in de centralised systems

Multi Layered Block chain Governance Game ONG YOO MANG IM BS TRACT This paper deals with design of an integrated secure Block chain network framework to prevent damages from attackers The multi layer concept which could handle multiple number of networks is adapted on the top of Block chain Governance Game frameworks This new integrated theoretical model is designed to find the best strategies toward preparation for preventing whole network systems malfunction from attackers and it is developed based on the combination of the Block chain Governance Game and the Strategic Alliance for Block chain Governance Game Analytically tractable results for executing safety mode are fully obtained and simulated results are demonstrated to obtain the optimal values of hyper parameters of Block chain based security network This research helps those whom are constructing multiple layer network by enhancing security features through multi layer framework in decentralized network TRO DUCT ION The Block chain is distributed public digital ledger maintained by achieving consensus among number of nodes in peer to peer network typical decentralized peer to peer network has strengths which remove number of security risks in conventional centralized networks basic data structure of the Block chain is storing the verified transaction data in chain of blocks and chain grows in an append only manner with all new verified blocks The security of Block chain network is achieved through the distributed consensus of miners This consensus is only reliable with the assumption that no single miner can hold more than percent of the computational power in the network and more than half of the miners are not aligned under single control To gain its profit an attacker either invests more than percent of the computational power or governs more than half of the total nodes Alternatively Verifiable Random Functions VR Fs which is capable to select miner randomly and each node shall have an equal chance to be miner by using this technique could be adapted into block chain based security applications besides of using heavy computation power for mining The Verifiable Random Function RF is capable to select miner randomly and each node shall have an equal chance to be miner by using this technique The RF is applied to select the node for generating ledgers and it is cryptographic primitive that maps inputs to verifiable pseudorandom outputs Researchers have improved the securities in the protocol levels and some researches have proposed the new protocol to prevent the percent attack These conventional protocol improvements might prevent the percent attack but these implementations are limited because critical values and boundaries for the hyper parameters are arbitrarily chosen This working paper is targeted to submit at an international journal in the Applied Mathematics area

Come back when you are charged Self Organized Charging for Electric Vehicles Benjamin Lei ding Clausthal University of Technology Institute for Software and Systems Engineering Clausthal eller fe ld Germany benjamin lei ding tu clausthal de Abstract Dwindling nonrenewable fuel reserves progressing severe en iron mental pollution and accelerating climate change require society to reevaluate existing transportation concepts While electric vehicles EV have become more popular and slowly gain widespread adoption the corresponding battery charging infrastructures still limits EV use in our everyday life This is especially true for EV owners that do not have the option to operate charging hardware such as wall boxes at their premises Charging an EV without an at home wall box is time consuming since the owner has to drive to the charger charge the vehicle while waiting nearby and ally drive back home Thus convenient and easy to use solution is required to overcome the issue and in centi viz EV for daily commuters Therefore we propose an ecosystem and as er vice platform for semi autonomous electric vehicles that allow them to utilize their free time at night to access public and private charging infrastructure charge their batteries and get back home be fore the owner needs the car again To do so we utilize the concept of the Machine to Everything Economy Economy and outline decentralized ecosystem for smart machines that transact interact and collaborate via block chain based smart contracts to enable convenient battery charging marketplace for semi autonomous EV Keywords Electric Vehicles Block chain Technology Smart Contracts Internet of Things Circular Economy

Reward Based bit Compressed Federated Distillation on Block chain LEON WITT Tsinghua University China and Fraunhofer Heinrich Hertz Institute Germany USAMA ZA FAR Tsinghua University China KUO YEH SHEN Tsinghua University China FELIX SATTLER Fraunhofer Heinrich Hertz Institute Germany DAN LI Tsinghua University China WOJCIECH SAME Fraunhofer Heinrich Hertz Institute Germany The recent advent of various forms of Federated Knowledge Distillation FD paves the way for new generation of robust and communication efficient Federated Learning FL where mere soft labels are aggregated rather than whole gradients of Deep Neural Networks NN as done in previous FL schemes This security per design approach in combination with increasingly perform ant Internet of Things oT and mobile devices opens up new realm of possibilities to utilize private data from industries as well as from individuals as input for artificial intelligence model training Yet in previous FL systems lack of trust due to the imbalance of power between workers and central authority the assumption of altruistic worker participation and the inability to correctly measure and compare contributions of workers hinder this technology from scaling beyond small groups of already entrusted entities towards mass adoption This work aims to mitigate the aforementioned issues by introducing novel decentralized federated learning framework where heavily compressed bit soft labels resembling hot label predictions are aggregated on smart contract In context where workers contributions are now easily comparable we modify the Peer Truth Serum for Crowd sourcing mechanism PTS for FD to reward honest participation based on peer consistency in an incentive compatible fashion Due to heavy reductions of both computational complexity and storage our framework is fully on block chain FL system that is feasible on simple smart contracts and therefore block chain agnostic We experimentally test our new framework and validate its theoretical properties Additional KeyWords and Phrases Federated Learning Block chain Reward Mechanism Federated Distillation Decentralized Machine Learning

chain and for gh ting OVID in various applications The newly emerging projects and use cases enabled by these technologies to deal with coronavirus pandemic are also presented case study is also provided using federated for OVID detection Finally we point out challenges and future directions that motivate more research efforts to deal with future coronavirus like epidemics INDEX TERMS Block Bytecode based Approach for Smart Contract Classic ation haochen Shi Yong Xiang Senior Member IEEE Robin Ram Mohan Dos Senior Member IEEE Jiang shan Yu Member IEEE Kesha ood Member IEEE and Long xiang Gao Senior Member IEEE Abstract With the development of block chain technologies the number of smart contracts deployed on block chain platforms is growing exponentially which makes it if cult for users to nd desired services by manual screening The automatic classic ation of smart contracts can provide block chain users with keyword based contract searching and helps to manage smart contracts effectively Current research on smart contract classic ation focuses on Natural Language Processing NLP solutions which are based on contract source code However more than of smart contracts are not open source so the application scenarios of NLP methods are very limited Meanwhile NLP models are vulnerable to adversarial attacks This paper proposes classic ation model based on features from contract bytecode instead of source code to solve these problems We also use features election and ensemble learning to optimize the model Our experimental studies on over real world there um smart contracts show that our model can classify smart contracts without source code and has better performance than baseline models Our model also has good resistance to adversarial attacks compared with NLP based models In addition our analysis reveals that account features used in many smart contract classic ation models have little effect on classic ation and can be excluded Index Terms Smart contract classic ation Bytecode Block chain there um cid

Extending On chain Trust to Off chain Trustworthy Block chain Data Collection using Trusted Execution Environment TEE Chun chi Liu He chuan Guo Ming hui Xu Sheng ling Wang Dong xiao Yu Ji guo Yu and Xi zhen Cheng Fellow IEEE Abstract Block chain creates secure environment on top of strict cryptographic assumptions and rigorous security proofs It permits on chain interactions to achieve trustworthy properties such as trace ability transparency and accountability However current block chain trustworthiness is only conned to on chain creating trust gap to the physical off chain environment This is due to the lack of scheme that can truthfully re ect the physical world in real time and consistent manner Such an absence hinders further real world block chain applications especially for security sensitive ones In this paper we propose scheme to extend block chain trust from on chain to off chain and take trustworthy vaccine transportation as an example Our scheme consists of Trusted Execution Environment TEE enabled trusted environment monitoring system built with the Arm Cortex microcontroller that continuously senses the inside of vaccine box through trusted sensors and generates anti forgery data and consistency protocol to upload the environment status data from the TEE system to block chain in truthful real time consistent continuous and fault tolerant fashion Our security analysis indicates that no adversary can tamper with the vaccine in anyway without being captured We carryout an experiment to record the internal status of vaccine shipping box during transportation and the results indicate that the proposed system incurs an average latency of ms in local sensing and processing followed by an average latency of ms to have the sensed data transmitted to and available in the block chain Index Terms Block chain Trusted Execution Environment Physical Trace ability Vaccine Transportation cid

Fair Method for Distributing Collective Assets in the Stellar Block chain Financial Network Kia rash Shams Mohammad Java Shaye gan Department of Computer Engineering University of Science and Culture Tehran Iran Department of Computer Engineering University of Science and Culture Tehran Iran Corresponding author Mohammad Java Shaye gan fard mail shaye gan usc ac ir ABSTRACT The financial industry is pioneer in Block chain technology One of the most popular platforms in Token based banking is the flexible Stellar platform This platform is open source and today its wide range of features makes it possible for many countries and companies to use it in crypto currency and Token based modern banking This network charges fee for each transaction As well percentage of the net amount is generated as the inflation rate of the network due to the increased number of tokens These fees and inflationary amounts are aggregated into general account and ultimately distributed among members of the network on collective vote basis In this mechanism network users select an account as the destination for which they wish to transfer assets using their user interface which is generally wallet This account could be the account of charities that need this help It is then determined the target distribution network based on the voting results of all members One of the challenges in this network is the purposeful and fair distribution of these funds between accounts In this paper the first step is complete infrastructure of Stellar financial network that will consist of three network based segments of the core network off chain server and wallet interface In the second step context aware recommendation system will be explored and implemented as solution for the purposeful management of payroll account selection The results of this study concerning the importance of the purposeful division of collective assets and showing context aware recommendation system as solution to improve the process of stellar users participation in the voting process by effectively helping them in choosing an eligible destination INDEX TERMS Block chain Crypto currency Token Based Banking Stellar Fair Distribution

Stochastic Performance Modeling for Practical Byzantine Fault Tolerance Consensus in Block chain Fan Qi Maa Quan Lin Lib Yi Han Liu Yan Xia Chang School of Economics and Management Yanshan University Qin huang dao China School of Economics and Management Beijing University of Technology Beijing China July Abstract The practical Byzantine fault tolerant PB FT consensus mechanism is one of the most basic consensus algorithms or protocols in block chain technologies thus its performance evaluation is an interesting and challenging topic due to higher complexity of its consensus work in the peer to peer network This paper describes simple stochastic performance model of the PB FT consensus mechanism which is re ned as not only queueing system with complicated service times but also level independent quasi birth and death QB process From the level independent QB process we apply the matrix geometric solution to obtain necessary and suf cie nt condition under which the PB FT consensus system is stable and to be able to numerically compute the stationary probability vector of the QB process Thus we provide four useful performance measures of the PB FT consensus mechanism and can numerically calculate the four performance measures Finally we use some numerical examples to verify the validity of our theoretical results and show how the four per for man ce measures are in en ced by some key parameters of the PB FT consensus By means of the theory of multi dimensional Markov processes we are optimistic that the methodology and results given in this paper are applicable in wide range research of PB FT consensus mechanism and even other types of consensus mechanisms Corresponding author Li liq uanl in tsinghua edu cn

White Paper Block chain based Carbon Credit Ecosystem Dr So heil Sara ji Dr Mike Boro wc zak Assistant Professor Department of Petroleum Engineering University of Wyoming Assistant Professor Department of Computer Science University of Wyoming Abstract Climate change and global warming are the significant challenges of the new century viable solution to mitigate greenhouse gas emissions is via globally in centi viz ed market mechanism proposed in the Kyoto protocol In this view the carbon dioxide or other greenhouse gases emission is considered commodity forming carbon trading system There have been attempts in developing this idea in the past decade with limited success The main challenges of current systems are fragmented implementations lack of transparency leading to over crediting and double spending and substantial transaction costs that transfer wealth to brokers and agents We aim to create Carbon Credit Ecosystem using smart contracts that operate in conjunction with block chain technology in order to bring more transparency accessibility liquidity and standardization to carbon markets This ecosystem includes token iz ation mechanism to securely digitize carbon credits with clear minting and burning protocols transparent mechanism for distribution of tokens free automated market maker for trading the carbon tokens and mechanisms to engage all stakeholders including the energy industry project ver if ers liquidity providers NGOs concerned citizens and governments This approach could be used in variety of other credit trading systems

Building Stable chain Payment Networks Mohammad Amin Fazl Seyed Moe enNe hz at Mohammad Amin Salar kia Sharif University of Technology Tehran Iran Abstract Payment channel is protocol which allows crypto currency users to route multiple transactions through network without committing them to the main block chain network main net This ability makes them the most prominent solution to block chains cal ability problem Each mo dication of payment channels requires transaction on the main net and therefore big transaction fees In this paper we assume that set of payment transactions are given batch or online and we study the problem of scheduling mod ici at ions on payment channels to route all of the transactions with minimum mo dication cost We investigate two cost models for aforementioned problem the step cost function in which every channel mo dication has constant cost and the linear cost function in which mo dication costs are proportional to the amount of change For the step cost function model we prove impossibility results for both batch and online case Moreover some heuristic methods for the batch case la represented and compared For the linear cost we propose polynomial time algorithm using linear programming for the batch case Keywords Payment Channels chain Payment Networks Network Mo dication Scheduling

Proof of Stake Mining Games with Perfect Randomness Ma the us Ferreira and Matthew Weinberg Computer Science Princeton University July Abstract Proof of Stake block chains based on longest chain consensus protocol are an at tractive energy friendly alternative to the Proof of Work paradigm However formal barriers to getting the incentives right were recently discovered driven by the desire to use the block chain itself as source of pseudorandom ness We consider instead longest chain Proof of Stake protocol with perfect trusted external randomness randomness beacon We produce two main results First we show that strategic miner can strictly outperform an honest miner with just of the total stake Note that miner of this size cannot outperform an honest miner in the Proof of Work model This establishes that even with access to perfect randomness beacon incentives in Proof of Work and Proof of Stake longest chain protocols are fundamentally die rent Second we prove that strategic miner cannot outperform an honest miner with of the total stake This means that while not quite as secure as the Proof of Work regime desirable incentive properties of Proof of Work longest chain protocols can be approximately recovered via Proof of Stake with perfect randomness beacon The space of possible strategies in Proof of Stake mining game is sign cant ly Xi richer than in Proof of Work game Our main technical contribution is character ation of potentially optimal strategies for strategic miner and in particular proof that the corresponding in nite state DP admits an optimal strategy that is positive recurrent Supported by NSF CAREER Award CCF

Game theory on the block chain model for games with smart contracts Mathias Hall Andersen and Nikola Schwartz bach Department of Computer Science Aarhus University Abstract We propose model for games in which the players have shared access to block chain that allows them to deploy smart con tracts to act on their behalf This changes fundamental game theoretic assumptions about rationality since contract can commit player to act irrationally in spec ic sub games making credible otherwise non credible threats This is further complicated by considering the inter action between multiple contracts which can reason about each other This changes the nature of the game in nontrivial way as choosing which contract to play can itself be considered move in the game Our model generalizes known notions of qui libri with single con tract being equivalent to Stack el berg equilibrium and two contracts being equivalent to reverse Stack el berg equilibrium We prove num ber of bounds on the complexity of computing PE in such games with smart contracts We show that computing an PE is SPACE hard in the general case Spec ic ally in games with contracts we show that computing an PE is hard for games of imperfect information We show that computing nSPE remains SPACE hard in games of perfect information if we allow for an unbounded number of contracts We give an algorithm for computing an PE in two contract games of perfect information that runs in time where is the size of the game tree and is the number of terminal nodes Finally we conjecture the problem to be NP complete for three contracts

On Reward Sharing in Block chain Mining Pools Bur ak Can Jens Le th Hou ga ard Mohsen Pour po une July Abstract This paper proposes conceptual framework for the analysis of reward sharing schemes in mining pools such as those associated with Bitcoin The framework is centered around the reported shares in pool instead of agents and results in two new fairness criteria absolute and relative redistribution These criteria impose that the addition of share to the pool ect all previous shares in the same way either in absolute amount or in relative ratio We characterize two large classes of economically viable reward sharing schemes corresponding to each of these fairness criteria in turn We further show that the intersection of these classes brings about generalization of the well known prop or ional scheme which also leads to new characterization of the proportional scheme as corollary Keywords Block chain Bitcoin fairness mining pools resource allocation mechanism design EL Classic ation Department of Data Analytics and Digitalis ation Maastricht University the Netherlands mail can maastricht university nl This work was partially supported by the Graduate School of Business and Economics Maastricht University Economics NYU Shanghai China mail lh nyu edu and IF RO University of Copenhagen Den mark mail lh if ro ku dk This work is supported by the Center for Block chains and Electronic Markets funded by the Carlsberg Foundation under grant no CF Department of Food and Resource Economics IF RO University of Copenhagen Denmark mail mohsen if ro ku dk This work is supported by the Center for Block chains and Electronic Markets funded by the Carlsberg Foundation under grant no CF

Collective intelligence and the block chain Technology communities and social experiments Andrea Baron chell City University of London Department of Mathematics London EC HB UK The Alan Turing Institute British Library Euston Road London NW DB UK UCL Centre for Block chain Technologies University College London London UK baron chell turing ac uk Block chains are still perceived chi ey as new technology But each block chain is also community and social experiment built around social consensus Here discuss three examples showing how collective intelligence can help threat or capitalize on block chain based ecosystems They concern the immutability of smart contracts code transparency and new forms of property The examples show that more research new norms and eventually laws are needed to manage the interaction between collective behaviour and the block chain technology Insights from researchers in collective intelligence can help society rise up to the challenge For most people block chain technology is about on chain consensus And it certainly is block chain provides users with method and incentives for validating and storing value or transaction without the need to trust central authority or any other participants in the system Once approved the transaction is recorded in an open ledger that cannot be altered retroactively Since the system is trust less everyone can join the network and read write or participate within the block chain in this article Iam considering only public and permission less block chains But public block chain is not self contained universe As socio technical system its life extents behind the user base For example block chain can provide competition to existent socio economic players and it is shaped by what users do with it and eventually by the law Continuous updates and strategic decisions are therefore required to keep up with such rapidly evolving landscape meaning that block chains are not self uci ent This has two implications The rst is that block chains need governance de ning how the community of users developers and immediate stakeholders can agree on how to make decisions The second implication is that in order for those decisions to be meaning ful the governing community needs to have clear understanding of the social experiment they have launched how norms and behaviours are impacting and will be impacted by the block chain itself Considering that each block chain is also community and social experiment is key to understand the evolution and impact of the technology Yet it is often overlooked both by block chain stakeholders who may be too absorbed by the technical aspects and by researchers who have traditionally been slow to detect societal transformation The latter is unfortunate since most data are public and the challenges raised by the block chain technology even just in the form of crypto currency have been increasing steadily Here focus on three examples showing what can happen when collective intelligence meets

Reputation based Approach using Consortium Block chain for Cyber Threat Intelligence Sharing ZHANG Xiao hui MIAO Xiang hua Faculty of Information Engineering and Automation Kunming University of Science and Technology Kunming China Computer Technology Application Key Laboratory of Yunnan Province Kunming China Abstract The TI Cyber Threat Intelligence sharing and exchange is an effective method to improve the responsiveness of the protection party Block chain technology enables sharing collaboration consortium to conduct trusted TI sharing and exchange without trusted centralized institution However the distributed connectivity of the block chain based TI sharing model proposed before exposes the systems into byzantine attacks the compromised members of partner organizations will further decrease the accuracy and trust level of TI by generating false reporting To address the un balance issues of performance in speed cal ability and security this paper proposes new block chain based TI model which combines consortium block chain and distributed reputation management systems to achieve automated analysis and response of tactical threat intelligence In addition the novel consensus algorithm of consortium block chain that is fit for TI sharing and exchange introduced in this paper The new consensus algorithm is called Proof of Reputation PoR consensus which meets the requirements of transaction rate and makes the consensus in creditable network environment through constructing reputation model Finally the effectiveness and security performance of the proposed model and consensus algorithm is verified by experiments Key words cyber threat intelligence block chain consensus algorithm reputation management

The Convergence Rates of Block chain Mining Games Markov ian Approach Alejandro of re Angel Pardo David Sal as Victor Verdugo Jose Vers cha Abstract Understanding the strategic behavior of miners in block chain is of great importance for its proper operation common model for mining games considers an in nite time horizon with players optimizing asymptotic average objectives Implicitly this assumes that the asymptotic behaviors are realized at human scale times otherwise invalidating current models We study the mining game utilizing Markov Decision Processes Our approach allows us to describe the asymptotic behavior of the game in terms of the stationary distribution of the induced Markov chain We focus on model with two players under immediate release assuming two different objectives the asymptotic average reward per turn and the asymptotic percentage of obtained blocks Using tools from Markov chain analysis we show the existence of strategy achieving slow mixing times exponential in the policy parameters This result emphasizes the imperative need to understand convergence rates in mining games validating the standard models Towards this end we provide upper bounds for the mixing time of certain meaningful classes of strategies This result yields criteria for establishing that long term averaged functions are coherent as payoff functions Moreover by studying hitting times we provide criterion to validate the commons implication of considering nite states models For both considered objectives functions we provide explicit formulae depending on the stationary distribution of the underlying Markov chain In particular this shows that both mentioned objectives are not equivalent Finally we perform market share case study in particular regime of the game More precisely we show that an strategic player with as ufc ent ly large processing power can impose negative revenue on honest players Department of Mathematical Engineering Universidad de Chile
