Improving Block chain Consistency by Assigning Weights to Random Blocks Qing Zhang Xue ping Gong Hui zhong Li Hao Wu and Ji heng Zhang Department of Industrial Engineering and Decision Analytics Department of Mathematics The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology We Bank Co Ltd July Abstract Block chains based on the celebrated Nakamoto consensus protocol have shown promise in several applications including crypto currencies However these block chains have inherent cal ability limits caused by the protocols consensus properties In particular the consistency prop er ty demonstrates tight trade between block production speed and the systems security in terms of resisting adversarial attacks This paper proposes novel method Ironclad that improves block chain consistency by assigning die rent weights to randomly selected blocks We analyze the fundamental properties of our method and show that the combination of our method with Nakamoto consensus protocols can lead to sign cant improvement inconsistency direct result is that Nakamoto Ironclad can enable much faster times with normal param ter settings block production rate than Nakamoto protocol under the same security guarantee with the same proportion of malicious mining power

Always on Voting Framework for Repetitive Voting on the Block chain arad Ven gopalan and Ivan Homo lia Abstract Elections are commonly repeated over longer and ed intervals of time ranging from months to years This results in limitations on governance since elected candidates or policies red if cult to remove before the next election eventhough they might be deemed detrimental to the majority of participants When new information is available participants may decide through public deliberation to make amendments to their choice but have no opportunity to change their vote before the next elections Another issue is the peak end effect where voters judgment is based on how they felt short time before the elections instead of judging the whole period of the governance Finally there exist few issues related to centralized voting such as censorship and tampering with the results and data To address these issues we propose Always on Voting oV repetitive block chain based voting framework that allows participants to continuously vote and change elected candidates or policies without having to wait for the next election Participants are permitted to privately change their vote at any point in time while the effect of their change is manifested at the end of each epoch whose duration is shorter than the time between two main elections To thwart the peak end effect issue in epochs the ends of epochs are randomized and made unpredictable While several block chain based voting proposals had been already presented to the best of our knowledge none of them addressed the issue of re voting and peak end effect Index Terms Block chain Security Voting Peak End Effect Privacy Veria ble Delay Function cid

an at Scalable Multi Enterprise Permission ed Block chain System with Confidentiality Guarantees Mohammad Java Amiri Boon Th au Loo Div ya kant Agra wal Amr El Abba di University of Pennsylvania University of California Santa Barbara mj amiri boon loo seas penn edu agra wal amr cs ucsb edu Abstract Todays large scale data management systems need to address distributed applications con dent ali ty and cal ability requirements among set of collaborative enterprises In this paper we present an at scalable multi enterprise permission ed block chain system that guarantees conde nti ali ty an at consists of multiple enterprises where each enterprise partitions its data into multiple shards and replicates data shard on cluster of nodes to provide fault tolerance an at presents data collections that preserve the conde nti ali ty of transactions and transaction ordering schema that enforces only the necessary and suf cie nt constraints to guarantee data consistency Furthermore an at supports both data consistency and conde nti ali ty across collaboration work ow where an enterprise can parti ci pate indie rent collaboration work ow with die rent sets of enterprises Finally an at presents suite of centralized and decentralized consensus protocols to support die rent types of intra shard and cross shard transactions within or across enterprises The ex peri mental results reveal the ec ien cy of an at in processing multi shard and multi enterprise transactions

Layer Block chain Scaling Survey Cosimo guan ci Roberto Spat for cosimo guan ci mail poli mi it roberto spat for mail poli mi it Andrea Mario Verga ni andrea mario verga ni mail poli mi it June Version Abstract Block chain technology is aec ted by massive limitations in cal ability with con se que nt repercussions on performance This discussion aims at analyzing the state of the art of current available Layer II solutions to overcome these lim tat ions both focusing on theoretical and practical aspects and highlighting the main dieren ces among the examined frameworks The structure of the work is based on three major sections In particular the rst one is an introductory part about the technology the cal ability issue and Layer II as solution The second section represents the core of the discussion and consists of three if fe rent subsections each with detailed examination of the respective solution Lightning Network Plasma Rollup the analysis of each solution is based on how it ect ve key aspects of block chain technology and Layer II cal ability security decentralization privacy fees and micro payments the last two are an aly zed together given their high correlation Finally the third section includes tabular summary followed by detailed description of use case spec ic ally thought for practical evaluation of the presented frameworks The results of the work met expectations all solutions eec iv ely contribute to increasing cal ability crucial clar cation is that none of the three dominates the th ers in all possible lds of application and the consequences in adopting each are die rent Therefore the choice depends on the application context and trade must be found between the aspects previously mentioned

How to Trust Strangers Composition of Byzantine Quorum Systems Or est is Al pos Christian Cach in University of Bern University of Bern or est is al pos in uni be ch cach in in uni be ch Luca Zan olin University of Bern luca zan olin in uni be ch Abstract Trust is the basis of any distributed fault tolerant or secure system trust assumption species the failures that system such as block chain network can tolerate and determines the conditions under which it operates correctly In systems subject to Byzantine faults the trust assumption is usually specie through sets of processes that may fail together Trust has traditionally been symmetric such that all processes in the system adhere to the same global assumption about potential faults Recently asymmetric trust models have also been considered especially in the context of block chains where every participant is free to choose who to trust In both cases it is an open question how to compose trust assumptions Consider two or more systems run by different and possibly disjoint sets of participants with different assumptions about faults how can they work together This work answers this question for the rst time and offers composition rules for symmetric and for asymmetric quorum systems These rules are static and do not require interaction or agreement on the new trust assumption among the participants Moreover they ensure that if the original systems allow for running particular protocol guaranteeing cons is ten cy and availability then so will the joint system At the sametime the composed system tolerates as many faults as possible subject to the underlying consistency and availability properties Reaching consensus with asymmetric trust in the model of personal Byzantine quorum systems Los et al DISC was shown to be impossible if the trust assumptions of the processes diverge from each other With asymmetric quorum systems and by applying our composition rule we show how consensus is actually possible even with the combination of disjoint sets of processes

Revealing the Landscape of Privacy Enhancing Technologies in the Context of Data Markets for the oT Systematic Literature Review Gonzalo Mun ill Garr ido Johannes Sed meir Omer Uludag Ilia So to la oui Andre Luck ow Florian Mat the Technical University of Munich Department of Informatics Munich Germany Project Group Business Information Systems Engineering of the Fraunhofer FIT Bayreuth Germany Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich Department of Computer Science Munich Germany Abstract oT data markets in public and private institutions have become increasingly relevant in recent years because of their potential to improve data availability and unlock new business models However exchanging data in markets bears considerable challenges related to the disclosure of sensitive information Despite considerable research that has focused on die rent aspects of privacy enhancing data markets for the oT none of the solutions proposed so far seems to nd considerable practical adoption Thus this study aims to organize the state of the art solutions analyze and scope the technologies that have been suggested in this context and structure the remaining challenges to determine areas where future research is required To accomplish this goal we conducted systematic literature review on privacy enhancement in data markets for the oT covering publications dated up to July Our results indicate that most research in this area has emerged only recently and noI oT data market architecture has established itself as canonical Existing solutions frequently lack the required combination of an ony miz ation and secure computation technologies Furthermore there is no consensus on the appropriate use of block chain technology for oT data markets and low degree of leveraging existing libraries or reusing generic data market architectures We also den tied sign cant remaining challenges such as the copy problem and the recursive enforcement problem that while solutions have been suggested to some extent are often not uci ent ly addressed in proposed designs Keywords An ony miz ation Big Data Copy Problem Data Exchange Marketplace Platform Secure Computation

Constant Function Market Makers Multi Asset Trades via Convex Optimization Guillermo Anger is Aks hay Agra wal Alex Evans anger is stanford edu aks hayk stanford edu he nc gmail com Ta run Chitra Stephen Boyd ta run gauntlet network boyd stanford edu July Abstract The rise of there um and other block chains that support smart contracts has led to the creation of decentralized exchanges DEX such as Uni swap Balancer Curve Stable and Sushi Swap which enable agents to trade crypto currencies without trust ing centralized authority While traditional exchanges use order books to match and execute trades DEX are typically organized as constant function market makers CFM Ms CFM Ms accept and reject proposed trades based on the evaluation of function that depends on the proposed trade and the current reserves of the DEX For trades that involve only two assets CFM Ms are easy to understand via two functions that give the quantity of one asset that must be tendered to receive given quantity of the other and viceversa When more than two assets are being exchanged it is harder to understand the landscape of possible trades We observe that various problems of choosing multi asset trade can be formulated as convex optimization problems and can therefore be reliably and cie ntl solved

AToM Active Topology Monitoring for the Bitcoin Peer to Peer Network Federico Franz on Xavier all eras and Vanes Daz Universitat Pomp eu abra Barcelona Spain federico franz on xavier all eras vanes daz up edu Abstract Over the past decade the Bitcoin network protocol has become reference model for all modern crypto currencies While nodes in this network are known the connections among them are kept hidden as it is commonly believed that this helps protect from dean ony miz ation and low level attacks However adversaries can bypass this limitation by in fer ring connections through side channels At the same time the lack of topology information hinders the analysis of the network which is essen ti alto improve ec ien cy and security In this paper we thoroughly review network level attacks and empirically show that topology obfuscation is not an eec ti ve counter measure We then argue that the be nets of an open topology potentially outweigh its risks and propose protocol tore li ably infer and monitor connections among reachable nodes of the Bitcoin network We formally analyze our protocol and experimentally evaluate its accuracy in both trusted and un trusted settings Results show our system has low impact on the network and has precision and recall are over with up to of malicious nodes in the network

Cross Referencing Method for Scalable Public Block chain Takaaki Yana ihara and Akihiro Fuji hara Department of Information and Communication Systems Engineering Chiba Institute of Technology Tsuda numa arashi no Chiba JAPAN Abstract We previously proposed across referencing method for enabling multiple peer to peer network domains to manage their own public block chains and periodically exchanging the state of the latest ed block in the block chain with hysteresis signatures among all the domains via an upper network layer In this study we evaluated the effectiveness of our method from three theoretical viewpoints decentralization cal ability and tamper resistance We show that the performance of the entire system can be improved be cause transactions and blocks are distributed only inside the domain We argue that the transaction processing capacity will increase to transactions per second which is as much as that of VISA credit card system The capacity is also evaluated by multiplying the number of domains by the average reduction in transaction processing time due to the increase in block size and reduction in the block generation time in ter val by domain partition For tamper resistance each domain has evidence of the hysteresis signatures of the other domains in the block chain We introduce two types of tamper resistance improvement ratios as evaluation measures of tamper resistance for block chain and theoretically explain how tamper resistance is improved using our cross referencing method With our method tamper resistance improves as the num ber of domains increases The proposed system of domains are times more tamper resistant than that of domains and the capacity is times higher Wec on clude that our method enables more scalable and tamper resistant public block chain balanced with decentralization Email address qq chiba kou dai jp akihiro fuji hara chiba kou dai jp Takaaki Yana ihara and Akihiro Fuji hara Pre print submitted to Else vier July

Decentralized Basic Income Creating Wealth with On ChainS taking and Fixed Rate Protocols Ha kwan Lau and Stephen Tse Center for Brain Science Riken Institute Japan Harmony ONE Correspondence ha kwan lau riken jp and harmony one Abstract In this review we evaluate the mechanisms behind the decentralized finance protocols for generating stable passive income Currently such savings interest rates can be as high as annually payable in traditional currency values such as US dollars Therefore one can benefit from the growth of the crypto currency markets with minimal exposure to their volatility risks We aim to explain the rationale behind these savings products in simple terms The key to this puzzle is that asset deposits in crypto currency ecosystems are of intrinsic economic value as they facilitate network consensus mechanisms and automated marketplaces for lending These functions create wealth for the participants and they provide unique advantages unavailable in traditional financial systems Our review speaks to the notion of decentralized basic income analogous to universal basic income but guaranteed by financial products on block chains instead of public policies We will go through their implementations of how savings can be channeled into the staking deposits in Proof of Stake PoS protocols through fixed rate lending protocols and staking derivative tokens there by exposing savers with minimal risks We will discuss potential pitfalls assess how these protocols may behave in market cycles as well as suggest areas for further research and development Background As of year the interest rates for savings in traditional fiat currencies such as the US dollar and the Japanese yen are at historic lows at around and respectively Because of the large national debts held by these major economies some may anticipate that interest rates may remain relatively low for the near future At low interest rates the traditionally lauded act of regular household savings becomes less rewarding This may have particularly strong impact on aging populations which rely on saved money as pension income for the long term sustenance of quality of life after retirement Meanwhile during the pandemic triggered by OVID major governments have printed large amounts of money to support their economic stimulation efforts This has led some to worry that inflation the rising of nominal prices of goods will eventually become inevitable Although modern economists

Pittsburgh PA USA Department of Physics University of Michigan Ann Arbor MI USA Accepted XXX Received YY in original form ZZZ ABSTRACT The quasar targets election for the upcoming survey of the Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument DESI will bex ed for the next ve years The aim of this work is to validate the quasars election by studying the impact of imaging systematics as well as stellar and galactic contaminants and to develop procedure to mitigate them Density uc tu at ions of quasar targets are found to be related to photometric properties such as seeing and depth of the Data Release of the DESI Legacy Imaging Surveys To model this complex relation we explore machine learning algorithms Random Forest and Multi Layer Perce ptr on as an alternative to the standard linear regression Splitting the footprint of the Legacy Imaging Surveys into three regions according to photometric properties we perform an independent analysis in each region validating our method using BOSS EZ mocks The mitigation procedure is tested by comparing the angular correlation of the corrected targets election on each photometric region to the angular correlation function obtained using quasars from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey SDSS Data Release With our procedure were cover similar level of correlation between DESI quasar targets and SDSS quasars in two thirds of the total footprint and we show that the excess of correlation in the remaining area is due to stellar contamination which should be removed with DESI spectroscopic data We derive the Limber parameters in our three imaging regions and compare them to previous measurements from SDSS and the dF QSO Redshift Survey Keywords survey cosmology observations large scale structures dark energy

Communicating Visualization without Visuals Investigation of Visualization Alternative Text for People with Visual Impairments Crescent Jung hub ham Mehta Atharva Kul karn Yu hang Zhao and Yea Seu Kim Abstract Alternative text is critical in communicating graphics to people who are blind or have low vision Especially for graphics that contain rich information such as visualization poorly written or an absence of alternative texts can worsen the information access inequality for people with visual impairments In this work we consolidate existing guidelines and survey current practices to inspect to what extent current practices and recommendations are aligned Then to gain more insight into what people want in visualization alternative texts we interviewed people with visual impairments regarding their experience with visualization and their information needs in alternative texts The study dings suggest that participants actively try to construct animage of visualization in their head while listening to alternative texts and wish to carryout visualization tasks retrieve spec ic values as sighted viewers would The study also provides ample support for the need to reference the underlying data instead of visual elements to reduce users cognitive burden Informed by the study we provide set of recommendations to compose an informative alternative text Index Terms accessible visualization assist ive technologies alternative text for graphics

Almost quasi Sasaki an manifolds equipped with skew symmetric connection Gala ev Submitted by Editor name Saratov State University ul Astrakhan kaya Saratov Russia Received June Abstract On sub Riemann ian manifold connection with skew symmetric torsion is de ned as the unique connection from the class of connections that has this property Two cases are considered separately sub Riemann ian structure of even rank and sub Riemann ian structure of odd rank The resulting connection called the canonical connection is not metric connection in the case when the sub Riemann ian structure is of even rank The structure of an almost quasi Sasaki an manifold is de ned as an almost contact metric structure of odd rank that satis es additional requirements Namely it is required that the canonical connection is metric connection and that the trans versa structure is Ka hler structure Both the quasi Sasaki an structure and the more general almost contact metric structure called an almost quasi Sasaki an structure satisfy these requirements uci ent conditions are found for an almost quasi Sasaki an manifold to be an Einstein manifold Keywords and phrases Sub Riemann ian manifold of contact type almost contact metric manifold inner connection almost quasi Sasaki an manifold skew symmetric connection

Anisotropic diu sion of ellipsoidal tracers in micro swimmer suspensions Henrik Nord anger Alexander Moro zo and Jo akim Sten ham mar Division of Physical Chemistry Lund University Lund Sweden SUPA School of Physics and Astronomy The University of Edinburgh James Clerk Maxwell Building Peter Guthrie Tait Road Edinburgh EH FD United Kingdom Dated August Tracer particles immersed in suspensions of biological micro swimmers such as coli or Chl amy do monas display phenomena unseen in conventional equilibrium systems including strongly en han ced diu siv it relative to the Brownian value and non Gaussian displacement statistics In dilute dimensional suspensions these phenomena have typically been explained by the hydro dynamic advection of point tracers by isolated micro swimmers while at higher concentrations correlations between pusher micro swimmers such as coli can increase the eec ti ve diu siv it even further Anisotropic tracers in active suspensions can be expected to exhibit even more complex behaviour than spherical ones due to the presence of nontrivial translation rotation coupling Using large scale lattice Bolt mann simulations of model micro swimmers described by extended force dipoles we study the motion of ellipsoidal point tracers immersed in dimensional micro swimmer sus pen ions We nd that the rotational diu siv it of tracers is much less aec ted by swimmer swimmer correlations than the translational diu siv it We furthermore study the anisotropic translational diu sion in the particle frame and nd that in pusher suspensions the diu siv it along the ellipsoid major axis is higher than in the direction perpendicular to it albeit with smaller ratio than for Brownian diu sion Thus we nd that far el hydrodynamics cannot account for the anomalous coupling between translation and rotation observed in experiments as was recently proposed Fi ally we study the probability distributions PDFs of translational and rotational displacements In accordance with experimental observations for short observation times we observe strongly non Gaussian PDFs that collapse when re scaled with their variance which we attribute to the ballistic nature of tracer motion at short times

Quark ivers Function at Small Spin Dependent Odder on and the Sub ikon al Evolution Yuri Kov che gov and Gabriel Santiago Department of Physics The Ohio State University Columbus OH USA We apply the formalism developed earlier for studying transverse momentum dependent part on distribution functions MDs at small Bjork en to construct the small asymptotic of the quarkS ivers function First we explicitly construct the complete fundamental polarized Wilson line operator to sub sub ikon al order this object can be used to study variety of quark MDs at small We then express the quark ivers function in terms of dipole scattering amplitudes containing various components of the polarized Wilson line and show that the dominant ikon al term which contributes to the quark ivers function at small is the spin dependent odder on con ming the recent results of Dong Zheng and Zhou Our conclusion is also similar to the case of the gluonS ivers function derived by Boer Ec he var ria Mulder and Zhou see also We also analyze the sub ikon al corrections to the quark ivers function using the constructed polarized Wilson line operator We derive new small evolution equations re summing double logarithmic powers of ln with the strong coupling constant We solve the corresponding novel evolution equations in the large Nc limit obtaining sub ikon al correction to the spin dependent odder on contribution We conclude that the quarkS ivers function at small receives contributions from two terms and is given by cid cid with the function CO kT varying slowly with and the ellipsis denoting the sub asymptotic and sub sub ikon al order corrections CONTENTS

Quantization of electromagnetic scattering from is per sive dielectric particles based on modal expansion of the polarization Carlo Forestier Department of Electrical Engineering and Information Technology Universit degli Studi di Napoli Federico II via Claudio Napoli Italy Giovanni Mia no Department of Electrical Engineering and Information Technology Universit degli Studi di Napoli Federico II via Claudio Napoli Italy An approach to the quantization of the electromagnetic scattering from is per sive dielectric of nite size in the Heisenberg picture is presented It is based on the combination of the Hutt ner Barnett model for the polarization and modal expansion of the polarization el The polarization is described as matter el of coherent harmonic oscillators that is linearly coupled to the ele tro magnetic el and to dissipative bath el Both the matter el and the bath el are represented in terms of the static longitudinal and transverse modes of the particle which are basis for the solenoid al vector lds de ned in the region occupied by the particle The Coulomb gauge is applied the longitudinal electric el is expressed in terms of the matter el and the transverse electromagnetic el is expanded in terms of transverse plane wave modes The He is en berg equations of motion for the coordinate operators of the matter el are obtained in closed form As expected the structure of these equations is the same of the classical electromagnetic scattering problem The initial states of the bath radiation and matter come into play through driving el operator Even if the equations for the longitudinal and transverse coordinate operators are coupled few longitudinal and transverse modes are needed for particles with size of the same order of the characteristic length accounting for the strength of the coupling between the matter and electromagnetic el Eventually the scattered electric el operator is expressed in terms of the driving el operators by means of classical yad operator

AM DET TOOL FOR MITOTIC CELL DETECTION IN HIS TO PATHOLOGY SLIDES TECHNICAL REPORT Walt Williams James Hall Auto ML Image Lab Auto ML Image Lab Microsoft Research Microsoft Research Cambridge MA Cambridge MA williams microsoft com James Hall microsoft com August ABSTRACT Breast Cancer is the most prevalent cancer in the world The World Health Organization reports that the disease still affects sign cant portion of the developing world citing increased mortality rates in the majority of low to middle income countries The most popular protocol pathologists use for diagnosing breast cancer is the Nottingham grading system which grades the proliferation of tumors based on major criteria the most important of them being mitotic cell count The way in which pathologists evaluate mitotic cell count is to subjectively and qualitatively analyze cells present in stained slides of tissue and make decision on its mitotic state is it mitotic or not This process is extremely in efc ent and tiring for pathologists and so an efc ent accurate and fully automated tool to aid with the diagnosis is extremely desirable Fortunately creating such tool is made sign cant ly easier with the Auto ML tool available from Microsoft Azure however to the best of our knowledge the Auto ML tool has never been formally evaluated for use in mitotic cell detection in his to pathology images This paper serves as an evaluation of the Auto ML tool for this purpose and will provide rst look on how the tool handles this challenging problem All code is available at https it hub com Walt AF Williams AM Det Keywords Object Detection Digital Pathology Machine Learning Breast Cancer

horseshoe particles being four to ve times more likely to survive than Trojans From the end state statistics we constrain the existence of planet es mal sized objects originally in co orbital lib ration ding that typically such planetesimals and no more than conde ce could have been present Our simulations also suggest that episodic variations in the terrestrial orbital eccentricity may have caused bulk escape of co orbitals though variations large enough to generate such episodes are statistically unlikely We then consider the orbital evolution of co orbital asteroids of sizes down toD under the Yar kov skye ect and nd that objects with km should escape over Gyr with the smallest asteroids escaping after Myr Further we test whether Earths co orbital region may be populated by asteroids arriving via outward Yar kov sky drift as conjectured by Zhou et al We nd this is nine cie nt process as planetary close encounters rapidly scatter the orbits far from Earths and towards the asteroid belt Finally we discuss how the des tabi lising action of Yar kov sky may be mitigated through spin state evolution or late collision al com min uti on of large parent asteroids Key words for the UW colors colored stripes in the plots sorted by CIEL Ch hue angle Abstract Peoples associations between colors and concepts in en ce their ability to interpret the meanings of colors in information visualization Previous work has suggested such effects are limited to concepts that have strong spec ic associations with colors However although concept may not be strongly associated with any colors its mapping can be disambiguate in the context of other concepts in an encoding system We articulate this view in semantic disc rim inability theory general framework for understanding Semantic disc rim inability theory posits that the capacity for semantic disc rim inability for set of concepts is constrained by the difference between the feature concept association distributions across the concepts in the set We de ne formal properties of this theory and test its implications in two experiments The results show that the capacity to produce semantically disc rim in able colors for sets of concepts was indeed constrained by the statistical distance between color concept association distributions Experiment Moreover people could interpret meanings of colors in bar graphs insofar as the colors were semantically disc rim in able even for concepts previously considered non color able Experiment The results suggest that colors are more robust for visual communication than previously thought Index Terms Visual Reasoning Information Visualization Visual Communication Visual Encoding Color Cognition

Shock wave like emission of spin waves induced by inter facial zy alo shins kii oriya interaction Hong Xia Ha or an Chen Chang yeon Won Hai bin Zhao and Yi zheng Wu Department of Physics State Key Laboratory of Surface Physics Fu dan University China Key Laboratory of Micro and Nano Photon ic Structures Ministry of Education and Shanghai Ultra precision Optical Manufacturing Engineering Research Center Department of Optical Science and Engineering Fu dan University China Department of Physics Kyung Hee University Seoul South Korea Shanghai Research Center for Quantum Sciences Shanghai China Abstract We investigated spin wave SW propagation and emission in thin film systems with strong inter facial zy alo shins kii oriya interaction MI utilizing micro magnetic simulation The effect of MI on SW propagation is analogous to the flow of magnetic medium leading to the spin Doppler effect and spin polarized current can enhance or suppress it It is demonstrated that for Doppler velocity exceeding critical value shock wave like emission of SW with cone shape emerges from magnetically irregular point as the cone apex The cone angle is quantitatively determined by the MI induced Doppler velocity Combining the inter facial MI and the spin polarized current constant SW emission by static source is demonstrated which provides promising route to efficiently generate SW with unable frequency

Testing the consistency of propagation between light and heavy cosmic ray nuclei Yu Wang Juan Wu and Wei Cheng Long School of Mathematics and Physics China University of Geosciences Wuhan China One of the fundamental issues in cosmic ray physics is to explain the nature of cosmic ray acc el ration and propagation mechanisms Thanks to the precise cosmic ray data measured by recent space experiments we are able to investigate the cosmic ray acceleration and propagation mod els more comprehensively and reliably In this paper we combine the secondary to primary ratios and the primary spectra measured by PAMELA AMS ACE CRIS and Voyager to constrain the cosmic ray source and transport parameters The study shows that the data yield high energy diu sion slope The species obtain looser constraint on The overlap infers the heavy and light particles can give compatible results at high energies Meanwhile at low energies sign cant disagreements exist between the heavy and light elements The ratio requires much larger diu sion slope variation around Vor stronger Alf ven velocity vA than the low mass data This indicates that the heavy and light parti cles may sue die rent low energy transport behaviors in Galaxy However better understanding on the consistency inconsistency between the heavy and light relies on more precise cross sections better constraints on correlations in systematic errors of data and more accurate description for Solar modulation during the reversal period of HM PAC numbers Keywords cosmic ray propagation acceleration

Angle dependent electron conn ment in graph ene moire super lattices Francisco Sanchez Ochoa Andres otello Mendez and Cecilia No guez Instituto de sica Universidad Nacional Autonoma de Mexico Apart do Postal Cd de Mexico Mexico Dated August In graph ene moire super lattices electronic interactions between layers are mostly hidden as band structures get crowded because of folding making their interpretation cumbersome Here the evo lu tion of the electronic band structure as function of the inter layer rotation angle is studied using Density Functional Theory followed by unfolding bands and then comparing them to their corre pond ing individual components We observe interactions at regions not theoretically elucidated so far where for small inter layer angles gaps turn into discrete like states that are evenly spaced in energy We nd that Vp attractive interactions between out of plane orbitals from die rent layers are responsible for the disc ret iz ation Furthermore when the inter layer angle becomes small these discrete evenly spaced states have energy dieren ces comparable to graph ene phonons Thus they might be relevant to explain electron ph on on assisted eec ts which have been experimentally observed in graph ene moire super lattices

Model choice and parameter inference in controlled branching processes Miguel Gonzalez Carmen Min esa In es del Puerto August Abstract Our purpose is to estimate the posterior distribution of the parameters of interest for controlled branching processes CB Ps without prior knowledge of the maximum number of spring that an individual can give birth to and without explicit likelihood calculations We consider that only the population sizes at each generation and at least the number of progenitors of the last generation are observed but the number of spring produced by any individual at any generation is unknown The proposed approach is two fold Firstly to estimate the maximum progeny per individual we make use of an approximate Bayesian computation ABC algorithm for model choice and based on sequential importance sam ling with the raw data Secondly given such an estimate and taking advantage of the simulated values of the previous stage we approximate the posterior distribution of the main parameters of BP by applying the rejection ABC algorithm with an appr opr ate summary statistic and post processing adjustment The accuracy of the proposed method is illustrated by means of simulated examples developed with the statistical soft ware Moreover we apply the methodology to two real datasets describing populations with logistic growth To this end die rent population growth models based on CB Ps are proposed for the rst time Keywords controlled branching process Bayesian analysis ABC methodology sequential Monte Carlo summary statistics logistic Quantum Induced Broadening Challenge For Cosmic Neutrino Background Discovery Shmuel Nuss in ov and Zo har Nuss in ov School of Physics and Astronomy Tel Aviv University Tel Aviv Israel Department of Physics Washington University St Louis MO USA Dated August recent pre print by Che pes et al pointed out that the zero point motion of Tritium atoms bound to Graph ene may blur the measured energies of electrons Smearing due to zero point motion is well known Such an eec features in studies of the spectrum expected in experiments like KATRIN using diatomic Tritium The recent pre print may however challenge new planned experiments seeking to discover the Cosmic Neutrino Background NB neutrinos and or other neutrinos of masses smaller than eV which plan to use Tritium ads or bed on to Graph ene or other materials Our paper cl aries these issues and examines the more general problem of smearing induced by quantum uncertainty Wend that the eec to fC he pes he al is reduced considerably The importance of the chemical evolution of the Hatom hosting the Tritium nucleus into tightly bound neutral He atom is emphasized We estimate the excess blurring caused by the dense spectrum near the lowest state of the Graph ene or other hosts of the Tritium atom generated by the electronic response to the sudden escape of the electron Our analysis suggests yet larger eec ts and di cul ties facing many experiments searching for small mass neutrinos We speculate on possible experimental setup which could minimize quantum broadening

Bran Webs and Quivers Shi Cheng Faculty of Physics University of Warsaw ul Pasteur Warsaw Poland mail cheng fu edu pl Abstract We discuss the eec ti ve hern Simons levels for gauge theories and their relations to the relative angles between NS bran and NS bran We nd that turning on real masses for chiral multiple ts leads to various equivalent bran webs that are related yipping the sign of mass parameters This ip can be interpreted as mirror symmetry for abelian theories Each of these webs has corresponding mathematical quiver structure We check the equivalence of vortex partition functions for these bran webs by implementing topological vertex method In addition we compute the vortex partition functions of non abelian theories with gauge group and nd the associated quiver structures and bran webs We nd that on Higgs branch non abelian bran webs are broken to abelian bran webs with gauge group We also discuss the Oo guri afa in variants for non abelian theories and the movement of vor bran es that leads to equivalent bran webs

Alignment of Tract graph Streamlines using Deformation Transfer via Parallel Transport Andrew Liza raga David Lee Antoni Ku bic ki shish Sahib Elvis Nunez Katherine arr and Shan tan Joshi Ah manson Lovelace Brain Mapping Center Department of Neurology UCLA Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering UCLA Department of Bioengineering UCLA Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences UCLA Andrew Liza raga med net ucla edu dale med net ucla edu aku bic ki ucla edu sahib ucla edu elvis nunez ucla edu kn arr med net ucla edu joshi ucla edu Abstract We present geometric framework for aligning white matter ber tracts By registering ber tracts between brains one expects to see overlap of anatomical structures that often provide meaningful com paris on across subjects However the geometry of white matter tracts is highly heterogeneous and ding direct tract correspondence across multiple individuals remains challenging problem We present novel deformation metric between tracts that allows one to compare tracts while simultaneously obtaining registration To accomplish this ber tracts are represented by an intrinsic mean along with the deformation lds represented by tangent vectors from the mean In this setting one can determine parallel transport between tracts and then register cor responding tangent vectors We present the results of bundle alignment on population of healthy adult subjects

Visual Analysis of Hyper properties for Understanding Model Checking Results Tom Hora Nor in Coen en Niklas Metzger Christopher Hahn Tamar aFl emi sch Julian Mendez Dennis imov Bernd Fink be in er and Rai mun dDa chse lt Fig HYPER VIS provides linked interactive views with highlighting mechanisms for analyzing counterexamples of hyper properties Abstract Model checkers provide algorithms for proving that mathematical model of systems at is esa given spec cation In case of violation counterexample that shows the erroneous behavior is returned Understanding these counterexamples is challenging especially for hyper property spec cations spec cations that relate multiple executions of system to each other We aim to facilitate the visual analysis of such counterexamples through our HYPER VIS tool which provides interactive visualization of the given model spec cation and counterexample Within an iterative and interdisciplinary design process we developed visualization solutions that can effectively communicate the core aspects of the model checking result Spec ic ally we introduce graphical representations of binary values for improving pattern recognition color encoding for better indicating related aspects visually enhanced textual descriptions as well as extensive cross view highlighting mechanisms Further through an underlying causal analysis of the counterexample we are also able to identify values that contributed to the violation and use this knowledge for both improved encoding and highlighting Finally the analyst can modify both the spec cation of the hyper property and the system directly within HYPER VIS and initiate the model checking of the new version In combination these features notably support the analyst in understanding the error leading to the counterexample as well as iterating the provided system and spec cation We ran multiple case studies with HYPER VIS and tested it with domain experts in qualitative feedback sessions The participants positive feedback con rms the considerable improvement over the manual text based status quo and the value of the tool for explaining hyper properties Index Terms Analyzing Counterexamples Hyper properties Multiple Coordinate Views Explain able Formal Methods

Melbourne Park ville VIC Australia st NASA Hubble Fellow ABSTRACT The presence of excess scatter in the Ly forest at together with the existence of sporadic extended opaque Gunn Peterson troughs has started to provide robust evidence for late end of hydrogen re ionisation However low data quality and systematic uncertainties complicate the use of Ly transmission as precision probe of re ionisation send stages In this paper we assemble sample of quasar sight lines at with high signal to noise ratios of per km spectral pixel relying largely on the new QR quasar sample QR is large program on VLT Shooter which obtained deep SNR per pixel spectra of quasars at We carefully account for systematics in continuum reconstruction instrumentation and contamination by damped Ly systems We present improved measurements of the meanLy transmission over Using all known systematics in forward modelling analysis wend excellent agreement between the observed Ly transmission distributions and the homogeneous UVB simulations Sherwood and Nyx up to and mild tension at Homogeneous UVB models are ruled out by excess Ly transmission scatter at with high conde ce Our results indicate that re ionisation related uc tu at ions whether in the UVB residual neutral hydrogen fraction and or IGM temperature persist in the intergalactic medium until Gyr after the Big Bang This is further evidence for late end tore ionisation Key words dark ages re ionisation rst stars quasars absorption lines intergalactic medium large scale structure of Universe mail bosman pia de The Authors

Draft version August Pre print typeset using LATEX style AS TeX PER REVISITED NO STRONG MID INFRARED EMISSION FEATURES AND NO EVIDENCE FOR STELLAR SUB STELLAR COMPANIONS we th Sankar email wet has nkr ucla edu Department of Physics and Astronomy University of California Los Angeles CA USA Carl Melis email melis ucsd edu Center for Astrophysics and Space Sciences University of California San Diego CA USA Beth Klein Department of Physics and Astronomy University of California Los Angeles CA USA Fulton NASA Exoplanet Science Institute Caltech PAC Pasadena CA USA st Zuckerman Department of Physics and Astronomy University of California Los Angeles CA USA In seok Song Department of Physics and Astronomy University of Georgia Athens GA USA Andrew Howard California Institute of Technology Pasadena CA USA ABSTRACT We present characterization of the planetary system architecture for Per the dustiest main sequence star known with fractional infrared luminosity of Far infrared imaging photo me try con rms the existence of an outer planetary system dust population with black body temperature of Mid infrared spectroscopy probing the previously den tied inner planetary system dust population does not detect any obvious solid state emission features suggesting either large grain sizes that mute such emission and or grain compositions dominated by species like amorphous carbon and metallic iron which do not produce such features In the latter case the presence of sign cant quantities of iron rich material could be indicative of the active formation of Mercury like planet around Per In any event the absence of solid state emission features is very unusual among main sequence stars with copious amounts of warm orbiting dust particles we know of no other such star whose mid infrared spectrum lacks such features Combined radial velocity monitoring and adaptive optics imaging nd no evidence for stellar sub stellar companions within several hundred AU of Per

BIG ROC BOOSTING IMAGE GENERATION VIA RO BUST CLASS FIER Roy Ganz Michael El ad Department of Electrical Engineering Department of Computer Science Tech ni on Israel Institute of Technology Tech ni on Israel Institute of Technology Tech ni on City Haifa Israel Tech ni on City Haifa Israel ganz campus tech ni on ac il el ad cs tech ni on ac il Figure BIG RoC results left images of classes birds cars and trucks generated by Big GAN rocket al trained on CI FAR Right the enhanced versions of these images attained by the proposed BIG RoC algorithm ABSTRACT The interest of the machine learning community in image synthesis has grown sign cant ly in recent years with the introduction of wide range of deep gen erat ive models and means for training them Such machines ultimate goal is to match the distributions of the given training images and the synthesized ones In this work we propose general model agnostic technique for improving the image quality and the distribution del it of generated images obtained by any generative model Our method termed BIG RoC boosting image generation via robust classier is based on post processing procedure via the guidance of given robust classier and without need for additional training of the genera ti ve model Given synthesized image we propose to update it through projected gradient steps over the robust classier in an attempt to rene its recognition We demonstrate this post processing algorithm on various image synthesis methods and show sign cant improvement of the generated images both quantitatively and qualitatively

Audio Spectral Enhancement Leveraging Auto encoders for Low Latency Reconstruction of Long Lossy Audio Sequences Darshan Desh pan de darshan desh pan de student th do mal org Department of Computer Engineering Th do mal Shah ani Engineering College Mumbai University Mumbai India Harsha vardhan Abi chan dani harsha vardhan abi chan dani student th do mal org Department of Computer Engineering Th do mal Shah ani Engineering College Mumbai University Mumbai India Editor Abstract With active research in audio compression techniques yielding substantial breakthroughs spectral reconstruction of low quality audio waves remains less indulged topic In this paper we propose novel approach for reconstructing higher frequencies from consider ably longer sequences of low quality MP audio waves Our technique involves in painting audio spec tro grams with residual ly stacked auto encoder blocks by manipulating in divi al amplitude and phase values in relation to perceptual dieren ces Our architecture presents several bottlenecks while preserving the spectral structure of the audio wave via skip connections We also compare several task metrics and demonstrate our visual guide to loss selection Moreover we show how to leverage dieren ti al quantization techniques to reduce the initial model size by more than half while simultaneously reducing inference time which is crucial in real world applications Keywords Audio Reconstruction Audio Enhancement Auto encoders Quantization Short Time Fourier Transform

Online Bootstrap Inference For Policy Evaluation In Reinforcement Learning Prat ik Ram prasad Yuan tong Li Zhuo ran Yang Zhao ran Wang Will Wei Sun Guang Cheng August Abstract The recent emergence of reinforcement learning has created demand for robust statistical inference methods for the parameter estimates computed using these al gor it hms Existing methods for statistical inference in online learning are restricted to settings involving independently sampled observations while existing statistical inference methods in reinforcement learning RL are limited to the batch setting The online bootstrap is ex ib lean dec ent approach for statistical inference in lin ear stochastic approximation algorithms but its ecac in settings involving Markov noise such as RL has yet to be explored In this paper we study the use of the online bootstrap method for statistical inference in RL In particular we focus on the tem oral die rence TD learning and Gradient TD TD learning algorithms which are themselves special instances of linear stochastic approximation under Markov noise The method is shown to be distribution ally consistent for statistical inference in policy evaluation and numerical experiments are included to demonstrate the ef fec ti ve ness of this algorithm at statistical inference tasks across range of real RL environments Keywords Asymptotic Normality Multiplier Bootstrap Reinforcement Learning Statist cal Inference Stochastic Approximation Department of Statistics Purdue University Department of Operations Research and Financial Engineering Princeton University Department of Industrial Engineering and Management Sciences Northwestern University Kr anne rt School of Management Purdue University Corresponding author Email sun purdue edu

Science Bilbao Spain Ultra fast manipulation of the magnetic state of matter bears great potential for future information technologies While de magnet is ation in ferro magnets is governed by dissipation of angular momentum materials with multiple spin sub lattices anti ferro magnets can allow direct angular momentum transfer between opposing spins promising faster functionality In lanthanides magnetic exchange is mediated indirectly through the conduction electrons the Ruder man Kitt elK as yaY os ida interaction RK KY and the effect of such conditions on direct spin transfer processes is largely unexplored Here we investigate ultra fast magnetization dynamics in anti ferro magnets and systematically vary the occupation there by altering the magnitude of RK KY By combining time resolved soft ray diffraction with ab in it io calculations we find that the rate of direct transfer between opposing moments is directly determined by the magnitude of RK KY Given the high sensitivity of RK KY to the conduction electrons our results offer novel approach for fine tuning the speed of magnetic devices Lanthanides are increasingly important in technology because their spin moments reach exceptionally large sizes compared to those of transition metals For applications involving ultra fast spin dynamics however the localized nature of magnetism poses an additional Meta Reinforcement Learning in Broad and Non Parametric Environments Zhen shan Bing Lukas Knak Department of Informatics Department of Informatics Technical University of Munich Technical University of Munich Munich Germany Munich Germany bing in tum de lukas knak tum de Fabric Oliver Robin Kai Huang Department of Informatics School of Data and Computer Science Technical University of Munich SunY at sen University Munich Germany Guangzhou China morin in tum de huang mail sy su edu cn Alois Knoll Technical University of Munich Munich Germany knoll in tum de Abstract Recent state of the art art ici al agents lack the ability to adapt rapidly to new tasks as they are trained exclusively for spec ic objectives and require massive amounts of interaction to learn new skills Meta reinforcement learning meta RL addresses this challenge by leveraging knowledge learned from training tasks to perform well in previously unseen tasks However current meta RL approaches limit themselves to narrow parametric task distributions ignoring qualitative differences between tasks that occur in the real world In this paper we introduce TI GR Task Inference based meta RL algorithm using Gaussian mixture models MM and gated Recurrent units designed for tasks in non parametric environments We employ generative model involving aGM to capture the multi modality of the tasks We de couple the policy training from the task inference learning and efc ent ly train the inference mechanism on the basis of an unsupervised reconstruction objective We provide benchmark with qualitatively distinct tasks based on the half cheetah environment and demonstrate the superior performance of TI GR compared to state of the art meta RL approaches in terms of sample efc ien cy times faster asymptotic performance and applicability in non parametric environments with zero shot adaptation The videos can be viewed at https video view site wi site com ti gr

Estimating population al average hazard ratios in the presence of un measured confounding Pablo Mart nez ambl or Todd MacKenzie and James Malley Department of Anesthesiology Dartmouth Hitchcock Medical Center NH USA Department of Biomedical Data Science Geisel School of Medicine at Dartmouth NH USA The Dartmouth Institute for Health Policy and Clinical Practice NH USA Abstract The Cox regression model and its associated hazard ratio HR are frequently used for summarizing the eec of treatments on time to event outcomes However the HRs interpretation strongly depends on the assumed underlying survival model The challenge of interpreting the HR has been the focus of number of recent works Besides several alternative measures have been proposed in order to deal with these concerns The marginal Cox regression models include an ident able hazard ratio without individual but population al causal interpretation In this work we study the properties of one particular marginal Cox regression model and consider its es tima tion in the presence of omitted con founder We prove the large sample consistency of an estimation score which allows non binary treatments Our Monte Carlo imu lat ions suggest that nite sample behavior of the procedure is adequate The studied estimator is more robust than its competitors for weak instruments although it is slightly more biased for large eec ts of the treatment The practical use of the pre sent ed techniques is illustrated through real practical example using data from the vascular quality initiative registry The used code is provided as Supplementary Material Keywords Cox regression model Population al average hazard ratio Mis specie models Omitted co variate Causal eec Correspondence to Pablo Mart nez ambl or Lebanon Street Suite in man Box Lebanon NH USA mail Pablo Martinez ambl or hitchcock org

Mean square Analysis of the NLM Algorithm are Al Naf four Muhammad Mo in ud in and num Ali Abstract This work presents novel approach to the mean square analysis of the normalized least mean squares NLM algorithm for circular complex colored Gaussian inputs The analysis is based on the derivation of closed form expression for the Cumulative Distribution Function CD of random variables of the form where is an isotropic vector and and are diagonal matrices and using that to derive some moments of these variables These moments in turn completely characterize the mean square behavior of the NLM algorithm in explicit closed form expressions Spec ic ally the transient steady state and tracking mean square behavior of the NLM algorithm is studied

Knowledge for warmer world patent analysis of climate change adaptation technologies Kerstin tte Su Jung ee Suga ndh Sri vast av Oxford Martin Programme on Technological and Economic Change University of Oxford UK Institute for New Economic Thinking at the Oxford Martin School University of Oxford UK Faculty of Business Administration and Economics University of Bielefeld Germany Smith School of Enterprise and Environment University of Oxford UK August Technologies help adapt to climate change but little systematic research about these technologies and their interaction with mitigation exists We identify climate change adaptation technologies CATs in US patent data to study the technological frontier in adaptation We nd that patenting in CATs was roughly stagnant over the past decades CATs form two main clusters science intensive CATs related to agriculture health and monitoring technologies and engineering based for coastal water and infrastructure adaptation of CATs help in climate change mitigation and we infer that syne gies can be maximized through well designed policy CATs rely more on public than other inventions and CC AT patents are citing more science over time indicating growing relevance of research as knowledge source for innovation Policymakers can use these results to get greater clarity on where support for CATs can be directed Corresponding author kerstin hotte oxford martin ox ac uk OR CiD KH SJ

Eec of Inter facial Defects on the Electronic Properties of MoS Based Lateral He ero phase Junctions Mohammad Bah mani Mahdi Gh or bani Asl and Thomas Frauen heim cid Bremen Center for Computational Materials Science BC CMS Department of Physics Bremen University Bremen Germany Institute of Ion Beam Physics and Materials Research Helmholtz Zentrum Dresden Ross end orf Dresden Germany Beijing Computational Science Research Center CSR Beijing China Shenzhen Computational Science and Applied Research Institute Shenzhen China The coexistence of semiconducting and metallic phases of MoS mono layers have further pushed their strong potential for applications in the next generation of ele tronic devices based on the two dimensional lateral he ero junctions Structural defects have considerable eec ts on the properties of these devices In particular the interfaces of two phases are often imperfect and may contain numerous vacancies created by phase engineering techniques under the electron beam Here the transport behaviors of the he ter oj unc ions in the existence of point defects are explored by means of rst principles calculations and non equilibrium Greens function approach While vacancies in semiconducting MoS act as scattering centers their presence at the interface improves the ow of the charge carriers In the case of the current has been increased by two orders of magnitude Mo in comparison to the perfect device The enhancement of transmission was explained by changes in the electronic densities at the interface which open new transport channels for electron conduction bah mani uni bremen de mahdi gh or bani hz dr de cid frauen heim uni bremen de

ASYMPTOTIC EXPANSIONS ABOUT INFINITY FOR SOLUTIONS OF NONLINEAR DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS WITH COHERENTLY DECAYING FORCING FUNCTIONS LU AN HO ANG Abstract This paper studies in ne details the long time asymptotic behavior of de ca ying solutions of general class of dissipative systems of nonlinear dieren ti al equations in complex Euclidean spaces The forcing functions decay as time tends to inn it in coherent way expressed by combinations of the exponential power logarithmic and iterated logarithmic functions The decay may contain sinusoidal oscillations not only in time but also in the logarithm and iterated logarithm of time It is proved that the decaying solutions admit corresponding asymptotic expansions which can be constructed concretely In the case of the real Euclidean spaces the real valued decaying solutions are proved to admit real valued asymptotic expansions Our results unite and extend the theory investigated in many previous works Contents

Asymptotic consensus in the He se lmann Krause model with self delay and non symmetric interaction weights Jan Has kov ec Abstract We derive uci ent condition for asymptotic oc king in He se lmann Krause type model with self delay also called reaction delay and with non symmetric interaction weights The condition is explicit and simply veria ble requiring the delay length to be uci ent ly small with respect to the initial interaction strength between the agents We show that the convergence to consensus is exponential with rate calculable as unique solution of transcendental equation The proof is based on decay estimate for the group diameter combined with variant of the Gr on wall Hala nay inequality Keywords He se lmann Krause model self delay asymptotic consensus Gr on wall Hala nay inequality MR Subject Classic ation

Improving Inference from Simple Instruments through Compliance Estimation Stephen Co us sens Jan Spies Columbia University Stanford University August Comments welcome Abstract Instrumental variables IV regression is widely used to estimate causal treatment eec ts in settings where receipt of treatment is not fully random but there exists an instrument that generates exogenous variation in treatment exposure While IV can recover consistent treat men te ect estimates they are often noisy Building upon earlier work in biostatistics Joe and Bren singer and relating to an evolving literature in econometrics including bad eet al Huntington Klein Bor us yak and Hull we study how to improve the ec ien cy of IV estimates by exploiting the predictable variation in the strength of the instrument In the case where both the treatment and instrument are binary and the instrument is independent of baseline co variate we study weighting each observation according to its estimated compliance that is its conditional probability of being aec ted by the instrument which we motivate from constrained solution of the rst stage prediction problem implicit to IV The resulting est mat or can leverage machine learning to estimate compliance as function of baseline co variate We derive the large sample properties of spec ic implementation of weighted IV estimator in the potential outcomes and local average treatment eec LATE frameworks and provide tools for inference that remain valid even when the weights are estimated non parametric ally With both theoretical results and simulation study we demonstrate that compliance weighting meaningfully reduces the variance of IV estimates when rst stage heterogeneity is present and that this improvement often outweighs any die rence between the compliance weighted and un weighted IV es tim and These results suggest that in variety of applied settings the precision of IV estimates can be substantially improved by incorporating compliance estimation Stephen Co us sens Mailman School of Public Health Columbia University sc cum columbia edu Jan Spies Graduate School of Business Stanford University spies stanford edu We thank Kiri ll Bor us yak Amanda Kowal ski Greg Lewis and Ashes Ram bach an for helpful comments

The Asymptotic Frequency of Stochastic Oscillators pre print Zachary Adams Max Planck Institute for Mathematics in the Sciences Abstract We study stochastic perturbations of ODE with stable limit cycles referred to as stochastic oscillators and investigate the response of the asymptotic in time frequency of oscillations to changing noise amplitude Unlike previous studies we do not restrict our attention to the small noise limit and account for the fact that large deviation events may push the system out of its oscillator regime To do so we consider stochastic oscillators conditioned on their remaining in an oscillator regime for all time This leads us to use the theory of quasi ergo dic measures and de ne quasi asymptotic frequencies as conditional long time average frequencies We show that quasi asymptotic frequencies always exist though they may or may not be observable in practice Our discussion recovers previous results on stochastic oscillators in the literature In particular existing results imply that the asymptotic frequency of stochastic oscillator depends quadratically on the noise amplitude We describe scenario where this prediction holds though we also show that it is not true in general even for small noise Keywords Stochastic oscillators Isochron Quasi ergo dic measures

Visualizing Income Distribution in the United States Sang Truong Humberto Barreto Stanford University De Pau University Figure The rst perspective shows sign cant development of household income with adjustment from to in the Each slide along the percentile axis the shortest one represents state The median national household income distance the benchmark determines each states color in The red or blue colors represent state below or above the benchmark in respectively We take advantage of the colors to give viewers an overall sense of position changing patterns overtime ABSTRACT The distribution of household income is central concern of modern economic policy due to its strong in enc eon life quality Yet non expert audiences are unaware of the relationship between these two factors To effectively communicate the effect of income inequality on the quality of life and among the strata we have designed novel technique for visualizing income distribution and inequality over time by using the household income micro data from the Current Population Survey The result is striking dynamic animation of income distribution overtime drawing public attention and further investigating economic inequality Index Terms Human centered computing Visualization Visualization application domains Information visualization

Constructing deterministic automata from examples by an extension of the RP NI algorithm Len Boh RW TH Aachen University horns tr Aachen Germany Christof ding RW TH Aachen University horns tr Aachen Germany Abstract The RP NI algorithm On in Garcia constructs deterministic finite automata from finite sets of negative and positive example words We propose and analyze an extension of this algorithm to deterministic automata with different types of acceptance conditions In order to obtain this generalization of RP NI we develop algorithms for the standard acceptance conditions of automata that check for given set of example words and deterministic transition system whether these example words can be accepted in the transition system with corresponding acceptance condition Based on these algorithms we can define the extension of RP NI to infinite words We prove that it can learn all deterministic automata with an informative right congruence in the limit with polynomial time and data We also show that the algorithm while it can learn some automata that do not have an informative right congruence cannot learn deterministic automata for all regular languages in the limit Finally we also prove that active learning with membership and equivalence queries is not easier for automata with an informative right congruence than for general deterministic automata ACM Subject Classification Theory of computation Formal languages and automata theory Automata over infinite objects Keywords and phrases deterministic omega automata learning from examples learning in the limit constructing acceptance conditions active learning Digital Object Identifier LIP Ics MFC

fr Correspondence tru cu maths dundee ac uk Abstract Brain related experiments are limited by nature and so biological insights are often restricted or absent This is particularly problematic in the context of brain cancers which have at very poor survival rates To generate and test new biological hypotheses researchers started using mathematical models that can simulate tumour evolution However most of these models focus on single scale cell dynamics and cannot capture the complex multi scale tumour invasion patterns in brains particular role in these invasion patterns is likely played by the distribution of micro bres To investigate explicitly the role of brain micro bres in the invading tumours in this study Citation Suv ges we extend previously introduced multi scale moving boundary framework to take into account Hossain Ibrahim Steele multi scale tumour dynamics weighted and DT Is can are used as initial conditions for our Ef timi Tru cu Mathematical model and to para met rise changes in brain multi scale tumour morphology while in other cases it has no effect This maybe caused by the underlying brain moving boundary approach structure and its microscopic bre representation Human in the loop Extraction of Interpret able Concepts in Deep Learning Models Zheng Zhao Pan pan Xu Carlos Sc heidegger Liu Ren Fig Concept Extract supports human in the loop visual concept learning and uses the extracted visual concepts for fine grained model interpretation diagnostics and comparison an image patch view displays small patches or super pixels Fig segmented from the original images with informative overlays to facilitate interactive visual concept extraction It displays visually similar patches in close proximity without overlap Here the overlay shows pixel wise prediction accuracy for an image segmentation model for road scene understanding and the border color of each image patch encodes concept confidence score cross filter panel enable filtering patches based on the concept confidence scores and other statistics an active learning label er panel allows easy specification of positive and negative samples for training models model analysis panel using the learned visual concepts shadow cloud for fine grained model interpretation diagnostics and comparison model summary panel showing summary of the target model performance This figure shows Concept Extract being used to analyze an image segmentation model for road scene understanding in autonomous driving scenarios Please refer to Section for more detail Abstract The interpretation of deep neural networks DN Ns has become key topic as more and more people apply them to solve various problems and making critical decisions Concept based explanations have recently become popular approach for post hoc interpretation of DN Ns However identifying human understandable visual concepts that affect model decisions is challenging task that is not easily addressed with automatic approaches We present novel human in the loop approach to generate user defined concepts for model interpretation and diagnostics Central to our proposal is the use of active learning where human knowledge and feedback are combined to train concept extractor with very little human labeling effort We integrate this process into an interactive system Concept Extract Through two case studies we show how our approach helps analyze model behavior and extract human friendly concepts for different machine learning tasks and datasets and how to use these concepts to understand the predictions compare model performance and make suggestions for model refinement Quantitative experiments show that our active learning approach can accurately extract meaningful visual concepts More importantly by identifying visual concepts that negatively affect model performance we develop the corresponding data augmentation strategy that consistently improves model performance Index Terms Visual Data Exploration Deep Neural Network Model Interpretation Explain able

Second Order De featuring Error Estimator of Porosity on Structural Elastic Performance in Manufactured Metallic Components Shi guang Deng Carl oder hj elm Diran Ape liana Krishna Sure hb CRC Materials Science and Engineering University of California Irvine CA USA Mechanical Engineering University of Wisconsin Madison WI USA Abstract Manufactured metallic components often contain non uniformly distributed pores of complex morph logie Since such porosity defects have significant influence on material behaviors and affect the usage in high performance applications it is significant to understand the impact of porosity characteristics on the behaviors of components In this work gradient enhanced porosity de featuring estimator which allows for the modeling of pore geometry and spatial distribution is proposed within general el as to static framework In this approach the first order shape sensitivity is implemented to account for the change in elastic quantity of interests with respect to variations of pore sizes and shapes which is then supplemented by second order shape sensitivity whose mixed partial derivative quantifies the interactions between pores in proximity The efficacy of the proposed method comes from its posterior manner that it only relies on field solutions of reference models where pores are suppressed In this context meshing difficulty and solution convergence issue are avoided which would otherwise arise in direct finite element analysis on porous structures The impact of porosity on structural elastic performance is approximated using second order Taylor expansion where the topological difference between the porous and reference domains is estimated by topological sensitivity the field variables on pore boundaries are approximated as explicit functions of design variables using exterior formulations Numerical results show that the elastic performances of components are influenced by the existence of pores The pore to pore interactions are significant when pores are close by Keywords Manufacturing induced porosity pore to pore interactions de featuring tomography reconstruction design sensitivity

Reduced Order Multi scale Modeling of Plastic Deformations in Cast Metallic Alloys with Spatially Varying Micro structures Shi guang Deng Carl oder hj elm Diran peli an Ram in Bos tana bad CRC Materials Science and Engineering University of California Irvine CA USA Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering University of California Irvine CA USA Abstract Cast aluminum alloys are increasingly utilized as light weight materials in automobile industry due to their superior capability in withstanding high mechanical loads major challenge impeding the large scale use of these alloys in high performance applications is the presence of manufacturing induced spatially varying porosity defects To understand the impacts of these defects on the macro mechanical properties of cast alloys multi scale simulations are often required In this paper we introduce computationally efficient reduced order multi scale framework to simulate the behavior of metallic components containing process induced porosity under irreversible nonlinear deformations The proposed model starts from data compression scheme which significantly reduces the number of unknown variables by agglomerating close by finite element nodes into limited number of clusters It proceeds to project solution variables into lower dimensional space via novel reduced order method where the materials el as to plastic behaviors are approximated The model then combines with porosity oriented micro structure characterization and reconstruction algorithm to mimic the materials local heterogeneity with reconstructed pores of various morph logie and spatial distributions The performance and versatility of the proposed approach are demonstrated by several numerical experiments Keywords Multi scale simulation Reduced order model Micro structure reconstruction El as to plastic analysis Manufacturing induced porosity

Quantum Hamiltonian Simulation Benchmark Yu long Dong Bir it ta Whale and Lin Lin Berkeley Center for Quantum Information and Computation Berkeley California USA Department of Chemistry University of California Berkeley California USA Department of Mathematics University of California Berkeley California USA Computational Research Division Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory Berkeley CA USA and Challenge Institute of Quantum Computation University of California Berkeley California USA Dated August Hamiltonian simulation is one of the most important problems in quantum computation and quantum singular value transformation SVT is an ec ent way to simulate general class of Hamiltonians However the SVT circuit typically involves multiple an cilla qu bits and multi qu bit control gates We propose drastically implied quantum circuit called the minimal SVT circuit which uses only one an cilla qu bit to simulate class of qu bit random Hamiltonians We formulate simple metric called the quantum unitary evolution score QUES which is scalable quantum benchmark and can be ve ried without any need for classical computation We demonstrate that QUES is directly related to the circuit del it and the classical hardness of an associated quantum circuit sampling problem Theoretical analysis suggests under suitable assumptions there exists an optimal simulation time top at which even noisy quantum device may be uci ent to demonstrate the classical hardness
