Under consideration for publication in Theory and Practice of Logic Programming Harnessing Incremental Answer Set Solving for Reasoning in Assumption Based Argumentation UOMO LEHTO NEN University of Helsinki Finland mail uomo lehto nen helsinki fi JOHANNES WALLNER Graz University of Technology Austria mail wallner is tu graz at MATT JARVIS ALO University of Helsinki Finland mail matt jarvis alo helsinki fi submitted January revised January accepted January Abstract Assumption based argumentation ABA is central structured argumentation formalism As shown re cent ly answer set programming ASP enables efc ent ly solving NP hard reasoning tasks of ABA in practice in particular in the commonly studied logic programming fragment of ABA In this work we harness recent advances in incremental ASP solving for developing effective algorithms for reasoning tasks in the logic programming fragment of ABA that are presumably hard for the second level of the poly no mi al hierarchy including skeptical reasoning under preferred semantics as well as preferential reasoning In particular we develop non trivial counterexample guided abstraction rene ment procedures based on in re mental ASP solving for these tasks We also show empirically that the procedures are sign cant ly more effective than previously proposed algorithms for the tasks This paper is under consideration for acceptance in TPL KEYWORDS answer set programming incremental answer set solving assumption based argumentation structured argumentation algorithms experimental evaluation

Accounting for scalar non Gaussian it in secondary gravitational waves Ra gave ndra Centre for Strings Gravitation and Cosmology Department of Physics Indian Institute of Technology Madras Chennai India It is well known that enhancement in the primordial scalar perturbations over small scales generate detectable amplitudes of secondary gravitational waves GW by sourcing the tensor perturbations at the second order These stochastic gravitational waves are expected to carry the imprints of the primordial non Gaussian ties The scalar bi spectrum that is typically produced in models of nation leading to sign cant secondary GW is non trivial and highly scale dependent In this work we present method to account for such general scale dependent scalar bi spectrum arising from nation ary models in the calculation of the spectral density of secondary GW Using this method on two spec ic models of nation driven by canonical scalar el we nd that the corrections arising from the bi spectrum to the power spectrum are not sign cant to leave detectable imprints on secondary GW Though the corrections may not be sign cant in the scenarios considered the method discussed is robust free from assumptions about the shape of the bi spectrum and generalizes earlier approaches adopted in the literature We argue that this method of accounting for scalar bi spectrum shall be helpful in future computations for exotic models generating larger amplitudes of scalar non Gaussian ties along with sign cant amount of secondary GW

The Structure and Incentives of OVID related Emergency Wage Subsidy Jules Linden Cathal ODon og hue Denis Solo gon National University Ireland Galway Ireland Luxembourg Institute of Socio Economic Research LISE Abstract During recent crisis wage subsidies played major role in sheltering firms and households from economic shocks During OVID most workers were affected and many liberal welfare states introduced new temporary wage subsidies to protected workers earnings and employment across the income distribution OECD New wage subsidies however marked departure from the structure of traditional income support payments and required reform This paper uses simulated datasets to assess the structure and incentives of the Irish OVID wage subsidy scheme CW under five designs We use now casting approach to update micro data producing near real time picture of the labour market at the peak of the OVID crisis Using micro simulation modelling we assess the impact of different designs on income replacement work incentives and income inequality We find that changes in design substantially affected the functioning of the scheme Our findings suggest that pro rata designs support middle earners more and flat rate designs support low earners more We find evidence for strong work disincentive under all designs though flat rate designs perform better Disincentive are primarily driven by generous unemployment payments and changes in work related costs Matching the structure of the unemployment payment and the wage subsidy only partially addresses work disincentive The impact of design on income inequality largely depends on the generosity of payments Earnings related pro rata designs were associated to higher market earnings inequality The difference in inequality levels fall however once benefits taxes and work related costs are taking into consideration In our discussion we turn to transaction costs the rationale for reform and reintegration of the emergency wage subsidy We find some support for the claim that design changes were motivated by political considerations We suggest that establishing permanent wage subsidies based on sector al turnover rules could offer enhanced protection to middle and high earners during emergencies and reduce uncertainty the need for costly reform and the risk of politically motivated designs Keywords emergency response wage subsidy OVID micro simulation policy design EL codes The Authors are grateful to the Irish Health Research Board Irish Research Council and the Luxembourg Fond National de la Recherche NR AFR Individual for funding this research Corresponding Author Jules Linden email jules linden lise lu

Clio rd groups are not always designs Matthew Gray don Joshua kane Norman and Joel Wall man Institute for Quantum Computing University of Waterloo Waterloo Ontario Canada Department of Applied Mathematics University of Waterloo Waterloo Ontario Canada Key sight Technologies Canada Kanata ON Canada Dated August The Clio rd group is the quotient of the normalize of the We yl Heisenberg group in dimension by its centre We prove that when is not prime the Clio rd group is not group unitary design Furthermore we prove that the multi part it Clio rd group is not group unitary design except for the known cases where in the local Hilbert space dimensions are constant prime number We also clarify the structure of projective group unitary designs We show that the ad joint action induced by group unitary design decomposes into exactly two irreducible components moreover group is unitary design if and only if the character of its so called representation is

Guaranteed Functional Tensor Singular Value Decomposition Run gang Han Pix Shi and An ru Zhang Department of Statistics University of Wisconsin Madison Department of Biostatistics Bioinformatics Duke University August Abstract This paper introduces the functional tensor singular value decomposition TSV novel dimension reduction framework for tensors with one functional mode and several tabular modes The problem is motivated by high order longitudinal data analysis Our model assumes the observed data to be random realization of an approximate CP low rank functional tensor measured on discrete time grid Incorporating tensor algebra and the theory of Reproducing Kernel Hilbert Space RK HS we propose novel RK HS based constrained power iteration with spectral initialization Our method can successfully estimate both singular vectors and functions of the low rank structure in the observed data With mild assumptions we establish the non asymptotic contractive error bounds for the proposed algorithm The superiority of the proposed framework is demonstrated via extensive experiments on both simulated and real data

FliT Library for Simple and Efc ent Persistent Algorithms Yuan hao Wei Na ama Ben David Michal Friedman Guy Ble loch and rez Pet rank Carnegie Mellon University USA VMware Research USA Tech ni on Israel yuan hao cs cmu edu ben david vmware com michal cs tech ni on ac il guy cs cmu edu rez cs tech ni on ac il Abstract Non volatile random access memory NV RAM offers byte addressable persistence at speeds com para ble to DRAM However with caches remaining volatile automatic cache evictions can reorder updates to memory potentially leaving persistent memory in an inconsistent state upon system crash Flush and fence instructions can be used to force ordering among updates but are expensive This has motivated sign cant work studying how to write correct and efc ent persistent programs for NV RAM In this paper we present FliT aC library that facilitates writing efc ent persistent code Using the library default mode makes any linear iz able data structure durable with minimal changes to the code FliT avoids many redundant ush instructions by using novel algorithm to track dirty cache lines The FliT library also allows for extra optimization but achieves good performance even in its default setting To describe the FliT library capabilities and guarantees wed enea persistent programming interface called the Interface which FliT implements The Interface captures the expected behavior of code in which some instructions effects are persisted and some are not We show that the interface captures the desired semantics of many practical algorithms in the literature We apply the FliT library to four different persistent data structures and show that across several work loads persistence implementations and data structure sizes the FliT library always improves operation throughput by atleast over naive implementation in all but one workload

Kori Interactive Synthesis of Text and Charts in Data Documents Shahid Latif ZhengZhou Yoon Kim Fabian Beck and Nam Wook Kim Fig The Kori system consists of chart gallery left edit area middle and link setting panel right Kori automatically suggests potential references dotted gray underline as user types Besides it supports manual creation of links through simple interactions The steps describe usage scenario to create an interactive story see Sect Abstract Charts goh and in hand with text to communicate complex data and are widely adopted in news articles online blogs and academic papers They provide graphical summaries of the data while text explains the message and context However synthesizing information across text and charts is if cult it requires readers to frequently shift their attention We investigated ways to support the tight coupling of text and charts in data documents To understand their interplay we analyzed the design space of chart text references through news articles and sci en tic papers Informed by the analysis we developed mixed initiative interface enabling users to construct interactive references between text and charts It leverages natural language processing to automatically suggest references as well as allows users to manually construct other references effortlessly user study complemented with algorithmic evaluation of the system suggests that the interface provides an effective way to compose interactive data documents Index Terms Data driven storytelling interaction design authoring visualization text linking mixed initiative interface interactive documents

Defense Against Adversarial Swarms with Parameter Uncertainty Claire Walton Isaac Ka miner Qi Gong Abram Clark and Theodor os Ts at san ifos Abstract This paper addresses the problem of optimal This challenge raises many issues for instance how defense of High Value Unit against large scale swarm to search for the swarm how to observe and infer attack We show that the problem can be cast in the swarm operating algorithms and how to best defend framework of uncertain parameter optimal control and against the swarm given algorithm unknowns and only derive consistency result for the dual problem of this framework We show that the dual can be computed limited indirect control through external means In this numerically and apply these numerical results to derive paper we restrict ourselves to the last issue However optimal defender strategies against agent swarm these problems share multiple technical challenges The attack preliminary approach we apply in this paper demon Index Terms optimal control nonlinear control umer st rates some basic methods which we hope will provoke ical methods swarming development of more sophisticated tools For objectives achieved via external control of the

Classic ation Auto Encoder based Detector against Diverse Data Poisoning Attacks Fer es teh azmi Li Xiong Emory University fr azmi xiong emory edu Abstract Poisoning attacks are category of adversarial machine learning threats in which an adversary attempts to subvert the outcome of the ma chin learning systems by injecting crafted data into training data set thus increasing the machine learning models test error The adversary can tamper with the data feature space data labels or both each leading to die rent attack strategy with die rent strengths Various detection approaches have recently emerged each focusing on one attack strategy The Achilles heel of many of these detection approaches is their dependence on having access to clean un tampered data set In this paper we propose CAE Classic ation Auto Encoder based detector against diverse poisoned data CAE can detect all forms of poisoning attacks using combination of reconstruction and cl as si cation errors without having any prior knowledge of the attack strategy We show that an enhanced version of CAE called CAE does not have to employ clean data set to train the defense model Our experimental results on three real datasets NIST Fashion NIST and CI FAR demonstrate that our proposed method can maintain its functionality under up to cont am in ted data and help the defended SV classier to regain its best accuracy Keywords Data poisoning Anomaly detection Auto encoder

Implementation of high precision computation capabilities into the open source dynamic simulation framework YA DE Jane Ko zi kia Anton Glad ky Klaus Tho enid Faculty of Applied Physics and Mathematics Gdansk University of Technology Gdansk Poland Advanced Materials Center Gdansk University of Technology Gdansk Poland Institute for Mineral Processing Machines and Recycling Systems Technology TU Berg akademie Freiberg Freiberg Germany Centre for Geotechnical Science and Engineering The University of Newcastle Callaghan Australia Abstract This paper deals with the implementation of arbitrary precision calculations into the open source discrete element framework YA DE published under the GPL free software license This new capability paves the way for the simulation framework to be used in many new lds such as quantum mechanics The implementation details and associated gains in the accuracy of the results are discussed Besides the stan dard double bits type support for the following high precision types is added long double bits float bits mp fr float backend arbitrary precision and cpp bin float arbitrary precision Benchmarks are performed to quantify the additional computational cost involved with the new supported precisions Finally simple calculation of chaotic triple pendulum is performed to demonstrate the new capabilities and the eec of die rent precisions on the simulation result Keywords arbitrary accuracy multiple precision arithmetic dynamical systems computational techniques numerical analysis Lj error theory Dk

SUPER DC STABLE SUPER FAST DIVIDE AND CONQUER EIGENVALUE DECOMPOSITION XIAO FENG OU AND JIAN LIN XIA Abstract For dense Hermit ian matrices with small diagonal numerical ranks and in hierarchically semi separable form we give stable divide and conquer ei gen decomposition method with nearly linear complexity called Super DC that sign cant ly improves an earlier basic algorithm in Vogel Xia et al SIAM Sci Com put We incorporate sequence of key stability techniques and provide many improvements in the algorithm design Various stability risks in the original algorithm are analyzed including potential exponential norm growth cancellations loss of accuracy with clustered eigenvalues or intermediate eigenvalues etc In the dividing stage we give new structured low rank update strategy with balancing that eliminates the exponential norm growth and also minimizes the ranks of low rank updates In the conquering stage with low rank updated eigenvalue solution the original algorithm directly uses the regular fast multi pole method MM to accelerate function evaluations which has the risks of cancellation division by zero and slow convergence Here we design triangular MM to avoid cancellation Furthermore when there are clustered intermediate eigenvalues or when updates to existing eigenvalues are very small we design novel local shifting strategy to integrate MM accelerations into the solution of shifted secular equations so as to achieve both the ec ien cy and the reliability We also provide several improvements or clar cations on some structures and techniques that are missing or unclear in the previous work The resulting Super DC ei gen solver has sign cant ly better stability while keeping the nearly linear complexity for ding the entire eigenvalue decomposition In set of comprehensive tests Super DC shows dramatically lower runtime and storage than the Mat lab ig function The stability be nets are also con med with both analysis and numerical comparisons Key words super fast eigenvalue decomposition stable divide and conquer ei gen solver rank structured matrix triangular fast multi pole method shifted secular equation local shifting AMS subject classic at ions

Geometric Horizons in Binary Black Hole Mergers Alan Coley Jeremy Peters and Erik Sch net ter Department of Mathematics and Statistics Dalhousie University Halifax Nova Scotia Canada Perimeter Institute for Theoretical Physics Waterloo Ontario Canada Department of Physics Astronomy University of Waterloo Waterloo ON Canada Center for Computation Technology Louisiana State University Baton Rouge LA USA August Abstract We numerically study the algebraic properties of the We yl tensor through the merger of two non spinning black holes We are particularly interested in the conjecture that for such vacuum spacetime which is zeroth order algebraically general geometric horizon on which the spacetime is algebraically special and which is den tied by the vanish ing of complex scalar invariant characterizes smooth folia tion independent surface horizon associated with the black hole In the rst simulation we investigate the level sets of Re since Im in the head on collision of two unequal mass black holes In the second simulation we shall investigate the level sets of through quasi circular merger of two non spinning equal mass black holes The umer ical results as displayed in the gur es presented provide evidence that unique smooth geometric horizon can bei den tied throughout all stages of the binary black hole merger

Scalable Bayesian transport maps for high dimensional non Gaussian spatial lds Matthias Katz fuss Florian Schafer Abstract multivariate distribution can be described by triangular transport map from the target distribution to simple reference distribution We propose Bayesian non parametric inference on the transport map by modeling its components using Gaussian processes This enables regular iz ation and accounting for uncertainty in the map es imation while still resulting in closed form and invertible posterior map We then focus on inferring the distribution of non stationary spatial el from small num ber of replicates We develop spec ic transport map priors that are highly ex ble but shrink toward Gaussian el with Mater type co variance The approach is scalable to high dimensional lds due to data dependent sparsity and parallel comp tat ions We also discuss extensions including Di rich let process mixtures for marginal non Gaussian it We present numerical results to demonstrate the accuracy scala bil it and usefulness of our methods including statistical emulation of non Gaussian climate model output Keywords climate model emulation Di rich let process mixture Gaussian process maxim in or de ring non station ari ty sparse triangular transport

Auto Video An Automated Video Action Recognition System Dao chen Zha Zaid Pervaiz Bhat Yi Wei Chen Yi cheng Wang Sir ui Ding An moll Kumar Jain Mohammad Qazi mBh at wei Her ng Lai Jia be nChen NaZo XiaH Department of Computer Science Rice University Department of Computer Science and Engineering Texas University Department of Engineering Technology and Industrial Distribution Texas University dao chen zha hlai xiah rice edu zaid bhat yi wei chen wang sir ui ding jain an moll kumar nz ou amu edu qazi mbh at gmail com chen jb shanghai tech edu cn Abstract Action recognition is crucial task for video understand ing In this paper we present Auto Video Python ys tem for automated video action recognition It currently sup ports seven action recognition algorithms and various pre processing modules Unlike the existing libraries that only CSV Reader provide model zoos Auto Video is built with the standard pipeline language The basic building block is primitive which wraps pre processing module or an algorithm with Pre Processing Frame Extraction some hyper parameters Auto Video is highly modular and ex tend able It can be easily combined with Auto ML searchers The pipeline language is quite general so that we can easily Frame Transformation enrich Auto Video with algorithms for various other video related tasks in the future Auto Video is released under MIT license at https it hub com data ml lab auto video TSN TS ECO

Lorentz symmetry in ghost free massive gravity Alan Ko stele ky and Robert us Potting Physics Department Indiana University Bloomington Indiana USA Universidade do Algarve acul dade de Ciencia Tecnol ogi Far Portugal and CENT RA IS Universidade de Lisboa Avenida ovis co Pais Lisboa Portugal Dated August The role of Lorentz symmetry in ghost free massive gravity is studied emphasizing features emer ing in approximately Minkowski spacetime The static ext rem and saddle points of the potential are determined and their Lorentz properties den tied Solutions preserving Lorentz in variance and ones breaking four of the six Lorentz generators are constructed Locally globally and absolutely stable Lorentz invariant ext rem are found to exist for certain parameter ranges of the potential Gravitational waves in the linear zed theory are investigated Deviations of the duc al metric from the Minkowski metric are shown to lead to pent are fr in gence of the ve wave polarizations which can include super lumina modes and sub lumina modes with negative energies in certain observer frames The Newton limit of ghost free massive gravity is explored The prop gator is constructed and used to obtain the gravitational potential energy between two point masses The result extends the Fier Pauli limit to include corrections generically breaking both rotation and boost in variance

Neural Network Repair with Reach ability Analysis XIAO DO NGYANG Vanderbilt University USA TOM YAMAGUCHI TR IN Toyota NAR USA HO ANG DUNG TR AN University of Nebraska USA BARD HOXHA TR IN Toyota NAR USA TAYLOR JOHNSON Vanderbilt University USA DAN IL PRO KHOR OV TR IN Toyota NAR USA Safety is critical concern for the next generation of autonomy that is likely to rely heavily on deep neural networks for perception and control Formally verifying the safety and robustness of well trained DN Ns and learning enabled cyber physical systems Le CP under adversarial attacks model uncertainties and sensing errors is essential for safe autonomy This research proposes framework to repair unsafe DN Ns in safety critical systems with reach ability analysis The repair process is inspired by adversarial training which has demonstrated high effectiveness in improving the safety and robustness of DN Ns Different from traditional adversarial training approaches where adversarial examples are utilized from random attacks and may not be representative of all unsafe behaviors our repair process uses reach ability analysis to compute the exact unsafe regions and identify sufficiently representative examples to enhance the efficacy and efficiency of the adversarial training The performance of our repair framework is evaluated on two types of benchmarks without safe models as references One is aD NN controller for aircraft collision avoidance with access to training data The other is rocket lander where our framework can be seamlessly integrated with the well known deep deterministic policy gradient DDP reinforcement learning algorithm The experimental results show that our framework can successfully repair all instances on multiple safety specifications with negligible performance degradation In addition to increase the computational and memory efficiency of the reach ability analysis algorithm in the framework we propose depth first search algorithm that combines an existing exact analysis method with an over approximation approach based on new set representation Experimental results show that our method achieves five fold improvement in runtime and two fold improvement in memory usage compared to exact analysis Additional KeyWords and Phrases Neural network repair reach ability analysis safe reinforcement learning

FERMILAB PUB Beware of Fake The Eec of Massive Neutrinos on the Non Linear Evolution of Cosmic Structure Adrian Bayer Ark Banerjee and Uro Selja Berkeley Center for Cosmological Physics University of California Berkeley CA USA Department of Physics University of California Berkeley CA USA Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory Cosmic Physics Center Batavia IL USA Physics Division Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory Cyclotron Road Berkeley CA USA Dated August Massive neutrinos suppress the growth of cosmic structure on small non linear scales It is thus often proposed that using statistics beyond the power spectrum can tighten constraints on the neutrino mass by extracting additional information from these non linear scales We study the information content regarding neutrino mass at the el level quantifying how much of this information arises from the die rence in non linear evolution between cosmology with id CD and ids CD neutrinos We do so by running two body simulations one with and one without massive neutrinos both with the same phases and matching their linear power spectrum at given low redshift This eec iv ely isolates the information encoded in the linear initial conditions from the non linear cosmic evolution We demonstrate that for cid Mpc and for single redshift there is negligible die rence in the real space CD el between the two simulations This suggests that all the information regarding neutrinos is in the linear power spectrum set by the initial conditions Thus any probe based on the CD el alone will have negligible constraining power beyond that which exists at the linear level over the same range of scales Consequently any probe based on the halo el will contain little information beyond the linear power We nd similar results for the matter el responsible for weak lensing We also demonstrate that there may be much information beyond the power spectrum in the matter el however this is not observable in modern surveys via dark matter halos or weak lensing Finally we show that there is additional information to be found in redshift space

MUL PH SAGE Classical gravitational scattering from gauge invariant double copy Andreas Brand huber Gang Chen Gabriele rava gl in and Cong kao Wen Centre for Theoretical Physics Department of Physics and Astronomy Queen Mary University of London Mile End Road London NS United Kingdom mail brand huber mul ac uk chen mul ac uk rava gl in mul ac uk wen mul ac uk Abstract We propose method to compute the scattering angle for classical black hole scattering directly from two massive particle irreducible diagrams in heavy mass eec ti ve el theory approach to general relativity without the need of subtracting it ration terms The amplitudes in this eec ti ve theory are constructed using recently proposed novel colour kinematic double copy for tree level two scalar multi graviton amplitudes where the BC numerators are gauge invariant and local with respect to the massless gravitons These tree amplitudes together with graviton tree amplitudes enter the construction of the required dimensional loop in te grands and allow for direct extraction of contributions relevant for classical physics In particular the soft heavy mass expansions of full in te grands is circumvented and all iterating con tri but ions can be dropped from the get go We use this method to compute the scattering angle up to third post Minkowski an order in four dimensions including radiation re ac tion contributions also providing the expression of the corresponding in te grand in dimensions
